We depend on our technical infrastructure for all aspects of the day-to-day management of our business and the delivery of our services. Any material disruption to the operation of such infrastructure, including as a result of legislative and regulatory changes regarding online sales and e-commerce, may materially and negatively affect our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations. Interruptions in these systems, whether due to system failures, computer viruses, software errors or physical or electronic break-ins, or other factors could affect the security or availability of our products and services on our websites or mobile applications and prevent or inhibit the ability of vendors and buyers to access our services. Electronic break-ins and cyber security attacks continue to increase in both prevalence and sophistication throughout the digital world with the potential to corrupt, affect or destroy key systems and data, including the confidentiality, integrity and availability of our data and systems. Given that techniques used in these break-ins and attacks change frequently and often are not recognized until launched against a target, it may be impossible to properly secure our systems. In addition, technical advances or a continued expansion and increased complexity of our digital offering could increase the likelihood of security breaches. The risk of electronic break-ins and cyber security attacks includes breaches and attempted breaches not only of our own products, services and systems, but also of those of our customers, employees, contractors, business partners, and other third parties as well as of third-party systems on which we rely to operate our digital platforms. ----- Successful breaches, employee malfeasance, or human or technological error could result in, for example, unauthorized access to, disclosure, modification, misuse, loss, or destruction of our data or systems or those of our customers or other third parties, theft of sensitive, regulated, or confidential data including personal information and intellectual property, loss of access to critical data or systems through ransomware, destructive attacks or other means, and business delays, service or system disruptions or denials of service. In addition, the fast-paced, evolving, pervasive and sophisticated nature of certain cyber threats and vulnerabilities, as well as the scale and complexity of the business and infrastructure, make it possible that certain threats or vulnerabilities will be undetected or unmitigated in time to prevent an attack on one of our customers and its customers. Furthermore, these risks will increase as we continue to shift of our operating model towards an online business in response to the COVID 19 pandemic. Problems with the reliability, availability or security of our systems and digital service offerings could harm our reputation, result in a loss of vendors or buyers or necessitate additional costs, fines or penalties, any of which could harm our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations. Certain vendors, as a condition of operating through us, audit our information and technology systems. These audits may require significant management time to address and could result in costly changes to information and technology systems as a condition of continued operation. The loss of the supply of vehicles from a vendor or the cost of changes to our information and technology systems following an audit could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations. Robust back office systems, including auction information systems, are also critical to our ability to attract visitors to our websites. These systems are also imperative for the operation of our website and mobile applications, pricing, third-party data feeds, customer service, internal and external communications, procurement, logistics, administration and financial reporting. In addition, we are dependent on certain third-party information and technology systems, particularly with respect to payment processing, vehicle licensing checks and fraud detection. In particular, we face liability risks in connection with online credit card fraud and problems adequately securing our payment systems, despite using market-standard protocols designed to ensure enhanced security and strong identification for our customers when they use their debit or credit cards for vehicle purchases. The failure or unavailability of any of our information and technology systems to detect such type of fraud or other errors with respect to payment processing or vehicle licensing checks could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations. Much of our physical information and technology infrastructure (including servers, website hosting, database storage and wide area networks) is supplied by service providers via managed services contracts. Technical or other service problems faced by our managed service providers could adversely affect the experience of our vendors and buyers. Any financial or operational difficulties faced by our managed service providers or any of the third-party service providers with whom they contract may have adverse effects on our business, the nature and extent of which are difficult to predict. Furthermore, any disruption of the distribution channels or networks used by our mobile applications could adversely affect the ability to access or update our mobile applications, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations. Our success also depends on our continued innovation and ability to provide features that make our websites and mobile applications user-friendly, particularly through the development of specific software and applications under a variety of new platforms and operating systems, which are generally expected by users to offer the same features or flexibility and to be as easily and intuitively operated as desktop interfaces. As technology improves and as our operations grow in size, scope and complexity, we will need to improve and upgrade our systems and infrastructure, which may require substantial financial, operational and technical resources. Delays or difficulties in implementing new or enhanced systems may impair our ability to provide digital services to our vendors and buyers or may reduce the effectiveness of digital auctions, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business
Subsubsection Title: Acceptance of our digital platforms and mobile applications as suitable platforms for the sale and purchase of used vehicles may decrease or fail to improve.
Subsubsection Text: The restrictions on physical sales activity (including physical auctions) due to the COVID 19 pandemic has significantly increased the volume of vehicles traded digitally across the used vehicle market and via the Marketplace. While the acceptance of our digital platforms has been strong by both buyers and vendors, there is no guarantee that overall online acceptance in the used vehicle market will be maintained or increased. If the acceptance of our digital offering decreases or fails to grow, we may not be able to achieve the future growth we target. -----

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business
Subsubsection Title: Our inventory and vehicles held on behalf of others may be damaged by extreme weather or other events outside our control, and the insurance we carry may be inadequate.
Subsubsection Text: During the handling of new and used vehicles across the business, large numbers of vehicles are transported and stored by us in both covered and open-air facilities. We are liable for the vehicles we own (the majority of which are purchased through the Vehicle Buying division) and, in many cases, we are liable for the vehicles supplied by vendors for auction through the Vehicle Remarketing division, as well as when we collect and deliver vehicles through our logistics services. Extreme weather, such as hail storms, fire and flooding, which has in the past damaged vehicles in our possession, natural disasters (such as extreme precipitation or extreme temperature) or other catastrophic events (such as terrorism and large-scale accidents) may adversely affect our physical facilities or damage vehicles awaiting sale or vehicles generally stored by us. Such risks are particularly prevalent in respect of our open air facilities. In addition, there is no assurance that used vehicles in our inventory will be properly protected (e.g., against theft or vandalism). This may result in an increase in costs, delay or cancelation of auction sales, any of which could have a material adverse impact on our revenue and profitability. Our failure to meet vendors’ or buyers’ demands in such situations could further adversely affect our reputation, reduce customer satisfaction, damage relationships with both vendors and buyers and result in a loss of future business. We maintain insurance cover for risks including property damage, business interruption, employers and public liability, as well as for certain other claims consistent with customary practice in the industry in which we operate. However, claims not covered by our insurance or in excess of our insurance coverage may arise, such as from a natural disaster, theft or other causes outside our control. Moreover, we may be unable in future periods to obtain insurance coverage on acceptable terms, without substantial premiums increase or at all, particularly if there is deterioration in our claim experience history. A successful claim against us, which is not covered by or in excess of our coverage could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to complex taxation in multiple jurisdictions, in particular relating to valued-added taxes.
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to taxation in multiple jurisdictions, including in the UK and continental Europe. Because of the complex interplay between our business and the various taxation regimes to which we are subject, the provision made for taxes in the accounts involves a significant amount of judgement and uncertainty regarding the interpretation of relevant facts and laws in the jurisdictions in which we operate. Changes to existing tax laws or tax reporting obligations, or the introduction of new tax laws or obligations (for instance with regards to online sales), in any of these jurisdictions could adversely impact our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations. The risks associated to unforeseen changes to existing tax laws or tax reporting obligations are compounded by the uncertainty created by Brexit and legislatives changes in connection thereto (see “—We are exposed to general economic, political and regulatory conditions and risks in _the countries in which we have operations and customers”) and the shift of our operating model towards an_ online business in response to the COVID 19 pandemic (see “—The COVID 19 pandemic has had, and will _continue to have, a significant adverse effect on our business, operations, financial condition, operating results and liquidity, and the ultimate outcome of the COVID 19 pandemic is uncertain”)._ Additionally, we are subject to complex laws and regulations in many countries involving VAT and other indirect taxes. In the jurisdictions in which we operate, we are responsible for collecting any VAT amounts due on the vehicles we sell, and we rely on our vendors to provide accurate and complete information relating to the VAT status of each vehicle to enable us to calculate the amount of any VAT due. We also rely on purchasers of our vehicles at auction to provide accurate information regarding their residency in order to assess appropriate treatment of VAT for sales invoices. If a vendor or buyer provides incorrect or incomplete VATrelated information, or if we fail to implement or fully comply with local VAT rules and regulations, we may be exposed to VAT claims and fines from relevant authorities. In the ordinary course of our business, we are frequently subject to VAT and other tax audits by relevant authorities throughout Europe, and these audits can relate to matters that arose many years in the past. The outcome of these audits could result in additional VAT claims and/or regulatory actions against us, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business
Subsubsection Title: We may not successfully implement our strategic initiatives.
Subsubsection Text: Our future operating results are dependent, in part, on our success in implementing our strategic and tactical initiatives. These initiatives are focused on enhancing our competitive advantage as an integrated end-to-end ----- service provider, further expanding internationally, strengthening our infrastructure and logistics network, capitalizing on favorable industry trends, continuing to enhance our data capabilities and improving our operational efficiencies, cash flow and leverage. These initiatives will require extensive planning and management attention and entail substantial execution risk. Notably, our strategy is focused on meaningful growth of vehicle volumes transaction through our marketplaces. Such volume growth requires simultaneous success in several different domains including: (i) commercial success with vendors, so they supply higher volume to our marketplaces; (ii) maintained data leadership in order for the marketplaces to provide efficient liquidity to all participants; (iii) digital product leadership to make our integrated services offering the most relevant in the market; and (iv) best-in-class logistics and services footprint to deliver an integrated end-to-end digital and physical service. Failure to maintain our competitive advantages in any of these dimension could have a material could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations. In addition, new digital platforms will also require substantial IT support and infrastructure and, as we grow, we will need to ensure our back-office IT systems are integrated across our operations. With respect to the Vehicle Buying division, our strategy places particular importance on expanding WeBuyAnyCar’s operations. However, there can be no assurance that WeBuyAnyCar will continue to grow in the UK. As we seek to expand car buying into new markets, we may also need to comply with unfamiliar regulatory regimes. In addition, because car buying involves purchasing vehicles and holding them as inventory until their sale (in contrast to our UK Vehicle Remarketing division and our International Vehicle Remarketing division, which do not include WeBuyAnyCar’s operations, and do not take title to the majority of vehicles that they sell), the expansion of such operations may increase our cash requirements and inventory risk, thereby increasing our depreciation and impairment charges. Similarly, recalls by OEMs are a common occurrence and have accelerated in frequency and scope in recent years. In case of such recalls, we may have to temporarily remove the affected used vehicles from our inventory and may be unable to liquidate such inventory in a timely manner or at all. The same may occur if regulatory changes (e.g., the introduction of stricter emission standards) prevent consumers from driving certain used vehicles in cities or at all, consequently reducing demand for the affected vehicles. If we are unable to sell the vehicles purchased at an appropriate price, or at all, we may incur write-downs or our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations may be adversely affected. In addition, the implementation of our strategic initiatives in certain international markets may not produce the benefits achieved in markets where we already have established operations. Each new market that we enter will require us to address the particular economic, currency, political and regulatory risks associated with that new market, which may entail finding new partners, hiring and training new staff with local language skills and an understanding of the local market, and learning the customs and cultures of the new country. These processes can be difficult, costly and divert management and personnel resources. Additionally, our business strategies may change from time to time, which could delay our ability to implement initiatives that we believe are important to our business. Our inability to successfully implement our strategic initiatives could result in, among others, the loss of clients and personnel, the loss of market share, the impairment of assets and inefficiencies from operating in new markets, any of which could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business
Subsubsection Title: We may be unable to successfully identify and acquire or integrate future acquisitions into our business.
Subsubsection Text: Our growth has been, in part, attributable to the acquisition of other businesses, and we may continue to expand our business through acquisitions and other business combinations in the future. The success of our acquisition strategy will depend on our ability to identify suitable acquisition candidates, to assess the value, strengths, weaknesses, contingent or other liabilities and potential profitability of acquisition candidates, to negotiate acceptable purchase terms, to obtain any necessary permits or approvals and to integrate the operations of such businesses, once acquired. Successful integration of future acquisitions will depend on our ability to effect any necessary changes in operations or personnel resulting from the acquisition. Acquisitions may also expose us to new risks, including difficulties in integrating and operating businesses in countries that are new to us, difficulties integrating acquired businesses in a cost-effective manner, unforeseen legal, regulatory, contractual, employment or other issues or expenses arising out of an acquisition, potential disruptions to our ongoing business caused by acquisitions, including pressure on management’s time and resources, or an acquired business’ failure to meet our expectations or business plans. The occurrence of any ----- of these risks could have an adverse impact on our ability to make acquisitions and may limit our growth, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business
Subsubsection Title: We may not be able to provide financing in order to offer stock funding (trade finance) to registered dealers through BCA Partner Finance or to repossess the financed vehicles serving as collateral.
Subsubsection Text: To support the attractiveness of our offering, we seek to help certain registered dealers in the UK by offering stock funding (trade finance). To this end, we have entered into a £220 million non-recourse receivables facility (the “Receivables Facility”) with a syndicate of banks, who provide the liquidity to support our BCA Partner Finance business, of which £148.3 million was drawn as of March 28, 2021. If these banks are no longer willing to provide financing to us or only grant such financing on disadvantageous terms, we may not be able to offer attractive financing options to registered dealers. As a result, demand for our used vehicles may suffer and we may not be able to grow our business as envisaged. In addition, we use our sold vehicles as security when offering stock funding (trade finance) and cooperate with third-party collection agents to repossess such vehicles, should registered dealers default on their obligations. We may, however, not be able to locate the relevant vehicles and successfully repossess them (e.g., if they are transported outside the UK). Furthermore, the residual value of the repossessed vehicles may be lower than anticipated (e.g., if they are involved in accidents), and we may not be able to take recourse against the relevant car dealer. As a result, we may incur significant losses even where we use sold vehicles as security for BCA Partner Finance. See “Business—Operations—Value-Added Services—Post-auction Services.”

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business
Subsubsection Title: We may not be able to protect our intellectual property rights.
Subsubsection Text: Our intellectual property rights include proprietary technology and software relating to digital auction systems as well as trademarks, trade secrets, copyrights and other intellectual property. Our increased reliance in recent years on proprietary Internet-based programs and technology have increased the relative importance of intellectual property assets to our business. Our business and IT systems and other key proprietary intellectual property generally are not protected by patents or registered design rights. As a result, we are particularly reliant on trademarks, copyright, database rights, registered domain names and the law protecting confidential information to protect our brands, technologies, software and databases. Although we have taken steps to reduce these risks, these steps may be inadequate. Effective intellectual property protection also may not be available in every country in which our services are offered, deployed or made available. Any significant impairment of our intellectual property rights or any inability to protect our intellectual property rights could have an adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations. Moreover, we may be required to spend significant funds on monitoring and protecting our intellectual property rights and we may not be able to discover all infringements, misappropriations or other violations of our intellectual property. If we initiate litigation against infringements of our intellectual property, such litigation may prove costly and there is no guarantee that it will ultimately be successful and that the rulings we obtain will adequately remedy the damage we have suffered. In addition, we provide certain information to third-party service providers who help us assess the performance of our business (e.g., Google Analytics). Consequently, we only have limited control to ensure that such information is not misused by such service providers or passed on to third parties, including our competitors.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business
Subsubsection Title: We may be accused of infringing on the intellectual property of third parties.
Subsubsection Text: As we utilize a variety of intellectual property for our business, vendors, regulatory authorities or other third parties may allege that we infringe on their intellectual property, and we may therefore become subject to allegations and litigation against us. Even unfounded allegations of infringement may adversely affect our reputation and business and may require significant resources to defend against. If we try to obtain licenses from such third parties to settle these disputes, there is no guarantee that such licenses will be available to us on acceptable terms, or at all, in which case we may be required to alter our brands and change the way we operate. Furthermore, some of the agreements we enter into with third parties may contain clauses regarding the protection of their intellectual property licensed to us. A violation of these clauses (e.g., the unauthorized sub-licensing or disclosure of a confidential source code) may require us to pay significant penalties, prevent us from utilizing such intellectual property in the future and result in litigation against us. In addition, some of our proprietary technology was developed on the basis of proprietary and non-proprietary software licensed from third parties. If these licenses were to be challenged or found invalid through litigation or other ----- proceedings, we may not be able to continue to utilize such proprietary technology. In addition, the licensors or other third parties may claim that the use of such technology is outside the scope of the relevant license and therefore infringes upon their intellectual property.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business
Subsubsection Title: We may be adversely affected by changes in laws and regulations, in particular those governing the trading of used vehicles and the automotive industry in general.
Subsubsection Text: We are required to comply with a wide range of laws and regulations relating to, among other things, the purchase and sale of used vehicles, the state of such vehicles, the use of the internet, online payments, consumer protection, data protection as well as road traffic, environmental, planning and employment matters, and the application of such laws and regulations by local authorities may vary. We may face risks associated with unexpected changes in the regulatory environment, particularly in relation to complexity of domestic and international customs and tariffs, potentially adverse tax consequences, restrictions on foreign trade or investment, currency exchange and capital controls, nationalization and expropriation and cancelation of our contractual relationships without full compensation for loss. Any changes in the laws and regulations, applicable to our business and operations, including used vehicles in our inventory, as well as the Marketplace, or changes to the application and interpretation of such laws and regulations by authorities and courts, may adversely affect our operations (such as the supply of vehicles) or may give rise to substantial compliance costs, adjustment expenses and other costs as well as fines in connection with our business activities, or prevent us from executing our strategy as planned. Even legislative initiatives and the corresponding public debates could result in significant uncertainty, regardless of whether such initiatives ultimately become law. We must comply with such regulations to the extent they are applicable to us as noncompliance could lead to the imposition of fines or other sanctions.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business
Subsubsection Title: Our failure to prevent unauthorized access to personal data or otherwise process personal data in accordance with applicable data protection laws could result in legal liability for, and reputational harm.
Subsubsection Text: We process and store personal data as part of our business, including in relation to our employees, vendors and buyers. Strict data protection laws exist in both the UK and throughout continental Europe. These data protection laws require us to ensure an appropriate level of security of personal data, having regard to the possibility of damage to and the nature of the data. Failure to take appropriate information security measures could result in personal data being processed in an unauthorized or potentially unlawful manner. The General Data Protection Regulation (Regulation (EU) 2016/679) (the “GDPR”) and the UK Data Protection Act 2018 significantly change the data protection landscape in the EU and the UK. Such laws and regulations strengthen the rights of individuals (data subjects), impose stricter controls over the processing of personal data by both controllers and processors of personal data and impose stricter sanctions with substantial administrative fines and potential claims for damages from data subjects for breach of their rights. The GDPR also offers data subjects the option to allow privacy organizations to litigate on their behalf, including collecting potential damages, which may result in a substantial increase in claims being brought. Should a serious data breach occur, the GDPR provides for increased obligations to notify regulators and data subjects whose personal data has been compromised and may result in the imposition of significant sanctions and penalties, which will require heightened escalation and notification processes with associated response plans. Complying with all relevant data protection laws and regulation is relatively complex. We, or the entities or businesses acquired by us, may have entered in the past or may enter in the future into employment agreements or other types of material contracts that may not be compliant with applicable data protection laws and regulations. Moreover, our customers frequently require that we demonstrate our compliance with data protection laws as they deem appropriate with respect to any personal data we may process on their behalf. Failure to demonstrate such compliance to their satisfaction may result in action including, but not limited to, the loss of contracts with such customers. The failure to comply with our obligations under applicable data protection laws could potentially result in us being issued with undertakings, enforcement notices (the failure with which to comply would be a criminal offence) and fines, as well as suffer damage to our brand and reputation, any of which could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to a variety of laws and regulations across the jurisdictions in which we operate, some of which are unsettled and still developing.
Subsubsection Text: Our operations are subject to compliance with extensive laws and regulations, both in the UK and across continental Europe, including, but not limited to, laws relating to vehicle brokerages and auctions, currency ----- reporting obligations, data protection, competition, consumer protection, advertising, the Internet, property usage, money laundering, bribery and taxation. A failure to comply with these laws and regulations could result in fines, criminal sanctions, liability to third parties, license revocation and reputational damage, which in turn could adversely affect our ability to conduct our business as well as our profitability. Furthermore, if laws and regulations are not enforced equally against our competitors in a particular market, our compliance with laws and regulations may put us at a competitive disadvantage vis-à-vis non-complying competitors. Changes in laws or regulations or the adoption of new laws and regulations applicable to us may also increase the costs of providing services or limit our ability to expand our service offerings, any of which could adversely impact our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations. More stringent laws or regulations may impose additional burdens on us, and it is difficult to predict the impact of new or amended laws or regulations to which we may become subject. There is, and will likely continue to be, an increasing number of laws, regulations and court decisions pertaining to the Internet and online commerce, which may relate to liability for information retrieved from or transmitted over the Internet. For example, in certain jurisdictions where we operate, local regulations impose restrictions on or prohibit credit and debit card operations in order to protect the privacy and security of personal information that is collected, processed and transmitted in or from the governing jurisdiction. The growth and development of online commerce has also prompted calls for more stringent consumer protection laws and more aggressive enforcement efforts by regulatory authorities that may impose additional burdens on online businesses generally. Because of our relatively large physical property portfolio, we are also subject to the risk that we could be compelled by government authorities to sell or vacate the property on which we operate or to make significant changes to the operations and activities we undertake to comply with changes to planning regulations. Furthermore, because of our international operations, the various regulatory regimes to which we are subject may conflict so that compliance with the regulatory requirements in one jurisdiction may create regulatory issues in another, thereby making compliance more difficult and increasing the costs of conducting our business. In addition, if we were to expand into new countries, we could face legal, regulatory or tax requirements with which we are not familiar. Compliance with current or future laws and regulations to which we are subject could place significant demands on our resources, as well as subject us to unforeseen and potentially adverse legal, regulatory or tax consequences, which could adversely impact our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business
Subsubsection Title: Our costs could materially increase.
Subsubsection Text: Our largest cost is payroll, driven primarily by the number of our employees and their wages and salaries. If relationships with our employees were to deteriorate, we could experience strikes, unionization efforts or other types of conflicts, which could lead to interruption to our operations and increased costs. In addition, payroll costs could increase because we compete with other service providers to recruit and retain skilled employees, which has become more challenging as a result of Brexit and the related restrictions on free movement of labor across the English Channel. High employment levels can lead to scarcity of staff and a corresponding increase in the wages and salaries necessary to attract and retain suitable employees may be indispensable in the future. In addition, future legislative changes relating to the minimum wage could necessitate an increase in payroll costs. We also undertake significant marketing activities, in particular for our Vehicle Buying division, and any increase in television, radio and Internet advertising rates could increase our operating expenses. Moreover, we incur significant fuel, power and other consumable supply costs across our operations that may escalate and there can be no assurance that our costs will not grow at a faster rate than our revenue. If we are unable to pass on future cost increases to our vendors or buyers, our operating profit margin could be adversely affected, which could adversely impact our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business
Subsubsection Title: We rely on the strength of our brands, and the costs of maintaining and enhancing our brand awareness may increase.
Subsubsection Text: Our brands, corporate image and reputation constitute a significant part of our value proposition. Our success over the years has largely depended on our ability to develop our brands and corporate image as a leading vehicle auction company in the UK and continental Europe. In addition, the WeBuyAnyCar consumer brand in the UK is particularly important to the Vehicle Buying division, and the development of the WeBuyAnyCar brand historically has required significant financial expenditure, particularly on marketing and advertising. ----- In order to maintain WeBuyAnyCar’s reputation, we have to be able to respond to changes in marketing and advertising rules, consumer sentiment and consumer preferences, all of which may change rapidly and as a result of factors outside of our control. Our brands could be adversely affected by the actions of other companies that damage the reputation of our industry as a whole, in particular in relation to the Vehicle Buying division, as several companies operate under names similar to WeBuyAnyCar’s name. As we seek to expand our operations, maintaining and increasing the awareness and perceived quality of our brands and corporate image will be important to attract and expand our vendor and buyer base. We use Internet search engines, in particular Google, to generate traffic to our websites. The purchase of keywords consists of anticipating words and terms consumers will use to search on Internet search engines and then bidding on those words and terms in the applicable search engine’s auction system. Search engines, including Google, frequently update and change the logic that determines the placement and display of results of a search, such that the purchased or algorithmic placement of links to our websites can be adversely affected. Our positioning on a search engine’s search results depends on algorithms designed by the search engine provider and are based on various criteria including, in particular, the historical level of traffic on our websites. As a result, if search engine providers change their search algorithms in a manner that is competitively disadvantageous to us, our ability to generate traffic to our websites would be harmed. Furthermore, our mobile applications rely on app stores operated by third parties, in particular Apple, which make mobile applications available for download. The structure of these app stores may change and third-party operators may decide to exclude our mobile applications from their offering (e.g., if we do not agree to changes in terms and conditions), which may adversely affect the availability of our mobile applications. These operators may also charge us fees to list our mobile applications for download, which could adversely affect our margins or result in us discontinuing to offer our mobile applications through third-party app stores. We will continue to invest in, and devote resources to, advertising and marketing, as well as other efforts to preserve and enhance customer awareness of our brands. In particular, we expect to spend significant amounts on television, radio and Internet advertising to support WeBuyAnyCar, which is a purely customer brand. There can be no assurance, however, that our advertising campaigns will successfully maintain or enhance customer awareness of our brands. Advertising campaigns may be ineffective and may even have adverse effects on website traffic and brand perception as a result of factors potentially out of our control, such as changes in consumer preferences and regulatory reforms impacting advertising and marketing rules. Even if we are successful in our branding efforts, significant costs are incurred in order to develop, deploy and update our advertising campaigns, and as a result our efforts may not be cost-effective because, among others, assumptions regarding required customer acquisition costs and resulting revenue prove to be incorrect. In addition, we cannot guarantee that our current marketing channels will continue to be effective, permissible and generally available to us in the future. For television marketing, the program during which we broadcast our commercials may not achieve the anticipated number of viewers. For our online marketing, the relevant partners may be unable to deliver the anticipated traffic to our website and mobile applications. In particular, the popularity of social media channels tends to fluctuate, making it difficult to predict which channels are best suited to reach a mass audience. Moreover, any negative publicity may be accelerated through social media (e.g., Facebook, Instagram and Twitter) due to its immediacy and accessibility as a means of communication. Social media and websites immediately publish posts from users, often without filters or checks on the accuracy of the content posted. New and existing customers value readily available information concerning digital offerings and often act on such posts without further investigation or authentication. Allegations against us may be posted on social media, in Internet chat rooms or on blogs or websites by anyone on an anonymous basis. Any negative publicity, even if factually incorrect or based on isolated incidents, or the failure to maintain or enhance customer awareness of our brands and generate demand in a cost-effective manner could damage our reputation, diminish the strength of our brands, undermine the trust and credibility we have established, have a negative impact on our ability to attract new or retain existing customers and require us to spend significant time and money to address such negative publicity.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business
Subsubsection Title: We may not be able to effectively communicate with our customers through email and other messages.
Subsubsection Text: We use newsletters (e.g., emails) as a free marketing tool to promote our digital and physical offering, website and mobile applications. Our emails may, however, be shown as “spam”or given a lower priority, which could reduce the likelihood of addresses opening or responding positively to them. Actions by third parties to block, impose restrictions on, or charge for the delivery of, emails and other messages, as well as legal or regulatory changes limiting our right to send such messages or imposing additional requirements, could impair our ability to communicate with customers. If we are not able to use unpaid marketing tools in the form of emails or other messages efficiently, this could impair our marketing efforts or make them more expensive if we have to increase spending on paid marketing channels. ----- Furthermore, malfunctions of our email and messaging services could result in erroneous messages being sent and customers no longer wanting to receive any messages from us. Furthermore, our process to obtain consent from visitors to our website and users of our mobile applications to receive newsletters and other messages from us and to allow us to use their data may be insufficient or invalid or become so as result of regulatory or legislative changes. As a result, such individuals or third parties may accuse us of sending unsolicited advertisements and other messages, which could result in claims or regulatory action being brought against us.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business
Subsubsection Title: Dissatisfaction with our customer service could prevent us from expanding our business as intended.
Subsubsection Text: To provide customer service, we communicate via email and through our telephone hotlines. The satisfaction of our customers depends in particular on the effectiveness of our customer service, in particular our ability to deal with complaints (e.g., with respect to the quality of used vehicles, technical problems, payment and shipping, defects and invoicing) in a timely and satisfying manner. Any unsatisfactory response or lack of responsiveness (e.g., due to interruptions of our hotlines) could reduce customer satisfaction and loyalty and therefore adversely affect our revenue and profitability.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business
Subsubsection Title: We are exposed to risks associated with currency fluctuations.
Subsubsection Text: We report our results in pound sterling, and pound sterling is also our functional currency. However, we conduct operations in the UK and continental Europe, as a result of which approximately 11% of our revenue in the fiscal year 2021 was denominated in currencies other than pound sterling, with the significant majority of this denominated in euro. Our results of operations may therefore be affected by both the transaction and translation effects of foreign currency exchange rate fluctuations when we incur costs or earn revenue in a currency other than the pound sterling. For example, because we report in pound sterling, our consolidated results would be adversely affected by the depreciation of the euro relative to the pound sterling, as this would result in reduced euro-denominated earnings, an effect which could increase were our European operations to expand, and could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations. In addition, we are subject to additional taxation as a result of any foreign exchange gain arising in respect of the interest on our euro-denominated indebtedness, which could similarly have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business
Subsubsection Title: Environmental, health and safety risks could adversely affect our operating results and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: We operate from multiple locations across the UK and continental Europe. Large numbers of vehicles are stored and prepared for sale at these sites, and during that time releases of fuel, motor oil and other materials may occur. In addition, members of the public and our employees come into close contact with vehicles moving on or around our sites. Furthermore, our employed and contracted drivers collect and deliver large numbers of vehicles across both the UK and continental Europe and our fleet of vehicle transporters carries large numbers of vehicles annually. Consequently, our operations are subject to various environmental and health and safety laws and regulations, including those governing the emission and discharge of pollutants into the air and water, the generation, treatment, storage and release of hazardous materials and wastes and the investigation and remediation of contamination, as well as regulations requiring adequate precautions to prevent injuries arising from collisions and impacts with vehicles moving within our locations and on public roads. For example, governments increasingly introduce low emission zones in certain geographical areas, where the most polluting vehicles are regulated and vehicles with higher emissions, including vehicles in support of the Automotive Services division, cannot enter, thereby limiting our operations. We may incur expenditures relating to accidents causing injury to individuals, releases of hazardous materials, investigative, remedial or corrective actions, claims by third parties and other environmental issues, and such expenditures, individually or in the aggregate, could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations. Our failure to comply with current or future environmental, health or safety laws or to obtain and comply with permits required under such laws, could also subject us to significant liability or require costly investigative, remedial or corrective actions, all of which could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business
Subsubsection Title: Failure to attract and retain skilled technical employees and management personnel could harm our business.
Subsubsection Text: Our success is in part driven by the skills, experience and efforts of our management team and by the efforts, ability and experience of key members of our management staff. The members of our senior management team have extensive experience in the industry in which we operate and have skills that are critical to the ----- operation of our business, including their relationships with, and understanding of the requirements of, the relevant regulatory authorities in the industry in which we operate. We have implemented policies and remuneration designed to retain and properly incentivize management; however, there can be no guarantee that we will be able to attract and retain qualified candidates to replace or succeed members of senior management, should the need arise. The loss of services of any of our management staff could significantly weaken our management expertise and our ability to deliver our services efficiently and effectively, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations. Because we operate in a rapidly changing and increasingly digitalized market, our success also depends to a significant extent upon our ability to identify, attract, retain and motivate highly skilled and qualified technical personnel. Our employees have specialized knowledge that is in high demand, and competition for suitably qualified individuals with the relevant technical expertise in our industry and in the locations in which we operate is intense and may further increase as more vehicle auction companies in the UK and continental Europe shift their operating model towards an online business in response to the COVID 19 pandemic. We have a dedicated team of data scientists and have been able to utilize our data pool to develop highly accurate pricing capabilities based on age, mileage and condition, which permit us to maximize margins in real time. If we are unable to identify, attract, develop, motivate, adequately compensate and retain well-qualified and engaged personnel, or if existing highly skilled and specialized personnel leave us and successors or adequate replacements are not readily available, we may not be able to manage our operations effectively, which could cause us to suffer delays in new service offerings, experience difficulty complying with applicable requirements or otherwise fail to satisfy our customers’ demands, which would have an adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. The difficulties in identifying, attracting and retaining suitable management personnel and employees are exacerbated as a result of Brexit and free movement complications in relation thereto, which make travel between the UK and continental Europe more difficult. In addition, we bear the risk that our key management and key personnel becomes infected with COVID 19, and the measures adopted in response to the COVID 19 pandemic could make the integration of newly hired personnel more challenging. See “—The COVID 19 _pandemic has had, and will continue to have, a significant adverse effect on our business, operations, financial condition, operating results and liquidity, and the ultimate outcome of the COVID 19 pandemic is uncertain.”_

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to a substantial number of non-terminable long-term leases.
Subsubsection Text: We lease the majority of our properties, primarily comprising properties in the UK, pursuant to long-term leases. These leases do not include break clauses. As a result, if we ceased operations at properties which we could not subsequently sublet, we would continue to incur significant lease payments on these properties. In addition, as we continue to shift our operations towards a fully digital business model, we may be required to adapt the use of some or all of our properties. We may also decide to dispose of certain of our properties or may seek to terminate certain of our leases. Similarly, if and when business operations resume and return to pre-pandemic levels (see “—The COVID 19 pandemic has had, and will continue to have, a significant adverse _effect on our business, operations, financial condition, operating results and liquidity, and the ultimate outcome of the COVID 19 pandemic is uncertain”), we may also seek changes to our overall composition of portfolio of_ properties, or the related use thereof. Moreover, the current use of our properties may not necessarily be appropriate or cost efficient for future operations. However, there can be no guarantee that it will be legally permissible to change the use of our properties at such time or that we will be able to dispose of properties on commercially reasonable terms or at all. Similarly, we cannot guarantee that we will be able to renegotiate long-term leases, especially if we were to seek the termination of a lease that does not include a break clause.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business
Subsubsection Title: We use standardized documents, contracts and terms and conditions, which may adversely affect our operations if any agreement or clause were held to be invalid.
Subsubsection Text: We maintain relationships with a large number of vendors and buyers and, in this context, we regularly use standardized terms and conditions, in particular in relation to the terms and conditions of sale and purchase on our remarketing platforms and the terms and conditions applicable to WeBuyAnyCar customers. Standardized terms and conditions have to comply with the statutory laws on general terms and conditions in the different jurisdictions in which we operate, which means that in many jurisdictions they are subject to intense scrutiny by the courts. The standard is even stricter if such terms and conditions are used vis-à-vis private consumers, such as in our WeBuyAnyCar business. If standardized documents, contracts, or terms and conditions we use contain provisions which are interpreted in a manner disadvantageous to us, or if any clauses are held to be invalid and thus replaced by statutory provisions which are disadvantageous to us, a large number of our contractual relationships could be affected. This could provide our counterparties with ----- unexpected legal rights and remedies (e.g., withdrawal rights), cause us to incur unexpected expenses and prevent us from operating our business as currently operated. In some cases, courts may even determine that our standardized terms and conditions are generally invalid, and as a result we may not have entered into a valid contractual relationship with the relevant counterparty.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business
Subsubsection Title: We have several defined contribution pension schemes in certain continental European countries as well as two defined benefit pension plans in the UK, some of which are in deficit.
Subsubsection Text: We participate in several defined contribution pension schemes in the UK and certain continental European countries as well as two defined benefit pension plans in the UK. Our cash funding obligations are set in accordance with applicable pension legislation, assessed on a triennial basis and required to be agreed between us and independent trustees. Our cash funding obligations are further subject to increases in life expectancy. Our total contribution to these defined contribution schemes in the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021 was £6.4 million. We cannot guarantee that our future cash contributions will not undermine our capacity to satisfy our debt obligations, including the Notes. In addition, the two defined benefit pension plans in the UK are in deficit. As of March 28, 2021, the two defined benefit pension plans in the UK had a deficit of £12.4 million (2020: £15.1 million). Plan liabilities, in respect of defined benefit obligations, are calculated on a discounted basis using a discount rate which is set with reference to corporate bond yields. If the plan assets underperform such yield, then this will create a deficit. The trustees of each plan, and their advisors, carry out regular reviews of asset allocations within each plan and consider the need to switch assets in line with the investment strategies. However, the plans hold only a portion of assets as defensive assets (government and corporate bonds) and we cannot guarantee that the level of investment risk is reduced appropriately as the maturity approaches for each plan. Moreover, while we have contractual caps on the level of inflationary increases to be applied to pension obligations in order to protect the plans from extreme inflation, our pension liabilities in deferment are linked and subject to inflation. Accordingly, we cannot guarantee that an increase in inflation will not lead to an increase in our pension deficit. Furthermore, plan assets are likely to decrease following an increase in the interest rate. This is due to an increase in interest rates having the effect of a decrease in value of the defensive assets held by the plans. While such risk is partially mitigated by the measurement of plan liabilities being linked to bond yields, any decrease in interest rates has the effect of decreasing bond yields, which in turn increases plan liabilities. Accordingly, the materialization of any of these risks, if significant, could adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business
Subsubsection Title: Significant differences exist between certain accounting principles, such as IFRS 16 and IAS 17, which may be material to investors’ assessments of our financial condition, and certain financial information in this Offering Memorandum is derived from unaudited management accounts, which are not comparable to audited financial information.
Subsubsection Text: IFRS 16 (Leases) became effective on January 1, 2019 and applies to the first full fiscal year commencing on or after that date. Accordingly, we have applied IFRS 16 since the fiscal year 2020. We have adopted IFRS 16 under the modified retrospective approach on April 1, 2019, with the cumulative effect of applying IFRS 16 on adoption recognized as an adjustment to opening equity. Under this approach, comparative information for the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019 is not restated and, as a result, no IFRS 16 adjustments have been made to the Fiscal Year 2019 Consolidated Financial Statements. Accordingly, the financial information included in this Offering Memorandum, including the Consolidated Financial Statements, the 2020 Predecessor Financial Statements and the Fiscal Year 2020 Aggregated Financial Information, may not be comparable insofar as they relate to the application of IFRS 16 (Leases). See “Presentation of Financial and _Other Information—IFRS Financial Information—Application of IFRS 16.”_

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business
Subsubsection Title: We have included in this Offering Memorandum certain unaudited adjusted data, which gives effect to the Refinancing Transactions, as if it had occurred on March 30, 2020, and other financial information not prepared in accordance with IFRS.
Subsubsection Text: We have included in this Offering Memorandum certain unaudited adjusted data, which gives effect to the Refinancing Transactions, as if it had occurred on March 30, 2020. In addition, we have included certain non-IFRS measures, including Reported Adjusted EBITDA, IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA, IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA, IAS 17 Pro Forma Adjusted Run Rate EBITDA, Underlying Cash CAPEX, Adjusted Operating Cash Flow, Adjusted Cash Conversion, COVID Adjusted Operating Cash Flow and COVID Adjusted Cash Conversion. The non-IFRS measures and other information (including unaudited adjusted data) included in this Offering Memorandum have been prepared for information purposes only and have not ----- been prepared in accordance with IFRS, U.S. GAAP or any other internationally accepted accounting principles or audited or reviewed in accordance with any applicable auditing standards. These non-IFRS measures and other information are not identified as accounting measures under IFRS and therefore should not be considered as alternative measures to evaluate our performance. The non-IFRS measures and other information (including unaudited adjusted data) are based on available information and certain assumptions and estimates that we believe are reasonable in the circumstances. However, these assumptions and estimates are inherently uncertain, subject to a wide variety of significant business, economic and other risks and may differ materially from our actual financial condition or results of operations. The non-IFRS measures and other information (including unaudited adjusted data) included in this Offering Memorandum are not intended to comply with the reporting requirements of the SEC and will not be subject to review by the SEC and certain measures would be prohibited from inclusion in documents furnished or filed with the SEC. Certain of these amounts have not been, and, in certain cases cannot be, audited, reviewed or verified by any independent accounting firm. We have also included certain unaudited financial information prepared in accordance with IAS 17 (Leases), which is an accounting standard that was superseded by IFRS 16. Such unaudited financial information has important limitations; in particular, it is prepared in accordance with a historic accounting standard, IAS 17 (Leases), and has not been audited. As such, it is not comparable to the audited results due to adjustments and should not be regarded as a substitute for the Consolidated Financial Statements or financial data prepared in accordance with IFRS. Moreover, some of the financial information included in this Offering Memorandum is adjusted for the estimated impact of COVID 19 and/or for certain run rate adjustments based on our most recent three months of trading. In particular, IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA and ratios derived therefrom seek to adjust IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA for the impact of COVID 19. The adjustments made to calculate IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA are based upon available information and assumptions that we believe are reasonable in the circumstances but are included for illustrative purposes only and have not been audited. IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA is not comparable to the audited results and should not be regarded as a substitute for the Consolidated Financial Statements, which are prepared in accordance with IFRS. The adjustments relating to COVID 19 are calculated by replacing the results of operations for COVID-impacted periods with prior non-COVID impacted periods, thereby presenting the results of operations during a more normalized period of trading. For the 53-week period ended May 30, 2021, the adjustments relating to COVID 19 are calculated by replacing the results of operations for January 2021 (£4.5 million) and February 2021 (£13.2 million) with the results of operations for January 2020 (£15.9 million) and February 2020 (£21.1 million), respectively, thereby presenting the results of operations during a more normalized period of trading. For the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, the adjustments relating to COVID 19 are calculated by replacing the results of operations for the first quarter of the fiscal year 2021 (£2.0 million) and the fourth quarter of the fiscal year 2021 (£43.9 million) with the results of operations for the first quarter of the fiscal year 2020 (£44.5 million) and the fourth quarter of the fiscal year 2020 (£66.2 million), respectively, thereby presenting the results of operations during a more normalized period of trading. For the unaudited aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020, the adjustments relating to COVID 19 are calculated by adding back an amount of £11.3 million (based on management forecasts using operating results for March 2020 immediately prior to lockdowns, reflecting restrictions on operating activities due to COVID 19) and an amount of £2.7 million (representing provisions relating to bad debt and inventory). Such information and adjustments are for illustrative purposes only and are not intended to project our consolidated results of operations for any future period. Such information has not been audited, reviewed or verified and you should not place undue reliance thereon. Moreover, IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA is included for, among other periods, the 53-week period ended May 30, 2021. IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA for the 53-week period ended May 30, 2021 is calculated on the basis of IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA for the 53-week period ended May 30, 2021 and adding adjustments relating to COVID 19 which are calculated by replacing the results of operations for January 2021 (£4.5 million) and February 2021 (£13.2 million) with the results of operations for January 2020 (£15.9 million) and February 2020 (£21.1 million), respectively. Financial information for the 53-week period ended May 30, 2021 is based on management accounts and is included for illustrative purposes only, has not been reviewed or audited and may not be reflective of the actual results for such periods and should not be regarded as a substitute for the audited consolidated financial data of the Parent or financial data prepared in accordance with IFRS. We have also included 52-week IAS 17 Pro Forma Adjusted Run Rate EBITDA as of May 30, 2021. IAS 17 Pro Forma Adjusted Run Rate EBITDA is calculated on the basis of IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA for ----- the aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020 and applying additional adjustments to give effect increases in profitability and volume in our UK Vehicle Remarketing division, the our International Vehicle Remarketing division and our Vehicle Buying division, as well as the decrease in IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA for our Automotive Services division, in the period from February 22, 2021 to May 30, 2021. IAS 17 Pro Forma Adjusted Run Rate EBITDA is included for illustrative purposes only and, as a run rate calculation giving full year effect to the most recent three month period, is likely to differ from actual results for the period. In particular, this run rate calculation does not give effect to seasonal variances or any impact of changes in longer term demand dynamics. See “Summary Financial Information—Non-IFRS Measures,” “Operating and Financial Review—COVID 19” and “Operating and Financial Review—Seasonality.” In addition, we have included certain unaudited aggregated financial information for the 52-week period ended March 29, 2020. The unaudited aggregated financial information is derived by adding together the unaudited consolidated income statement information of BCA Marketplace for the 219-day period from and including April 1, 2019 to and including November 5, 2019 and the consolidated income statement information of the Parent for the 42-week period from and including June 10, 2019 to and including March 29, 2020 (which includes the 145-day post-CA Acquisition trading result from November 6, 2019 up to and including March 29, 2020). The financial information used in presenting such information includes information for the Parent from June 10, 2019 (the date of incorporation of the Parent), which overlaps with information of BCA Marketplace from April 1, 2019. However, the Parent was formed on June 10, 2019 for the purposes of facilitating the CA Acquisition, which was consummated on November 6, 2019 and the Parent did not trade prior to November 6, 2019. Moreover, while both the Fiscal Year 2020 Consolidated Financial Statements and the 2020 Predecessor Financial Statements have been prepared in accordance with IFRS, they relate to different entities that have not prepared their financial information on a consistent basis. Such unaudited aggregated financial information is included for illustrative purposes only and does not purport to represent what our income statement would have been if the CA Acquisition had occurred on April 1, 2019 and is not intended to project our consolidated results of operations for any future period. The foregoing financial data has not been prepared in accordance with the requirements of Regulation S-X of the U.S. Securities Act or any generally accepted accounting standards. None of the adjustments, estimates or run rate calculations have been audited by any independent auditors and should not be considered indicative of actual results that would have been achieved had the events for which we have made the adjustment, estimate or calculation been completed as the dates stated and do not purport to indicate our future consolidated results of operations or financial position. The actual results may differ significantly from those presented for a number of reasons, including, but not limited to, differences in assumptions used.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Financial Profile, Our Structure, the Notes and the Guarantees
Subsubsection Title: Our substantial leverage and debt service obligations could adversely affect our business and prevent us from fulfilling our obligations with respect to the Notes and the Guarantees.
Subsubsection Text: We are, and following the issuance of the Notes, will continue to be, highly leveraged. As of March 28, 2021, after giving effect to the Refinancing Transactions, our primary financing arrangements will be the Notes, the Senior Term Loan Facility, the Revolving Credit Facility and the Second Lien Facility, and we would have had £1,760 million of Adjusted Total Debt (which excludes finance leases and borrowing under the Receivables Facility). See “Capitalization”and “Description of Other Financial Arrangements.”In addition, as of March 28, 2021, we had borrowings in an amount of £148.3 million under the Receivables Facility. The degree to which we will remain leveraged following the issuance of the Notes could have important consequences to holders of the Notes offered hereby, including, but not limited to: - making it difficult for us to satisfy our obligations with respect to the Notes; - increasing our vulnerability to, and reducing our flexibility to respond to, general adverse economic and industry conditions, including an economic downturn due to the impact of the COVID 19 pandemic; - requiring the dedication of a substantial portion of our cash flow from operations to the payment of interest and amortization costs on indebtedness, thereby reducing the availability of such cash flow to fund the payment of principal of indebtedness, working capital, capital expenditures, acquisitions, joint ventures or other general corporate purposes; - limiting our flexibility in planning for or reacting to changes in our business and the competitive environment and the industry in which we operate; ----- - placing us at a competitive disadvantage as compared to our competitors, to the extent that they are not as highly leveraged; and - limiting our ability to borrow additional funds and increasing the cost of any such borrowing. Any of these or other consequences or events could have a material adverse effect on our ability to satisfy our debt obligations, including the Notes.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Financial Profile, Our Structure, the Notes and the Guarantees
Subsubsection Title: Despite our high level of indebtedness, we may be able to incur significant additional amounts of debt, which could further exacerbate the risks associated with our substantial indebtedness.
Subsubsection Text: We may be able to incur substantial additional indebtedness in the future. Although the Indenture, the Senior Facilities Agreement and the Second Lien Facility Agreement contain restrictions on the incurrence of additional indebtedness, these restrictions are subject to a number of significant qualifications and exceptions, and under certain circumstances, the amount of indebtedness that could be incurred in compliance with those restrictions could be substantial. Additionally, the Indenture, the Senior Facilities Agreement and the Second Lien Facility Agreement do not prevent us from incurring obligations that would not constitute indebtedness under these agreements.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Financial Profile, Our Structure, the Notes and the Guarantees
Subsubsection Title: The debt under the Senior Facilities Agreement and the Second Lien Facility Agreement will bear interest at a floating rate that could rise significantly, increasing our interest cost and debt and reducing our cash flow.
Subsubsection Text: Borrowings under the Senior Facilities Agreement will bear interest at floating rates of interest per annum equal to the Sterling Over Night Index Average risk-free rate (“SONIA”) (in respect of pound sterling), the Euro Interbank Offered Rate (“EURIBOR”) (in respect of euro) and the London Interbank Offered Rate (“LIBOR”) (in respect of any other applicable currency), subject in each case to a zero floor, plus an agreed margin. Borrowings under the Second Lien Facility Agreement will bear interest at floating rates of interest per annum equal to SONIA, subject to a zero floor, plus an agreed margin. SONIA, EURIBOR and LIBOR could rise significantly in the future. Although we may enter into and maintain certain hedging arrangements designed to fix a portion of these benchmark interest rates in the future, there can be no assurances that hedging will continue to be available on commercially reasonable terms. Hedging itself carries certain risks, including that we may need to pay a significant amount (including costs) to terminate any hedging arrangements. To the extent interest rates were to rise significantly, our interest expense associated with the debt under the Senior Facilities Agreement and the Second Lien Facility Agreement, to the extent not fixed by means of hedging arrangements, would correspondingly increase, thus reducing cash flow. As a consequence of regulatory reforms, the common maturities of U.S. dollar LIBOR will cease to be published as panel bank rates after June 30, 2023 (and all other LIBOR settings for all currencies will cease as panel bank rates after December 31, 2021). It is not known if or when regulatory reform may, in the future, cause EURIBOR to cease or be replaced. The U.S. dollar floating rate market is currently expected to transition to use, in place of U.S. dollar LIBOR, a floating rate equal to compounding overnight Secured Overnight Financing Rate published by the Federal Reserve in the United States plus a spread adjustment, by not later than the time that the relevant U.S. dollar LIBOR setting is to cease as a panel bank rate, although other alternative rates may also be used. These reforms may cause such benchmarks to perform differently than in the past or have other consequences which cannot be predicted. Any such consequence could have a material adverse effect on our debt linked to such a benchmark. Regulatory requirements under the EU Benchmark Regulation (particularly in relation to EURIBOR) and under the UK Benchmark Regulation (particularly in relation to LIBOR) may: (i) discourage market participants from continuing to administer or contribute to a regulated benchmark (such as EURIBOR or LIBOR); (ii) trigger changes in the rules or methodologies used for the benchmark; or (iii) lead to the disappearance of the benchmark. The scheduled cessation of the LIBOR benchmark as a panel bank rate or any proposal to cease the determination or publication of any other benchmark, changes in the manner of administration of any benchmark, or actions by regulators or law enforcement agencies could result in changes to the manner in which the relevant benchmark is determined, which could require an adjustment to the terms and conditions, or result in other consequences, in respect of any debt linked to such benchmark. Any of the above changes or any other consequential changes as a result of international, national or other proposals for reform or other initiatives may result in a sudden or prolonged increase in any affected benchmark, which could have a material adverse effect on the value of and return on any floating rate debt linked to such benchmark and on our ability to service debt that bears interest at floating rates of interest. -----

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Financial Profile, Our Structure, the Notes and the Guarantees
Subsubsection Title: The Issuer is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Parent that does not have any revenue generating operations of its own and depends on cash from operating companies to be able to make payments on the Notes.
Subsubsection Text: The Issuer is a finance subsidiary that was incorporated to facilitate the offering of the Notes and has no business operations or material assets other than its rights under the Proceeds Loan Agreement. The Issuer will be dependent upon payments under the Proceeds Loan Agreement and cash flow from our operating companies to meet its obligations under the Notes. We intend to provide funds to the Issuer in order for the Issuer to meet its obligations under the Notes principally through payments made pursuant to the Proceeds Loan Agreement, the provisions of intercompany loans, dividends and other distributions. If entities within our group do not fulfill their obligations under any such intercompany loans and do not otherwise distribute cash in order for the Issuer to make scheduled payments on the Notes, the Issuer will not have any other source of funds that would allow it to make payments to the holders of the Notes. The amount of cash available to the Issuer will depend on the profitability and cash flows of our operating companies and the ability of those companies to transfer funds under applicable law. Our operating companies, however, may not be able to, or may not be permitted under applicable law to, make distributions or advance loans, directly or indirectly, to the Issuer in order for the Issuer to make payments in respect of the Notes. In addition, the entities of our group that do not guarantee the Notes have no obligation to make payments with respect to the Notes. Applicable law may also limit the amounts that some of our subsidiaries will be permitted to pay as dividends or distributions on their equity interests, or even prevent such payments. The inability to transfer cash among entities within their respective consolidated groups may mean that even though the entities, in aggregate, may have sufficient resources to meet the obligations under the Notes, they may not be permitted to make the necessary dividends or distributions from one entity in their restricted group to another entity in their restricted group in order to make payments to the entity owing the obligations.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Financial Profile, Our Structure, the Notes and the Guarantees
Subsubsection Title: The Notes will be structurally subordinated to the liabilities of non-Guarantor subsidiaries.
Subsubsection Text: Some, but not all, subsidiaries of the Parent will guarantee the Notes. For the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, the Issuer and the Guarantors represented 68% of IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA. Unless a company is a Guarantor, such company will not have any obligation to pay amounts due under the Notes or to make funds available for that purpose. Generally, holders of indebtedness of, and trade creditors of, non-guarantor subsidiaries, including lenders under our finance facilities and bank financing agreements, are entitled to payments of their claims from the assets of such subsidiaries before these assets are made available for distribution to any Guarantor, as a direct or indirect shareholder. Accordingly, in the event that any non-Guarantor subsidiary becomes insolvent, is liquidated, reorganized or dissolved or is otherwise wound up other than as part of a solvent transaction: - the creditors of the Issuer (including the holders of the Notes) and the Guarantors will have no right to proceed against the assets of such subsidiary; and - creditors of such non-Guarantor subsidiary, including trade creditors, will generally be entitled to payment in full from the sale or other disposal of the assets of such subsidiary before any Guarantor, as a direct or indirect shareholder, will be entitled to receive any distributions from such subsidiary. As such, the Notes and each Guarantee will be structurally subordinated to the creditors (including trade creditors) and any preferred stockholders of non-Guarantor subsidiaries.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Financial Profile, Our Structure, the Notes and the Guarantees
