Subsubsection Text: The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and any possible future outbreaks could have an adverse effect on us. In response to the outbreak, we have initiated a centralized crisis alert team to carry out a global pandemic contingency and preparedness response plan to ensure the safety of our employees worldwide. Our 45 plants and converting sites in 14 countries have remained operational during 2020, except for a few temporary shutdowns caused by government lockdowns or employee absences due to quarantine or infections. Raw material supply issues have not caused any significant interruptions of production. Our investment project in a second-hand Voith production line that will produce biodegradable and compostable tea and coffee infusion materials at our Chirnside plant in the UK, however, has partially been delayed and has incurred additional costs in an amount of €9 million. The deviation in the capital expenditure spending and timeline is a result of the complexity of the project, reduction in capital expenditure plans in 2019 which placed the project on hold, as well as the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic. The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and any possible future outbreaks of the virus among our employees, or if employees are unable to work as a result of being quarantined, may have an adverse effect on our operations and could lead to significant interruptions of production. In addition, the current pandemic or any possible future outbreaks of the virus could have an adverse effect on our suppliers, distributors, logistics and other supply chain operations, resulting in a deficit of supplies necessary to carry out our operations, and therefore possibly disrupting output deliveries to customers. Although we have taken measures to decrease operational risks arisen due to the COVID-19 pandemic, there can be no assurance that the chosen measures will be effective, especially if the COVID-19 pandemic persists for a long period. Furthermore, the COVID-19 pandemic or any possible future outbreaks or COVID-19, including any new variants thereof, or of other viruses could negatively affect the demand of our products. For example, the exceptional circumstances of the COVID-19 pandemic, with regional lockdowns and limited mobility for citizens, have resulted in lower restaurant traffic, which has slowed demand for food processing and packaging products. Similarly, demand for home building and furniture, transportation and industrial end-uses has decreased. In 2020, we implemented actions, such as temporary layoffs, shorter working hours and minimizing 40 ----- the use of external personnel and services, to mitigate the financial impact of lower volumes, in particular during the second and third quarters of 2020. Any failure to successfully adapt our business operations or strategy to the changing operating conditions caused by the COVID-19 pandemic or any future outbreaks or materialization of any other risks mentioned above, may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Operations
Subsubsection Title: We may not be able to achieve the estimated benefits from the renewal of our business platform.
Subsubsection Text: On February 13, 2020, we announced a renewal of our business processes and modern systems to create a strong foundation to operate our global business effectively and strengthen customer experience. The new, stronger platform is intended to benefit our way of doing business by utilizing the data and the opportunities for further digitalization. The business platform is expected to enable growth strategy implementation and generate efficiency, agility, transparency, improve stakeholder value and contribute to profitable growth. The business platform renewal started in 2020 with a planning phase and will be implemented over several years. Achieving the estimated benefits of the renewal will involve certain risks and uncertainties, and there can be no assurance that we will achieve the estimated benefits of the renewal within the currently estimated timeframe, or at all. In addition, increased digitalization of our business may increase certain of the risks described in this “Risk _Factors” section, including the risks described under “—Any significant problems with our IT systems could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.”_ Risks and challenges relating to the renewal of the business platform include, but are not limited to, the following: - introduction and implementation of a new operating model and business processes; - implementation of new IT technologies; - placement of demands on our resources to manage the process internally, which may affect the management’s ability to run our business effectively during the renewal process; and - co-operation with our employees and customers. The expected benefits from the renewal of the business platform as well as the related costs are inherently uncertain and based on a number of our assumptions and judgments. In addition, the renewal might not be completed in the expected timeframe. The materialization of any of the above described risks could result in us not being able to achieve the estimated benefits from the renewal and cause additional costs to us, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Operations
Subsubsection Title: Our production operations involve operational risks, and failures or deficiencies in the management of operational efficiency could have a material adverse effect on us.
Subsubsection Text: Our ability to utilize our production capacity efficiently could be materially affected by variations in customer demand or interruptions in production. Any inability to adjust production capacity may lead to opportunity loss, in the case of increasing demand, or to cost burdens, in the case of decreasing demand. Rapid production changes may be challenging to implement, which could also increase our vulnerability to adverse general economic and industry conditions. We typically only produce goods against orders received, rather than for stock. However, a variety of conditions may cause customers to reduce, delay or cancel anticipated or confirmed orders and lower capacity utilization to align the production with the demand. Any inability to maintain operational efficiency could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. In addition, any interruption or disruption in production at our production sites, whether due to lack of orders, labor action, environment-related accidents, breakdown of major paper, pulping or other production machines, interruptions in the distribution of energy, system failures or service interruptions in IT systems, fire, accidents, natural hazards, catastrophes, natural disasters, adverse weather conditions, unexpected geological or other physical conditions, criminal or terrorist acts, pandemics, transportation disruptions, problems in our supply agreements or other factors, could have a material adverse effect on our ability to meet our production goals and result in lost opportunities in the future. Any of the above may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Operations
Subsubsection Title: Loss of significant customer relationships and customer concentration could harm our business.
Subsubsection Text: Changes in customer industries related to customer strategies or end-user needs could have a material adverse effect on our business. We are not dependent on any specific customer or group of customers. Our ten 41 ----- largest customers generated 19.0% of our net sales in the year ended December 31, 2020 and no single customer represented more than 10% of our net sales in same period. However, we have customers that are significant to the operations of an individual business area. Additionally, a number of our customers are, or could in the future be, under pressure in their own domestic markets from imports, in particular from Asia, and may consequently lose market share or have to relocate their production or converting facilities to other markets, which could cause our customers to reduce the volume of their purchases. The loss of a significant number of our key customers, if not replaced with new customer agreements on similar terms, or a significant reduction in sales to any such customers could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. We are also exposed to a risk of customer concentration. The industries in which our customers operate may be subject to future consolidation. Any such consolidation could result in companies having increased bargaining power and could lead to a decline in our market share if an existing customer merges with or is acquired by an entity that has a strong relationship with one of our competitors.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Operations
Subsubsection Title: We rely on certifications by industry standard-setting bodies.
Subsubsection Text: We obtain and seek to adhere to certain certifications, because we seek to conduct our activities with respect to the environment. We incur significant costs and expenses in order to comply with and maintain our certifications, including assessments necessary for the renewal of the certifications and monitoring and implementation of the certifications. If we fail to maintain any of our certifications, our business may be harmed because our customers may cease buying certain products from us, which in turn could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Operations
Subsubsection Title: Any significant problems with our IT systems could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: Our operations depend on the integrity, security and stable operation of our IT systems and software, which are primarily provided by third-party suppliers. The operation of our IT systems and software could be interrupted by power cuts, software or telecommunication errors or disasters such as fires or natural disasters, as well as human errors made by our own staff or third-party suppliers. If our IT systems and software were to become unusable or their function were to be significantly impaired for any reason during an extended period of time due to, for example, systems and software becoming outdated or due to a lack of sufficient resources for IT support from third-party suppliers, our operations could be adversely affected, since our production processes and our ability to deliver products on time, order raw materials and handle inventory are largely dependent on our IT systems and software. Difficulties in renewing, maintaining, upgrading and outsourcing our IT systems and software could result in increased costs and damage to our reputation in the eyes of our customers and other third parties, which, in turn, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Despite our security measures and back-up systems, our information technology and infrastructure may be vulnerable to attacks by hackers, computer viruses or malicious code. Various cyber threats have increased in recent years along with the digitalization of companies’ operations. We may be targeted, for example, by phishing or malware attacks, denial-of-service attacks, breaches in information or data systems, ransomware or attacks targeting production processes. It may also be difficult for us to detect cyber-attacks upon their occurrence, which could have an impact on the size of damage. In addition, our information technology and infrastructure may be breached due to employee error, malfeasance or affected by other disruptions, including as a result of natural disasters or telecommunications breakdowns or other reasons beyond our control. In addition, any problems with IT systems and software could result in leakage of sensitive information and theft of intellectual property. Any of the above could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Operations
Subsubsection Title: Failure to establish, manage and protect intellectual property rights could have a material adverse effect on our competitiveness and our business, financial condition and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: Our success depends on being on the leading edge in terms of product development and improvement of our manufacturing and production processes. This, in turn, depends on our ability to protect our intellectual property rights. We have taken active measures to obtain protection of our intellectual property by obtaining patents, trademarks and by monitoring activities in our major markets. In addition to our patent portfolio and trademarks, we rely on trade secrets, know-how, the development of new products and technological development in combination with non-disclosure and other agreements to protect our intellectual property rights. However, the measures that we take to protect our intellectual property may not effectively deter competitors from improper 42 ----- use of our intellectual property. Protection of intellectual property rights may be more challenging in some of the regions in which we operate. For example, in the past there have been attempts in China to misuse the name and logo of Ahlstrom Corporation, one of our predecessor companies. Competitors, suppliers and customers may misappropriate intellectual property owned or licensed by us, disputes as to ownership of intellectual property may arise and intellectual property may otherwise become known by or independently developed by competitors, suppliers or customers. In addition, certain technologies and processes used by us may be subject to the intellectual property rights of third parties. Such third parties may take legal action for infringement of these intellectual property rights and any such claim could delay or prevent the delivery of our products. We may not be successful in defending against this or other challenges brought against our intellectual property rights, may be required to pay royalties for the use of patents or trademarks of third parties for key technologies or may need to make substantial investments to research and develop suitable alternatives. We, at times, rely on trade secrets instead of other forms of protection for our patents or trademarks when patent or trademark protection is not possible, such as, for example, when the particular technology which was used could not be exactly identified or would not qualify for patent or trademark protection, or in our opinion would be less effective than maintaining secrecy. In addition, we rely upon confidentiality agreements with our employees, contractors and other third parties. To the extent that we rely on trade secret protection and confidentiality agreements, there can be no assurance that our efforts to maintain secrecy will be successful or that third parties will not be able to develop the product, technology or know-how independently. Any loss of secrecy could have a material adverse effect on our financial condition and results of operations. Any failure by us to establish, manage and protect our intellectual property or resulting claims of infringement on third-party intellectual property rights could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and our competitiveness. See also “—We may from time to time be involved in litigation and other similar proceedings that could have a _material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.”_

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Operations
Subsubsection Title: Compliance with environmental, health and safety, anti-corruption and other national and international laws and regulations could increase our operating costs, and potential violations of laws and regulations could have a material adverse effect on us.
Subsubsection Text: We and our operations are subject to various regional, national and local laws and regulations, including environmental regulations, health and safety laws and regulations, labor regulations, competition regulations, regulations restricting competitive trading conditions, anti-corruption laws, anti-dumping, data-protection, corporate, tax and accounting laws. These requirements are complex and frequently change, and they have tended to become more stringent over time. The passing of new or amended laws or regulations, could require us to adopt more stringent standards, could restrict our operational or strategic flexibility or require significant costs and investments. In addition, our operations are subject to different environmental permits, with which we must comply. We will incur capital and operating costs in our efforts to comply with these laws and regulations. For example, wastewater discharges and air emissions are highly regulated, and large investments are required to ensure compliance with applicable requirements. There can be no assurance that the requirements of such laws and regulations and the associated cost of compliance will not increase in the future. Adapting operations to such changes may require us to incur costs that are difficult to anticipate, which, in turn, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Our operations in the EU are also affected by the cost of compliance with the EU Emissions Trading System (“ETS”) in accordance with directive 2003/87/EC, as amended, establishing a scheme for greenhouse gas emission allowance trading. If our carbon dioxide emission levels exceed the rights in our possession, we must purchase sufficient carbon dioxide emission allowances. From 2013 onwards, manufacturing companies have generally had to purchase a steadily increasing amount of emission rights in auctions, for which the costs for emission allowances are difficult to foresee. The cap on total annual emissions in the EU will gradually be reduced in phase four of the ETS starting from 2021, and auctions will become the main method for issuing allowances. Further, regulations on chemicals, such as EU Regulation (No 1907/2006) concerning chemicals and their safe use, aim to improve the protection of human health and the environment through a system of registration, evaluation, authorization and restriction of chemicals, and may also impose obligations and related costs on us. For example, we use titanium dioxide as a raw material for manufacturing certain types of specialty papers. The European Commission has approved the classification of titanium dioxide as a category 2 carcinogen under the CLP regulation (1272/2008/EC) and the harmonized classifications will apply from September 9, 2021. The change in the classification could impose additional obligations and costs on us and the use of titanium dioxide in our products could generate reputational harm for us. Any of the above events could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. 43 ----- Other environmental and health and safety expenditures relate to maintenance, inspection and security requirements, contingency arrangements for emergency preparedness and insurance coverage. Industrial operations, including our production processes are inherently fraught with risks of substantial environmental costs and liabilities. We may be unable to predict future changes to laws, regulations and operating permits, which may require us to incur increased operating costs and additional liabilities on us. We are also required to comply with the provisions of anti-corruption legislation in jurisdictions in which we operate. There can be no assurance that our current and past policies and monitoring systems have been or will be able to detect or prevent all potential instances of illicit conduct, or that such policies have been or will be fully and consistently applied throughout our organization. While we seek to exercise best practices in compliance with applicable laws, there can be no assurance that our past and current policies and monitoring systems were or are able to detect or prevent all potential instances of illicit conduct. We have adopted data protection practices with the aim of being compliant with the General Data Protection Regulation 2016/679 (the “GDPR”) and other applicable data protection laws and regulations applicable to our business and operations. Compliance with the GDPR and other laws and regulations or potential inadequacy of our data protection practices may cause problems, difficulties or additional costs for us. Any infringement of the GDPR or any other applicable laws and regulations could adversely affect our reputation among our customers and other stakeholders. Furthermore, data protection authorities may be vested with the power to impose corrective actions, including temporary or definitive bans on data processing, and to impose fines for breaches of the GDPR or other applicable laws and regulations. If we or our employees, distributors or suppliers, violate any of the applicable laws and regulations, we could experience increased costs or delays in the delivery of our products, be subject to fines, damages or penalties as well as orders and sanctions imposed by supervisory authorities and courts. We may also suffer reputational harm, which could reduce demand for our products and have a material adverse effect on our business.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Operations
Subsubsection Title: Our operations are exposed to risks related to human health, environment and natural resources, which may cause it to incur additional costs and liabilities.
Subsubsection Text: The nature of our manufacturing processes and products exposes us to potential liability risks under applicable laws and regulations relating to human health, the environment and natural resources. Health and safety-related incidents have occurred in the past at our production sites and could occur in the future. Such incidents could result in injury to our employees, harm to employees and disruptions in production processes, which may result in costs and other liabilities and have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations, and could damage our reputation and ability to recruit qualified employees. Our operations result in emissions of substances in the air and water, and generate noise. Production processes and products, which by their nature require the use of chemicals and materials that are potentially harmful to the environment and result in the generation of waste products that require special treatment. Many of our manufacturing facilities are situated in locations with a long history of environmentally harmful industrial use, including the use, storage and disposal of hazardous materials. We are currently, and could in the future be, required to investigate, remediate, monitor or otherwise pay for remediation or other clean-up measures at locations where operations are currently pursued or where they have been pursued in the past, and such payments may be material. Such liability for costs might also arise with respect to real estate property that we own, have previously owned or where predecessor companies previously had operations, or in connection with a closure of a production facility. Even where liability is the result of predecessor actions, these costs may not be adequately covered by predecessors or we may be liable for such costs in the future even after a production facility is closed or sold. For the year ended December 31, 2020, we made environmental provisions of €15.8 million. There can be no guarantee that our environmental provisions will be sufficient to cover any environmental liabilities that we may incur. Our product development and manufacturing processes involve the use of chemicals, such as organic solvents and other mineral additives, and other hazardous materials. Our operations also result in emissions of substances in the air and generate noise. These programs and processes expose us to risks of accidental contamination, such as accidental discharge of untreated water used in the production process, events of non-compliance with environmental, health and safety laws and regulatory enforcement, personal injury, property damage and claims and litigation resulting from such events. Any environmental accident or finding, employee injury, occupational disease or other health and safety issue could impose significant liabilities and remedial costs on us as well as result in reputational damage. In 44 ----- addition, individuals (employees as well as third parties) could seek damages for alleged personal injury or property damage due to accidents or exposure to chemicals, materials or substances that are currently used or were used in the past by us or that are present at facilities operated by us. The Rottersac and Arches production sites in France have been designated as sites where employees have been in contact with asbestos from 1956 to 1997 and from 1960 to 1992, respectively. As a result of potential exposure to asbestos, employees employed at the Rottersac and Arches production sites during these periods are entitled to or have already opted for early retirement. In addition, we are aware of a number of cases where individual employees and/or their beneficiaries have presented asbestos indemnification claims for their illness, alleged loss of salary, anxiety suffering (préjudice d’anxiété) and difficult living conditions (trouble dans les conditions d’existence). While we sold our fine arts paper business which was housed by the Arches production site, to Italy-based F.I.L.A. Group in the first quarter of 2020, we continue to remain liable for these claims under the terms of the sale. Although we do not believe that these claims will have a material effect on our financial condition, there can be no assurance that further claims will not be made against us. While we have an outstanding provision of €1.5 million as of December 31, 2020 to cover outstanding asbestos-related claims by employees, there can be no guarantee that such claims will not increase or that new claims will not be brought in the future. We may face other asbestosrelated liabilities as asbestos has been identified in materials and structures in certain current and former productions sites. If materials and structures containing asbestos become damaged or are renovated or demolished, additional costs may be incurred. If any of the above-mentioned risks were to materialize, they could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. In addition, any potential non-compliance with environmental, health and safety regulations could lead to administrative sanctions, such as warnings, fines and suspension of activities, temporary or permanent withdrawal of permits and licenses granted from government entities and/or public authorities and, potentially, criminal sanctions.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Operations
Subsubsection Title: Product safety or quality failures could interrupt our manufacturing operations and we may be required to pay damages or other remedies as a result of product liability claims.
Subsubsection Text: The quality and safety of our products is critical to the success of our business. The quality targets of our customers in many product segments are very high and tend to have risen further in recent years, which highlights the importance of consistency and repeatability in production processes to ensure customer satisfaction. Furthermore, certain of our products are used in the food and medical industries, where key customers have stringent requirements regarding the products they purchase and conduct regular audits to ensure compliance with applicable regulations, including consumer protection, health, safety and hygiene standards. The consequences of quality or safety issues due to, for example, accidental or malicious raw material contamination or due to supply chain contamination caused by human error, sabotage or equipment fault could be severe. Detected faults or defects in products or in product descriptions discovered at a critical point in our production chain could interrupt production in the unit concerned and disturb the entire chain’s operations. Such disturbances could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Our products are generally integrated into and become a part of more valuable end products. If a product supplied by us is found to be defective and causes the end product to fail, our potential liability may be higher than the cost of the faulty product sold by us. In the event that effective contractual limitations of liability have not been included in some of the supply agreements into which we have entered or will enter with our customers, or if such limitations are not enforceable, we may be required to pay substantial damages if faulty products have been or are delivered by us under such supply agreements. Such occurrences may also take substantial time to resolve, including assessing potential liabilities and involving insurance companies. Any of the above could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Operations
Subsubsection Title: Our insurance coverage may not be sufficient, potentially leaving us uninsured against certain risks.
Subsubsection Text: Globally, we have 45 production facilities located in several European countries, the United States, Brazil and Asia, and damages to these facilities or interruptions in the production at these facilities may disrupt our operations and lead to production loss, which can result in delivery problems and additional costs. There can be no assurance that damages to the production facilities or losses resulting from production interruptions are fully covered by insurance. The COVID-19 outbreak has adversely changed and may continue to change the characteristics of the global insurance market, making it less favorable to insurers amidst the outbreak. We seek to use leading insurance brokers and insurance companies for our business. However, our insurance coverage may not be sufficient to cover all of our potential liabilities. Accordingly, a major claim, or a series of smaller claims, for damages related to our products sold, or advice given to customers in connection with products sold, 45 ----- may not be fully covered by insurance, or may not be covered by insurance at all, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. We maintain insurance coverage for, among other things, property damage, business interruption and product and general liability in amounts believed to be consistent with industry practices, but it is not fully insured against all risks, and insurance against all types of risks and catastrophic events may not be available on reasonable economic terms or at all. In addition, our global operations make it more difficult to manage the insurance coverage, as insurance practices and terms vary depending on the jurisdiction, and there can thus be no assurance that we are able to maintain a sufficient insurance coverage in all the jurisdictions in which we operate. The occurrence of an accident that causes losses in excess of limits specified under the relevant policy or is subject to material deductibles or self-insured retentions, or losses arising from events not covered, or not fully covered, by insurance policies, such as certain catastrophic events, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. We may be exposed to natural catastrophic events including, among others, windstorms, hailstorms, severe winter weather, floods, earthquakes and outbreaks of disease, viruses and pandemics, which are inherently unpredictable in terms of both their occurrence, severity, spread and potential harm to human beings. We may also be exposed to the risk of terrorism, the materialization of which could have a material adverse effect on the industries in which we operate and our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Operations
Subsubsection Title: Financial difficulties or bankruptcy of one or more of our major customers or financing counterparties could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: We are exposed to credit risk in relation to our accounts receivable from customers. As of December 31, 2020, our trade and other receivables amounted to €264.7 million. In the past, certain of our customers have experienced, and may experience in the future, financial and operational challenges, the continuation or exacerbation of which could place them in additional financial and operational distress or could even result in their bankruptcy. Although we have in place certain procedures and controls, such as credit insurance and additional credit risk assessment, such measures may not fully or adequately alleviate our exposure to such credit risks. For example, the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic may have a negative effect on the business of our customers, especially in the short-term. See “—The COVID-19 pandemic and possible future outbreaks could _disrupt our business operations.”_ Furthermore, a prolonged duration of the COVID-19 pandemic, including any future outbreaks of the virus or of a similar pandemic, or the other changes in the global economy may put additional financial stress on our customers. Financial and operational challenges experienced by customers may impact our ability to collect outstanding accounts receivables fully or in a timely manner, or at all, and, consequently, result in credit losses and have a material adverse effect on our cash flows. In an uncertain economic situation, it may be difficult to cover our customer credit risks with credit insurance. In addition, the failure by customers to fulfill their payment obligations towards us may have a material adverse effect on the terms or availability of credit insurance for us. These factors, combined with limited availability of credit, could also cause our customers to reduce the volume of their purchases in an effort to improve their own financial position. An uncertain economic situation also leads to increased counterparty risk, that is the risk that one or more of our counterparties may be unable to fulfill their contractual obligations to us. The financial downturn following the COVID-19 pandemic has exacerbated this risk. As uncertainty remains in the global markets, the global economy could fall back into a recession which could lead to banks, insurance companies and other corporations facing financial difficulties, which, in turn, may lead to corporate restructuring arrangements, states taking over companies and bankruptcies. Despite any efforts by us to manage our counterparty risk, there is a possibility that one or more of our counterparties could face serious financial difficulties or bankruptcy. If counterparty risk materializes, we may have to absorb losses in an amount higher than expected or may incur costs relating to, among other things, rearranging our credit transactions, including on less favorable terms, such as an incremental change in our financing rate or insurance contracts. Further, counterparty risks that materialize could force us to obtain alternative financing to meet our obligations under our financing arrangements, and such financing may not be available on commercially acceptable terms, or at all. Materialization of a credit or counterparty risk could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Operations
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to currency exchange rate fluctuations.
Subsubsection Text: We operate and sell products globally, and, as a result, we generate a portion of our sales and incur a portion of our expenses in currencies other than our functional currency, euro, which are primarily U.S. dollar, Swedish 46 ----- krona, Chinese renminbi, Brazilian real, British pound sterling and South Korean won. As a result of our significant presence in the United States, we are particularly exposed to fluctuations in the exchange rate of the U.S. dollar. In addition, purchase prices of pulp, chemicals and freight are primarily denominated in U.S. dollar, and, following the Transactions, a large portion of our indebtedness will be denominated in U.S. dollars. We are exposed to both transaction risk and translation risk. As we incur a portion of our expenses in currencies other than the currencies in which we generate our sales, appreciation of a currency in which costs are incurred against a currency in which sales are generated could have a material adverse impact on our results of operations. To reduce the impact of transaction exposure at the Group level, we have regularly hedged a forecasted exposure to currencies in accordance with our hedging policies, See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial _Condition and Results of Operations—Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Financial Risk—Market Risk—Currency Risk.” Following the Transactions, we also expect to naturally hedge U.S. dollar translation risk_ by designating the USD Notes and the USD TLB Facility as hedges of our net investments denominated in U.S. dollars. However, the hedging policies adopted by us may not be sufficient to reduce or eliminate such risk. In addition, we report our results in euro, but have revenues, expenses, assets and liabilities in other currencies, primarily as the result of our ownership of our foreign subsidiaries. Consequently, we are exposed to translation risk to the extent that assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses are reported in currencies other than euro. In order to prepare our consolidated financial statements, we must translate the value of those assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses at then applicable exchange rates. For more information on currency risk management, see note 19 to the 2020 Financial Statements. As a result, any fluctuations in currency exchange rates could have a material adverse effect our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Operations
Subsubsection Title: An impairment of goodwill, other tangible assets or property, plant and equipment could have a material adverse effect on our financial position or operating results.
Subsubsection Text: As of December 31, 2020, Ahlstrom-Munksjö had €608.9 million of goodwill, €452.3 million of other intangible assets, such as customer relationships, patents, trademarks and technology-related intangible assets, and €1,032.3 million of property, plant and equipment in our balance sheet. Following the Transactions, we will account for the Acquisition using the acquisition method of accounting in accordance with IFRS 3 (Business _Combinations). The application of purchase accounting will result in the recognition of the acquired assets and_ assumed liabilities of Ahlstrom-Munksjö in the consolidated accounts of the Issuer at the acquisition date fair values, which may result in significantly different carrying values for goodwill, intangible assets and property, plant and equipment. Due to these and other potential adjustments, future financial statements for the Group could be materially different and may not be comparable to our Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum, including but not limited to, risk of impairment of goodwill and intangible and tangible assets, increased depreciation and amortization expenses over the remaining lives of the acquired assets and recognition of temporary differences at the acquisition date. None of the financial information in this Offering Memorandum have been adjusted to reflect the impact of any changes to the consolidated statement of financial position, consolidated income statement and other comprehensive income (statement of comprehensive income), consolidated statement of changes in equity and consolidated statement of cash flows that might occur as a result of purchase accounting adjustments to be applied as a result of the Transactions. See “Presentation of Financial _and Other Information Ahlstrom-Munksjo¨—Comparability of the Financial Statements—Impact of the Transactions.”_

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Operations
Subsubsection Title: Certain business area information presented on a pro forma basis included herein needs to be carefully considered.
Subsubsection Text: For internal management reporting purposes, certain business area information has been presented as if Expera Specialty Solutions and Caieiras had been consolidated for the results of the year ended December 31, 2018 and is included in the footnotes to the 2019 and 2018 Financial Statements prepared in accordance with IFRS 8 (Operating Statements) and is presented on a comparable basis to such information for the year ended December 31, 2019. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information—Ahlstrom-Munksjo¨—Comparability _of the Financial Statements—Segment Reporting Principles” and “Presentation of Financial Information and Other_ _Information—Ahlstrom-Munksjo¨—Comparability_ _of_ _the_ _Financial_ _Statements—Acquisitions_ _and Disposals—Acquisitions of Expera Specialty Solutions and Caieiras.” Such information has not been audited and_ does not purport to reflect what the combined results of operations actually would have been had the acquisitions of Expera Specialty Solutions and Caieiras been completed as of the date indicated. Any reliance you place on this information should fully take this into consideration. 47 -----

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Operations
Subsubsection Title: The As Adjusted EBITDA presented is inherently subject to risks and uncertainties.
Subsubsection Text: Our As Adjusted EBITDA presented in this Offering Memorandum represents Comparable EBITDA as adjusted for certain cost savings programs, certain post-acquisition savings programs and a COVID-19 normalization, in each case, as further described under “Summary—Summary Consolidated Financial and Other _Information—As Adjusted Data of the Issuer.” As Adjusted EBITDA has not been subject to audit and the_ adjustments and assumptions that have been used to prepare it may prove to be inaccurate or may be affected by other factors that have not been accounted for. As Adjusted EBITDA is based on a number of assumptions and estimates, including estimates with respect to certain cost savings that we expect to generate following the Transactions and the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. See “—We may not be able to realize the anticipated _operational efficiencies and cost savings in the Acquisition.” Certain of these adjustments and estimates are_ forward-looking by nature and therefore subject to a number of assumptions about the timing, execution and costs associated with implementing the underlying initiatives. Such assumptions are inherently uncertain and are subject to significant business, economic and competition risk and uncertainties. See “Forward—Looking _Statements.”_ As Adjusted EBITDA for the year ended December 31, 2020 has not been prepared in accordance with IFRS, the requirements of Regulation S-X under the Securities Act, the Prospectus Regulation or any generally accepted accounting standards. Neither the assumptions underlying the adjustments nor the resulting As Adjusted EBITDA for the year ended December 31, 2020 has been audited or reviewed in accordance with any generally accepted auditing standards and should not be relied upon when making an investment decision. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information—As Adjusted Financial Information” and “Presentation of _Financial and Other Information—Non-IFRS Financial Measures.”_

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Operations
Subsubsection Title: Our tax burden could increase due to changes in tax laws or regulations or their application and interpretation, or as a result of current or future tax audits.
Subsubsection Text: Due to the international nature of our business, we are subject to the tax laws and regulations of several jurisdictions, in particular with regard to transfer pricing rules. Related companies must conduct any intercompany transactions on an arm’s length basis and provide sufficient documentation thereof, subject to applicable rules of the relevant jurisdiction. The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (“OECD”) has recently published new guidance on transfer pricing. National tax authorities are increasingly scrutinizing and challenging companies’ transfer pricing policies. In addition, the estimation of our total income taxes requires thorough consideration and numerous filings in various countries and the final amount of taxes related to certain transactions and calculations cannot be estimated with full certainty. Our tax burden is, therefore, dependent on specific aspects of tax laws and regulations in several jurisdictions including their application and interpretation. Changes in tax laws or regulations or their application or interpretation could significantly increase our tax burden, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. These include the recent limitations on the right to deduct interest expense and controlled foreign company rules, implemented into national tax laws and applied as of the year 2019, due to the Council Directive (EU) 2016/1164 of 12 July 2016 laying down rules against tax avoidance practices that directly affect the functioning of the internal market (as amended from time to time). Furthermore, the introduction of the OECD multilateral instrument and the inclusion of the so-called principal purpose test in the same could increase uncertainty with respect to application of tax treaties. In addition, we are currently and will be, from time to time, subject to general tax audits by national tax authorities. At the date of this Offering Memorandum, we are subject to tax audits or tax litigation in Italy, Germany, India, Brazil, the United States (Pennsylvania, Kentucky and Illinois) and China. As a result of ongoing or future tax audits or other review actions of tax or other authorities, additional taxes (such as income taxes, withholding taxes, real estate taxes, capital gains taxes, transfer taxes and value added taxes) could be imposed, which could lead to an increase in our tax liabilities either as a result of the relevant tax payment being imposed directly against us or as a result of us becoming liable for the relevant tax as a secondary obligor. Tax audits and claims could have a material adverse effect on us. We and our predecessors have historically grown by acquisitions, with the most significant being the Expera Acquisition and the Caieiras Acquisition in 2018. Tax authorities may question some of the positions that we or our predecessors have taken and, consequently, additional taxes may be assessed, or tax assets may be challenged. The main items under discussion or already disputed relate to transfer pricing and business-related taxes. Although we currently believe that the above-mentioned processes will not have any significant effect on our financial position or profitability, 48 ----- the realization of any risks described above could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Operations
Subsubsection Title: We may be unable to utilize our deferred tax assets.
Subsubsection Text: As of December 31, 2020, Ahlstrom-Munksjö’s recorded deferred tax assets (after netting) and deferred tax liabilities were €6.1 million and €141.7 million, respectively. Our ability to generate taxable income will be subject to general economic, financial, competitive, legislative, regulatory and other factors that are beyond our control. If we generate a lower taxable income than the amount assumed in determining our deferred tax assets or if tax rates are lowered, the value of our deferred tax assets would be reduced. Any of these factors could have a material adverse effect on our financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Operations
Subsubsection Title: Costs related to pension benefit plans could increase.
Subsubsection Text: Ahlstrom-Munksjö has established certain defined pension benefit and defined pension contribution plans in various countries in which it operates or have liability for such plans as part of its historical operations. Accordingly, we will be exposed to various risks related to our defined benefit plans, including the risk of actual investment returns being lower than assumed rates of return and the risk of results deviating from actuarial assumptions for areas such as mortality of plan participants. In addition, fluctuations in interest rates may cause changes in the annual cost and benefit obligations. Higher than expected inflation may increase benefit obligations and annual payments to insurance companies. The additional amount of future contributions to our defined benefit plans will depend upon factors mentioned above and, as a result, the amounts we will be required to contribute in the future may vary. Cash contributions to defined benefit plans will reduce cash available for our business. The above-mentioned risks relate in particular to our plans that are in effect in Sweden, Germany, France, Italy, the United States and the United Kingdom. As of December 31, 2020, Ahlstrom-Munksjö’s employee benefit obligations in the balance sheet amounted to €93.1 million. Any of the above-mentioned risks, if they were to materialize, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Operations
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to the risk of labor disputes, work stoppages and increased labor costs.
Subsubsection Text: Most of our employees are represented by labor unions. Although we believe that our relations with our employees and with our labor unions are generally good, there can be no assurance that this will continue to be the case. A deterioration of relationships between us and our employees and labor unions could result in strikes or work stoppages at any of our facilities. In addition, our relations with employees represented by a labor union are governed by certain collective bargaining agreements and we may not be able to renegotiate satisfactory collective bargaining agreements when they expire, which could lead to, among other consequences, increased labor costs. Such renegotiation could also lead to disputes which may disrupt operations at our production sites. Labor disputes in the transportation sector may prevent the distribution of our products, and labor disputes affecting our suppliers or customers may result in variations in the supply of products and materials to us and in demand for our products and services. Any sustained labor dispute leading to a substantial interruption in our overall business, increased labor costs or changes to the terms of collective bargaining agreements could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Operations
Subsubsection Title: We may from time to time be involved in litigation and other similar proceedings that could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: We may from time to time be involved in litigation and other similar proceedings and further disputes could arise in the ordinary course of business related to, among others, contracts, tax issues, alleged defects in product deliveries, health and safety matters, competition law, intellectual property, employment matters, and environmental issues. Such litigation and other similar proceedings may be costly, divert management attention, disrupt normal operations and result in reputational damage for us. The outcome of any dispute is impossible to predict. It is also impossible to rule out the possibility of an unfavorable outcome in ongoing proceedings, or any proceedings that may arise in the future, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Business and Operations
Subsubsection Title: Concerns about the effects of climate change may have an impact on our business.
Subsubsection Text: Concerns about global warming and carbon footprints, as well as legal and financial incentives favoring alternative fuels, are causing the increased use of sustainable, non-fossil fuel sources for electricity generation. 49 ----- Electricity generation companies are competing in the same markets as us for the same raw materials that we use in some of our production process, namely wood and derivative products, driving prices for such materials upwards, especially during the winter in the Northern hemisphere. Climate change could also cause the spread of disease and pestilence into plantations and fiber sources, far beyond their traditional geographic spreads, increasing the risk that the wood supply necessary to our operations may be negatively impacted. If either of these phenomena intensifies, additional costs or supply shortages could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to the Transactions
Subsubsection Title: Ownership of 100% of the Company Shares is dependent on the completion of the Squeeze-Out.
Subsubsection Text: As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Issuer owns 90.6% of the Company Shares. The Issuer has filed an application to initiate the Squeeze-Out proceedings as provided in the Finnish Companies Act in order to gain 100% of the Company Shares. Until such time as the Squeeze-Out has completed or the Issuer has obtained advance title to the remaining minority Company Shares against the placing of a security under the Squeeze-out proceedings, third-party minority shareholders will continue to hold the outstanding Company Shares. The Squeeze-Out is an arbitral proceeding regulated by the Finnish Companies Act and the Finnish Arbitration Act, which could potentially be time consuming, and is subject to appeal by one or more minority shareholders. These proceedings typically take approximately eight to twelve months to complete but advance title to the minority shares may, subject to the discretion of the arbitral tribunal, under the proceedings often be obtained in approximately four to six months against the placing of a security. These proceedings may also be longer due to events outside the Issuer’s control. Further, in the event that the placing of a security by the Issuer for obtaining of the advance title is refused by the arbitral tribunal, the Issuer could decide not to place such security or appeal the arbitral award and if the Issuer decides not to pay the redemption price in accordance with such award, the minority shareholders would potentially continue to hold some or all of the outstanding Company Shares until the Issuer’s redemption right and the redemption price have been finally determined by a non-appealable arbitral award or court decision and such redemption price has been paid by the Issuer.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to the Transactions
Subsubsection Title: The Sponsors’ opportunity to conduct due diligence with respect to Ahlstrom-Munksjö was limited, and their due diligence may not have revealed all facts that may be relevant in connection with the Acquisition.
Subsubsection Text: Before making investments, the Sponsors conduct due diligence that they deem reasonable and appropriate based on the facts and circumstances applicable to each investment. The objectives of the due diligence process are to identify attractive investment opportunities based on the facts and circumstances relevant to a specific asset, to identify possible risks associated with such asset and to prepare a framework that may be used from the date of the acquisition of such asset to drive operational achievement and value creation in such asset. When conducting due diligence, the Sponsors typically evaluate a number of important business, financial, tax, accounting, environmental and legal issues in determining whether or not to proceed with an investment. Outside consultants, legal advisors, accountants and investment banks are involved in the due diligence process in varying degrees depending on the type of investment. Nevertheless, when conducting due diligence and making an assessment regarding an investment, the Sponsors rely on resources available to them, including information provided by the target of the investment and, in some circumstances, third party investigations. Instances of bribery, fraud, accounting irregularities, contingent liabilities and other improper, illegal or corrupt practices can be difficult to detect, and fraud and other deceptive practices can be widespread in certain jurisdictions. There may be liabilities that the Sponsors failed or were unable to discover in the course of performing due diligence investigations into us and our subsidiaries in connection with the Acquisition. Following the Acquisition, the Sponsors may learn of additional information about us and/or any of our subsidiaries that adversely affect us, such as unknown or contingent liabilities and issues relating to compliance with applicable laws. Any such liabilities, individually or in the aggregate, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position and results of operations. As Ahlstrom-Munksjö is a publicly listed company, the due diligence conducted for the Acquisition was mostly limited to publicly available information and certain other information made available to the Sponsors as part of their due diligence process. Accordingly, we cannot be certain that the Sponsors’ due diligence investigation has revealed or highlighted all relevant facts (including fraud, bribery and other illegal activities and contingent liabilities) that may be necessary or helpful in evaluating the merits of investing in us. We cannot be certain that the Sponsors’ due diligence investigations will result in the Sponsors’ investment in us being 50 ----- successful or that the actual financial performance of such investment will not fall short of the financial projections the Sponsors used when evaluating that investment.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to the Transactions
Subsubsection Title: We may not be able to realize the anticipated operational efficiencies and cost savings in the Acquisition.
Subsubsection Text: The Sponsors intend to implement certain operational efficiency and cost saving measures in connection with the Acquisition. We may not be able to realize the anticipated efficiencies and savings targeted by these measures, either in the amount or within the timeframe that we currently anticipate, and the costs of achieving these measures may be higher than what we expect. Our estimated efficiency gains and costs savings are forward-looking and therefore subject to a number of assumptions about the timing, execution and costs associated with realizing the underlying measures. Such assumptions are inherently uncertain and are subject to significant business, economic and competition risks and uncertainties. There can be no assurance that such assumptions will turn out to be correct. In addition, the estimated efficiency gains and cost savings may be offset by deterioration in the markets in which we operate, increases in other expenses or challenges in the business unrelated to the Transactions. As a result, the amount of efficiency gains and savings that we will actually realize and/or the timing of any such realization may differ significantly (and may be significantly lower or later) from the ones that we currently estimate and we may incur significant costs in realizing the Acquisition and in reaching the estimated gains and savings. Failure to achieve the expected efficiency gains and savings may result in a lower return on investment for the Acquisition and could have a material adverse effect on our business and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to the Transactions
Subsubsection Title: The Acquisition will entitle certain of Ahlstrom-Munksjö‘s customers and business partners to terminate their agreements with Ahlstrom-Munksjö as a result of change of control provisions.
Subsubsection Text: Certain of the agreements entered into by Ahlstrom-Munksjö and its subsidiaries include change of control provisions. The Acquisition may constitute a change of control under such agreements. As a result, counterparties to these agreements may be entitled to terminate their agreements with Ahlstrom-Munksjö as a result of the Acquisition. Some of these counterparties may exercise their termination rights, which could have an adverse effect on Ahlstrom-Munksjö‘s business, financial position and results of operations. In addition, changes of control may be subject to approval by governmental authorities. In the event of termination of any material contract as a result of the Acquisition, there can be no assurance that Ahlstrom-Munksjö would be able to successfully replace any products or services that were provided under the relevant contract at attractive prices or at all. Likewise, if Ahlstrom-Munksjö is required to amend any such contract, we can provide no assurance that the terms of such amendment will not be materially adverse to us or will not otherwise impact Ahlstrom-Munksjö‘s business or operations. Accordingly, any termination or amendment of a significant contract as a result of the change of control could materially or adversely affect Ahlstrom-Munksjö‘s business and the ability to provide services to our customers. It is also possible that material supply contracts could be terminated or amended in other circumstances. Any such termination or amendment could have a material adverse effect on Ahlstrom-Munksjö‘s business, results of operations and financial condition.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Indebtedness
Subsubsection Title: Our significant amount of debt and debt service obligations could materially adversely affect our business, financial position and results of operations and preclude us from satisfying our obligations under the Notes and the Note Guarantees.
Subsubsection Text: We have a significant amount of debt and debt service obligations. As of December 31, 2020, after giving effect to the Transactions, we would have had total as adjusted indebtedness (including lease liabilities amounting to €51.0 million) in a nominal amount of €1,845.6 million (equivalent), of which €1,650.0 million (equivalent) is senior secured indebtedness consisting of the Notes and the Senior Term Facilities. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, there were no cash drawings under the Revolving Credit Facility. See “Capitalization,” “Description of Other Indebtedness,” and “Description of the Notes.” We anticipate that our high leverage will continue to exist for the foreseeable future. The degree to which we will be leveraged following completion of the Transactions could have important consequences to holders of the Notes, including, but not limited to: - making it more difficult for the Issuer and its subsidiaries to satisfy their respective obligations with respect to the Notes, the Senior Secured Credit Facilities and other debt and liabilities we may incur; 51 ----- - increasing our vulnerability to, and reducing our flexibility to respond to, general adverse economic and industry conditions; - requiring the dedication of a substantial portion of our cash flow from operations to the payment of principal of, and interest on, our indebtedness, thereby reducing the availability of such cash flow to fund working capital, capital expenditures, acquisitions, joint ventures, product research and development, or other general corporate purposes; - restricting us from pursuing acquisitions or exploiting business opportunities; - limiting our flexibility in planning for, or reacting to, changes in our business, the competitive environment and the industry in which we operate; - negatively impacting credit terms with our suppliers and other creditors; - increasing our exposure to interest rate increases because some of our indebtedness bears a floating rate of interest; - placing us at a competitive disadvantage compared to our competitors that are not as highly leveraged; - limiting our ability to obtain additional financing to fund future operations, capital expenditures, business opportunities, acquisitions and other general corporate purposes and increasing the cost of any future borrowings; - limiting our ability to obtain additional capacity for issuance of bid, advance payment, performance and warranty guarantees for operative business purposes and increasing the cost of any future guarantee issuances; and - tax implications arising from the Transactions, tax deductibility of interest costs thereon, an increase in our effective tax rate and tax jurisdictions involved. Any of these or other consequences or events could have a material adverse effect on our ability to satisfy our obligations, including under the Notes and the Senior Secured Credit Facilities.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Indebtedness
Subsubsection Title: The Issuer is a holding company that has no revenue generating operations of its own and will depend on cash from the operating companies of the Group to be able to make payments on the Notes and the Note Guarantees.
Subsubsection Text: The Issuer is a holding company with no business operations other than management of the equity interests it holds in its subsidiaries. The Issuer will be dependent upon the cash flow from its operating subsidiaries in the form of dividends or other distributions or payments to meet its obligations, including its obligations under the Notes and the Note Guarantees. Given the Group’s international operations, it has a large number of operating subsidiaries and business participations, which individually contribute to our Group’s results. The amounts of dividends and distributions available to the Issuer will depend on the profitability and cash flows of their subsidiaries and the ability of each of those subsidiaries to declare dividends under applicable law or transfer profits under profit and loss transfer agreements, if applicable. The Issuer’s subsidiaries, however, may not be able to, or may not be permitted under applicable law to, make distributions or advance upstream loans to the Issuer to make payments in respect of their indebtedness, including the Notes and the Note Guarantees. Various agreements governing our debt may restrict and, in some cases may actually prohibit, the ability of these subsidiaries to move cash within their restricted group. Applicable tax laws may also subject such payments to further taxation. Applicable law as well as profit and loss transfer agreements between several entities of the Group may also limit the amounts that some of our subsidiaries will be permitted to pay as dividends or distributions on their equity interests, or even prevent such payments. In particular, the ability of the Issuer’s subsidiaries to pay dividends to the Issuer will generally be limited to the amount of distributable reserves available to each of them and the ability to pay their respective debt when due. The subsidiaries of the Issuer that do not guarantee the Notes have no direct obligation to make payments with respect to the Notes or the Note Guarantees. While the Indenture limits the ability of the Issuer’s subsidiaries to incur consensual restrictions on their ability to pay dividends or make other intercompany payments, these limitations are subject to significant qualifications and exceptions, including exceptions for restrictions imposed by applicable law. 52 -----

Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Indebtedness
Subsubsection Title: We may incur substantially more debt in the future, which may make it difficult for us to service our debt, including the Notes, and impair our ability to operate our businesses.
Subsubsection Text: Despite our substantial leverage, we may incur substantial additional debt in the future. We have the ability to borrow up to approximately €325.0 million (equivalent) under our Revolving Credit Facility, which will be secured by the Collateral, and the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement permits, and the Indenture will permit, the incurrence of additional debt thereunder, including additional debt that may be secured on the Collateral. The Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement permits, and the Indenture will permit, us to incur a substantial amount of indebtedness at subsidiaries that do not guarantee the Notes and to incur indebtedness that may be secured on the assets comprising in the Collateral or that benefits from security interests over assets that do not secure the Notes. Any debt that our subsidiaries incur could be structurally or effectively senior to the Notes to the extent that such subsidiaries do not guarantee the Notes such debt is secured by liens that do not secure the Notes, to the extent of the value of such property and assets securing such debt. Moreover, we will be permitted to incur other debt that matures prior to the Notes. Although the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement contains, and the Indenture will contain, restrictions on the incurrence of additional indebtedness, these restrictions are subject to a number of significant qualifications and exceptions, and under certain circumstances the amount of indebtedness that could be incurred in compliance with these restrictions could be substantial. If the Issuer and its subsidiaries increase their existing debt levels, the related risks would increase. In addition, the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement does not, and the Indenture will not, prevent us from incurring obligations that do not constitute indebtedness under those agreements. Our inability to service our debt could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations and our ability to fulfil our obligations under the Notes and the Note Guarantees.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Indebtedness
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to restrictive covenants that will limit our operating and financial flexibility.
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement contains, and the Indenture will contain, covenants which impose significant operating and financial restrictions on us. These agreements limit our ability to, among other things: - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness or issue certain preferred stock; - make certain restricted payments and investments; - transfer or sell assets; - enter into transactions with affiliates; - create or incur certain liens; - make certain loans, investments or acquisitions; - issue or sell share capital of certain of our subsidiaries; - create or incur restrictions on the ability of our subsidiaries to pay dividends or to make other payments to us; - take certain actions that would impair the security interests in the Collateral granted for the benefit of the holders of the Notes; - merge, consolidate or transfer all or substantially all of our assets; and - pay or redeem subordinated debt or equity. All of these limitations will be subject to significant exceptions and qualifications. See “Description of the _Notes—Certain Covenants.” The covenants to which we will be subject could limit our ability to finance our_ future operations and capital needs and our ability to pursue business opportunities and activities that may be in our interest. In addition, the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement requires us to comply with certain affirmative covenants while amounts under the Senior Secured Credit Facilities remain outstanding. Furthermore, under certain circumstances, the Revolving Credit Facility under the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement will require us to comply with a financial ratio while amounts exceeding a certain threshold remains outstanding under the Revolving Credit Facility. See “Description of Other Indebtedness—Senior Secured Credit Facilities _Agreement.” Our ability to meet the financial ratio under the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement may be_ affected by events beyond our control, and we cannot assure you that we will meet such financial ratio, which 53 ----- could result in a draw stop under the Revolving Credit Facility. A breach of any of the covenants or restrictions under the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement could result in an event of default under the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement. Upon the occurrence of a payment event of default that is continuing under the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement, subject to the applicable cure period and any other limitations on acceleration or enforcement, the relevant creditors could cancel the availability of the Senior Secured Credit Facilities and elect to declare all amounts outstanding under the Senior Secured Credit Facilities, together with accrued interest, immediately due and payable. In addition, a default under the Senior Secured Credit Facilities could lead to an event of default and acceleration under other debt instruments that contain cross-default or crossacceleration provisions, including the Indenture. If our creditors, including the creditors under the Senior Secured Credit Facilities, accelerate the payment of those amounts, we cannot assure you that our assets and the assets of our subsidiaries would be sufficient to repay in full those amounts, to satisfy all other liabilities of our subsidiaries that would be due and payable and to make payments to enable us to repay the Notes. In addition, if we are unable to repay those amounts, our creditors could proceed against any Collateral granted to them to secure repayment of those amounts.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Indebtedness
Subsubsection Title: We will require a significant amount of cash to service our debt and sustain our operations, which we may not be able to generate or raise.
Subsubsection Text: Our ability to make principal or interest payments when due on our indebtedness, including the Senior Secured Credit Facilities and our obligations under the Notes, and to fund our ongoing operations or expansion plans, will depend on our future performance and ability to generate cash, which, to a certain extent, is subject to the success of our business strategy as well as general economic, financial, competitive, legislative, legal, regulatory and other factors, as well as other factors discussed in these “Risk Factors,” many of which are beyond our control. We cannot assure you that our business will generate sufficient cash flows from operations, that currently anticipated growth, cost savings or efficiencies will be realized or that future debt financing will be available to us in an amount sufficient to enable us to pay our debts when due, including the Notes, or to fund our other liquidity needs including the repayment at maturity of the then outstanding amount under the Senior Secured Credit Facilities. At the maturity of the Senior Secured Credit Facilities (including the Revolving Credit Facility, which matures six months before the Notes), the Notes or any other debt that we may incur, if we do not have sufficient cash flows from operations and other capital resources to pay our debt obligations, or to fund our other liquidity needs, we may be required to refinance or restructure our indebtedness. If our future cash flows from operations and other capital resources are insufficient to pay our obligations as they mature or to fund our liquidity needs, we may be forced to: - sell assets; - obtain additional debt or equity capital; or - restructure or refinance all or a portion of our debt, including the Notes, on or before maturity. The type, timing and terms of any future financing, restructuring, asset sales or other capital raising transactions will depend on our cash needs and the prevailing conditions in the financial markets. We cannot assure you that we would be able to accomplish any of these alternatives on a timely basis or on satisfactory terms, if at all. In such an event, we may not have sufficient assets to repay any portion or all of our debt. Any failure to make payments on the Notes on a timely basis would likely result in a reduction of our credit rating, which could also harm our ability to incur additional indebtedness. In addition, the terms of our debt, including the Notes and the Senior Secured Credit Facilities, limit or will limit, and any future debt may limit, our ability to pursue any of these alternatives. Any refinancing of our debt could be at higher interest rates and may require us to comply with more onerous covenant or other terms, which could further restrict our business, financial position and results of operations. There can be no assurances that any assets that we could be required to dispose of could be sold or that, if sold, the timing of such sale and the amount of proceeds realized from such sale would be acceptable. If we are unsuccessful in any of these efforts, we may not have sufficient cash to meet our obligations.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Indebtedness
Subsubsection Title: The Senior Secured Credit Facilities bear interest at floating rates that could rise significantly, thereby increasing our costs and reducing our cash flow.
Subsubsection Text: Debt under the Senior Secured Credit Facilities will bear interest at a variable rate based on the Euro Interbank Offered Rate (“EURIBOR”) and the London Interbank Offered Rate (“LIBOR”) (in each case, subject 54 ----- to a zero floor if less than zero) plus an applicable margin. These interest rates could rise significantly in the future, increasing our interest expense associated with these obligations, reducing cash flow available for capital expenditures and hindering our ability to make payments on the Notes. Neither the Senior Secured Credit Facilities Agreement nor the Indenture contains a covenant requiring us to hedge all or any portion of our floating rate debt.
