While such protests have largely diminished in response to government concessions, any such future protect could pose a risk to our supply chain continuity and restaurant operations. Any continued or resurgent social and political uncertainty may expose us to greater risks of interruption of our operations. Further, our security costs may rise and footfall in our stores may suffer as a result of any adjacent incidents of social unrest or violence. We cannot accurately predict the extent to which such events may affect us, directly or indirectly, in the future. Prolonged disruptions of our operations due to natural disasters, civil unrest or other catastrophic events, may adversely affect our results of operations and financial condition. Although we have insurance policies in place, we cannot assure you that we will continue to be able to obtain adequate insurance coverage with respect to natural disasters, civil unrest, terrorist attacks or other catastrophic events and any losses that could result from such events in the future. Terrorist attacks in France and abroad, as well as war and threats of war or actual conflicts involving France or other countries, may dramatically and adversely impact the economy of France and cause consumer confidence and spending to decrease. Any of these occurrences could result in a material adverse effect on our operating results, financial condition and prospects. Further, following the COVID-19 pandemic, most insurance companies have begun to exclude pandemics from their insurance coverage of operating losses. To the extent we renew our insurance coverage or face a subsequent pandemic, our insurance coverage of the negative impact on our operating losses would no longer be subject to coverage.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Business
Subsubsection Title: Burger King France, the largest brand in our portfolio, holds a master franchise for the Burger King trademarks and trade names in France and is therefore highly dependent on its franchisor.
Subsubsection Text: In 2013, Burger King France entered into the twenty-year Master Franchise Agreement with BK Europe, the duration of which has since been amended in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic to extend for an additional year through December 31, 2034, pursuant to which Burger King France has the exclusive right to use certain trademarks and trade names associated with Burger King in mainland France, open and operate Burger King Company Restaurants and select and offer sub-franchisees the right to operate such restaurants. We do not own the Burger King brand, and we are therefore highly dependent on the franchisor, BK Europe and its ultimate parent, Burger King Corporation (“BKC”). Moreover, the Master Franchise Agreement contains certain undertakings, and failure to reach certain restaurant opening milestones may result in fines or early termination in certain circumstances. If the Master Franchise Agreement were terminated, we would not be able to continue to expand the Burger King network and realize anticipated economies of scale, although we would be able to continue to operate the existing Burger King network under certain conditions. The early termination of the Master Franchise Agreement with BK Europe could adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition. We cannot control or influence the actions of BK Europe as master franchisor, and BK Europe may take actions that could harm our operation of Burger King brand restaurants. For example, BK Europe may at any time have economic, business or legal interests or goals that are inconsistent with ours. Certain actions taken by BK Europe, including those involving the Burger King brand, may adversely affect our business operations such as BKC requiring its franchisees to adopt a product offering that we do not believe would be popular with consumers in France. Moreover, if BK Europe does not adequately protect the Burger King brand and other intellectual property rights, Burger King’s brand perception could deteriorate in France and our competitive position, business, results of operations and financial condition could be adversely affected. Additionally, pursuant to the Master Franchise Agreement with BK Europe, Burger King is required to comply with operational programs established by the master franchisor. For example, the Master Franchise Agreement requires that our Burger King restaurants comply with specified design criteria. In addition, the master franchisor generally has the right to require us to remodel Burger King restaurants to conform to the then-current image of Burger King, which may require the expenditure of considerable funds. Failure to conform to these requirements could constitute a breach of the Master Franchise Agreement, which could adversely affect our competitive position, business, results of operations and financial condition. See “Business—Our Networks—Our Brands— _The Burger King Master Franchise Agreement”._ 39 -----

Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Business
Subsubsection Title: Consumer preferences and perceptions in relation to food consumption may continue to change and we may be unable to adapt to such changes
Subsubsection Text: Our business is affected by consumer preferences and perceptions in relation to both drink and food, as well as demographic trends over time. If we fail to tailor the restaurant brands in our portfolio to respond to customers’ evolving preferences, we may not be able to sustain or increase customer traffic and we may lose our market share to our competitors. While the restaurant brands in our portfolio cater to different consumer preferences through diverse cuisine types, price points, formats and channels, our overall success depends on the continued appeal of such brands in the context of rapidly evolving consumer preferences. In particular, the QSR segment is characterized by the frequent introduction of new products, often supported by substantial promotional campaigns, and is subject to changing consumer preferences, tastes, and eating and purchasing habits. Any failure by us to anticipate, identify and respond to trends in consumer preferences could have a material adverse effect on our business, operating results, financial condition and prospects. Customers have become increasingly concerned with making health-conscious dining choices, as well as the provenance of locally sourced ingredients, which impacts all of the restaurant brands in our portfolio, but in particular has a strong impact on the product options available in our QSR restaurant brands. If we do not rapidly and adequately respond to prevailing health or dietary preferences and perceptions, consumers may avoid our restaurant brands, particularly our QSR brands, in favor of alternative food options, which could cause our business to suffer. In addition, negative publicity about the options that our restaurant brands offer could adversely harm our business, results of operations and financial condition. In recent years, numerous restaurant concepts have introduced products positioned to capitalize on the growing consumer preference for food products that are, or are perceived to be, healthy, nutritious and low in calories, sodium and fat content or that meet other nutritional criteria, such as gluten-free, vegetarian or vegan. Our success will depend in part on our ability to anticipate and respond to changing consumer preferences, tastes and eating and purchasing habits by adapting the restaurant brands in our portfolio to respond to these changes and our franchisees adequately adapting these changes. Responding to such shifts in consumer preferences could entail specific costs. There can be no assurance that we will continue to be able to respond to these or other trends in consumer preference by introducing changes to our formats, brands, drink and food offerings and premises or otherwise. In addition, consumers are increasingly reliant on food delivery services. This trend was significantly accelerated as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. Sustained consumer reliance on food delivery services could have longterm effects on our operations. In France, the food delivery service industry is predominantly concentrated among a few key players, such as Deliveroo, Uber Eats and Just-Eat. A sustained increase in our consumers’ preference for food delivery has made us reliant on the few main delivery aggregators. Further, purchases made through third-party delivery aggregators require the payment of an additional fee to such third-party aggregators, increasing our overall costs. In the long-term, we may need to raise our prices to recoup the additional delivery fees, or alternatively reduce our margins. Our business is significantly influenced by the evolving preferences and perceptions of consumers, not only regarding the products we offer but also the channels through which they access them. As trends shift, there is an increasing expectation for a variety of dining options, including home delivery, eat-in, click & collect, drive-through, and take-away services. Our restaurant brands must adeptly develop and balance these offerings to meet the diverse needs of our customers. The failure to anticipate or respond to changes in consumer preferences for product offerings or service modalities could result in a decline in customer patronage. Any such eventuality could reduce our sales or have a material impact on our financial condition or results of operations. If our competitors are more innovative than we are, if we fail to appropriately respond to changes in consumer preferences and perceptions or if prevailing health or diet preferences cause customers to avoid our restaurants brands, in particular our QSR restaurant brands, in favor of foods that are perceived to be healthier, we may fail to retain existing, or attract new, customers. Any failure to retain existing, or attract new, customers could have an adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. 40 -----

Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Business
Subsubsection Title: Food safety, food-traceability, food-borne illness and hygiene-related concerns, including failure by us, our franchisees or third-parties to supply or handle food products in compliance with food safety regulations or our requirements, may adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: Food safety, food-traceability (including in respect of product origins, freshness and conditions of preservation through the supply chain) and hygiene are top priorities, and we dedicate substantial resources to ensure that our customers enjoy safe, quality food products in a clean environment. However, food-borne illnesses, such as E. coli, listeria, bovine spongiform encephalopathy or “mad cow disease”, hepatitis A, trichinosis or salmonella, and food safety issues have occurred in the food industry in the past, and could occur in the future. New illnesses resistant to existing precautions or diseases with long incubation periods may develop in the future, such as mad cow disease, which could give rise to claims or allegations on a retroactive basis. Risks to the health of our customers can arise from our supply and logistics chain, which we do not control, and at our Company Restaurant and Franchise Restaurant locations. We rely on third party food suppliers, distributors, logistics and warehousing partners to supply ingredients used in the preparation of the meals our restaurant brands sell, including sauces, meat and fresh produce. Although such third parties are subject to regulations, including food safety and environmental regulations, such regulations may not prevent such third parties from experiencing problems related to food safety and hygiene. Further, although we aim to work with the highest quality suppliers by pre-approving a limited number of suppliers that work with our restaurant brands, we do not control such suppliers and cannot guarantee that food safety related risks will not materialize. As a result, our reliance on third party food suppliers, distributors, logistics and warehousing partners increases the risk that food-borne illness incidents could be caused by factors outside of our control and that multiple restaurant brands and locations would be affected rather than a single restaurant. In addition, although we maintain operational controls and provide employee and franchisee training aimed at preventing food-borne illnesses, food tampering and other food safety issues, we can provide no assurance that these measures will be sufficient. Moreover, we are increasingly reliant on food delivery aggregators to deliver food from our restaurants to the customers, which may increase the risk that food- or beverage-borne illness incidents and food safety issues could be caused by factors outside of our control. Any report or publicity linking us, one of our franchisees, any of our brand restaurants in France or, in the case of our brands that also have international operations, restaurants in other countries, to instances of food-borne illness or other food safety issues, including food tampering or contamination, could adversely affect any of the brands in our portfolio, along with our revenue and profits. Outbreaks of disease, including influenza, or the continued emergence of COVID-19 variants, could reduce footfall in our restaurants. If customers were to become ill from food-borne or hygiene-related illnesses, we or our franchisees could also be forced to temporarily close some restaurants and, more significantly, our reputation and the reputation of our brands could be damaged, which could result in a decline in sales, thereby negatively affecting our business, results of operations and financial condition. Additionally, failure by any of our third-party food suppliers, distributors, logistics and warehousing partners to comply with regulations, allegations of compliance failure, claims of intentional or negligent contamination of ingredients and raw materials or prolonged and intense negative publicity may disrupt their operations and result in a disruption of our food supply. Disruption of our third-party food suppliers, distributors, logistics and warehousing partners’ operations could in turn reduce or impair our supply of ingredients or other raw materials, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. This risk is heightened in the case of our restaurant brands that rely on the supply pooling that we facilitate, as a reduction in supply from any one of our supply pool suppliers that provides products for multiple restaurant brands could have an impact across multiple restaurant brand operations. In addition, instances of food-borne illness, food tampering or food contamination occurring at restaurants of competitors could also adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition as a result of negative publicity about the food service industry generally. The occurrence of food-borne illnesses or food safety issues could also adversely affect the price and availability of ingredients, which could result in supply chain disruptions, significantly increasing our costs and/or lowering margins for us and our franchisees. In addition, our industry has long been subject to the threat of food tampering by suppliers, employees or guests, such as the addition of foreign objects in the food that we sell. We cannot guarantee that our operational controls and employee training will be effective in preventing food-borne illnesses, food tampering and other food safety issues that may affect our restaurants. Reports of alleged injuries caused by food tampering have in the past severely injured the reputations of restaurant chains and could negatively affect us in the future as well. 41 ----- In addition, the QSR industry is currently under heightened journalistic, legislative and regulatory scrutiny stemming from the perception that some QSR products have contributed to widespread medical problems, such as obesity and diabetes. See “—The growing concern about obesity and personal health may affect our sales.” Compliance with consumer health laws and regulations, such as those regarding the ingredients and nutritional content of our menu items, may be costly and time-consuming. Additionally, if such laws and regulations change significantly, our QSR restaurant brands may be required to modify or discontinue certain menu items, and the higher costs associated with the implementation of those changes may reduce our margins. We cannot make any assurances regarding our ability to effectively respond to changes in consumer health regulations or our ability to successfully implement the nutrient content disclosure requirements and to adapt our menu accordingly. The imposition of menu-labeling laws could have an adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial conditions, as well as on the QSR industry in general.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Business
Subsubsection Title: The growing concern about obesity and personal health may affect our sales.
Subsubsection Text: Over the past few years, consumers have developed an increased awareness of the health benefits of eating natural products with high nutritional value, reducing consumption of products with low nutritional content. In addition, there has been an increased focus on obesity in various media and social media outlets, including television and radio shows and public service announcements. This trend may affect our sales since some of the products we offer are regarded as of low nutritional value and high in calories.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Business
Subsubsection Title: Our success depends substantially on the value and perception of the restaurant brands in our portfolio and on our corporate reputation.
Subsubsection Text: Our success depends in large part upon the value of the restaurant brands in our portfolio in the eyes of our customers and our ability to preserve, enhance and leverage the value of such brands. Brand value is partly based on consumer perceptions of a variety of subjective qualities, some of which we may have limited or no control over. Isolated or repeated events that originate from us, our franchisees or suppliers, can significantly reduce brand value and consumer trust, particularly if the incidents receive considerable publicity or result in litigation. For example, our restaurant brands could be damaged by claims or perceptions about the quality or safety of our products or the quality of our suppliers and distributors, regardless of whether such claims or perceptions are true. The reputation of our restaurant brands can also be negatively impacted if consumers perceive that we or our franchisees have acted in an unethical, illegal, biased or socially irresponsible manner. Further, entities in our supply chain may engage in conduct, including alleged human rights abuses, which damages the reputation of the brands in our portfolio. Any such incidents could cause a decline in consumer confidence in, or negatively affect the perception of, our restaurant brands, decreasing the value of our brands as well as consumer demand for our restaurants, which could result in lower revenue and profits. We may not always be able to control the occurrence and mitigation of such incidents that create a negative impact on our brands’ reputation. Additionally, our corporate reputation could suffer from a real or perceived failure of corporate governance or misconduct by a company officer or representative. The occurrence of any of the foregoing could have a material impact on the financial performance of any of our restaurant brands, which could in turn have a negative impact on our overall financial performance and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Business
Subsubsection Title: We rely on third-party suppliers, logistics operators and distributors and our business may be disrupted if our key suppliers experience operational difficulties or we cannot maintain satisfactory contracts with these third- parties.
Subsubsection Text: We are dependent on third-party suppliers, logistics operators and distributors for our products, which exposes us to risks that such suppliers may fail to meet timelines, provide us with sufficient products or comply with our specifications. With respect to the Burger King brand, we pre-approve a limited number of suppliers, while logistics are managed by QSR Logistics. For the rest of our brands, we pre-approve a limited number of key product suppliers for each brand and have also put into place supply pooling systems for products used by multiple brands (such as beverage and packaging), with logistics of key products managed through third parties, mainly Transgourmet and Sysco. As a result, we are dependent on the third parties that provide supply, logistics and distribution services to our brands to ensure smooth restaurant operations across our entire business. This select group of third parties, while ensuring consistency and quality, also present a vulnerability. Any issues that arise with these third parties, such as a disruption due to economic, environmental, or political factors, could hamper 42 ----- our restaurant brands’ ability to provide their respective signature dining experiences, which could result in fewer sales and have a negative impact on our financial performance. This risk is heightened in connection with the supplies secured through our supply-pooling platform. While the decision to pool the procurement of certain supplies across brands streamlines the supply of key materials and provides cost saving advantages, it also creates a risk that any issue, shortage or delay of materials secured through the supply pooling platform will have a negative impact on multiple brands across our portfolio. While we may in the future choose to certify additional suppliers in order to diversify our raw material sourcing or to replace our existing suppliers, such certifications may take longer than anticipated to obtain. We cannot guarantee that we will be able to locate suppliers that meet our certification requirements quickly. Any difficulty in locating an adequate number of such certified suppliers could affect our restaurants’ operations and market position, which could adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition. While we negotiate contract renewals where desirable, we cannot guarantee that we will be successful in obtaining renewals of our existing contracts with our suppliers on the same or similar terms, or at all. Failure to timely agree renewals with our suppliers and distributors, termination of these agreements or a variation of its terms could cause distribution or supply disruptions and could increase costs if we are required to find alternative suppliers and distributors, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, operating results, financial condition and prospects. Further, the lack of direct control over these third-party suppliers and logistics providers adds another layer of complexity to our risk management. We require the suppliers that service our restaurant brands to meet certain specifications and standards to ensure the high quality of our products. If the products provided by our suppliers do not meet the relevant quality standards, our reputation may be adversely affected. All of the foregoing risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Business
Subsubsection Title: Increases in input costs, such as ingredients, packaging materials fuel and electricity, or shortages or interruptions in the availability of these supplies or other equipment, could adversely affect our results of operation.
Subsubsection Text: The operation of our restaurant brands depends on reliable sources of large quantities of raw materials, as well as significant amounts of electricity and fuel to regulate the temperature of food protects stored in restaurants. The type, variety, quality, source and price of beef, chicken, produce and cheese, namely, can be subject to change due to factors beyond our control, including fluctuations in commodities markets, governmental agricultural policies, macroeconomic conditions, seasonality factors, demand levels, health regulations, customs barriers, taxes and tariffs (including as a result of trade disputes), inflationary conditions, labor shortages, transportation issues, food safety warnings, the operations of suppliers, political upheavals, energy costs and unforeseen events, such as severe weather conditions (which may be exacerbated by climate change). In the event of a supply disruption, a rise in commodities prices or other adverse event that affects our sources, our food, fuel and electricity or logistics costs could materially increase. Increases in prices or scarcity of ingredients or packaging materials required for the food served by our restaurant brands could increase our costs and disrupt our operations. Volatility in global food and drink prices and energy costs can have a negative impact on our operating margins. Although we have procedures in place to anticipate changes in the cost of certain raw materials used in the preparation of our products, any increase in the cost of the ingredients used in our products that cannot be transferred to our customers could affect our results of operations. If supplies of these materials become scarce or prices otherwise increase significantly and remain high for an extended period of time, there can be no assurance that we would be able to pass on any or all of the effects of such price increases to our customers, which could adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition. Taking into account ongoing inflationary conditions, we have recently experienced an increase in the prices of various raw materials and other operating costs (such as energy costs) as well as increased volatility in such prices and costs, which has adversely affected, and may continue to adversely affect our results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Business
Subsubsection Title: There are risks associated with our increasing dependence on third-party delivery aggregators to maintain and grow sales.
Subsubsection Text: Customers are increasingly using apps owned by us or third-party delivery aggregators (such as Deliveroo, Uber Eats and Just-Eat) and third-party developers and payment processors, to order and pay for food delivery or Click & Collect services from our restaurants. As a result, our business is increasingly reliant on third-party delivery 43 ----- aggregators and digital ordering and payment as a sales channel. Our business and/or growth prospects could be negatively impacted if we are unable to successfully implement, execute or maintain our consumer-facing digital initiatives across the restaurants in our brand portfolio, such as delivery, curbside pick-up and mobile carryout. If the third-party aggregators that we utilize for delivery, including marketplace and delivery as a service, cease or curtail their operations, fail to maintain sufficient labor force to satisfy demand, provide poor customer service, materially change fees, access or visibility to our products, or give greater priority or promotions to our competitors, our reputation, business and/or growth prospects may be negatively impacted. Further, we face the risk that these third-party delivery aggregators do not comply with existing regulations governing fair labor practices, which increases the risk of negative publicity for us, our franchisees and our restaurant brands. In addition, third-party delivery services typically charge restaurants a per order fee, and as such utilizing third-party delivery services may not be as profitable as sales directly to our customers, and may also introduce food quality and customer satisfaction risks outside of our control. These digital ordering and payment platforms also could be damaged or interrupted by power loss, technological failures, user errors, cyber-attacks, other forms of sabotage, inclement weather or natural disasters and have experienced interruptions and could experience further interruptions, which could limit or delay customers’ ability to order through such platforms or make customers less inclined to return to such platforms. The rapid acceleration in growth of digital sales has placed additional stress on those platforms, which may result in more frequent and potentially more severe interruptions.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Business
Subsubsection Title: Consumers’ increasing focus on environmental factors in their consumption choices may have an impact on the offering of the brands in our portfolio, which may have an impact on our business and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: In addition to their increasing focus on health-conscious dining choices, consumers are also increasingly concerned with consuming food with low impact on the environment. We have observed a heightened awareness around the environmental impact of food and a corresponding shift toward more sustainable and plant-based dietary choices. This risk is heightened in the case of certain of the brands within our portfolio, such as Burger King, Hippopotamus and Au Bureau, whose menus tend to include a large number of animal products and whose brand images are associated with beef options. We have in recent years invested in the development and roll-out of menu options that offer alternatives to animal products in order to cater to these eco-conscious preferences, aiming to reduce our environmental footprint and meet customer expectations. Despite these initiatives, if we do not rapidly adapt to these changing preferences or if our competitors more adequately respond to such industry trends, we could lose customer patronage, which could impact our revenue. Our success will depend on our ability to continue to adapt our menus to these changing consumer preferences, taking into impact the carbon impact of our food sourcing, while retaining the quality and authenticity that our customers have come to expect from our brands.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Business
Subsubsection Title: If we were to violate the French or other applicable consumer protection laws, our results of operations could be adversely affected.
Subsubsection Text: Although we have implemented strict measures to protect our customers and are engaged in ongoing improvements to ensure their continuing satisfaction with our services, it is possible that in the course of their daily interactions with our customers we may violate or fail to comply with the provisions contained in applicable French consumer protection laws. In the event of non-compliance with such laws, legal action may be commenced against or penalties may be imposed on us ranging from administrative fines to the closure of our units, any of which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Business
Subsubsection Title: Increasing scrutiny and changing expectations from stakeholders with respect to our environmental, social and governance practices may impose additional costs on us or expose us to new or additional risks.
Subsubsection Text: Companies across all industries are facing increased scrutiny from stakeholders related to their ESG practices. Investor advocacy groups, certain institutional investors, investment funds, other influential investors, lenders and other market participants are also increasingly focused on ESG practices and in recent years have placed 44 ----- increasing importance on the implications and social cost of their investments and consumer choices. Regardless of the industry, investors’ increased focus related to ESG and similar matters may hinder access to capital, as investors may decide to reallocate capital or to not commit capital as a result of their assessment of a company’s ESG practices. Companies which do not adapt to or comply with investor or other stakeholder expectations and standards, which are evolving, or which are perceived to have not responded appropriately to the growing concern for ESG issues, regardless of whether there is a legal requirement to do so, may suffer from reputational damage and the business, financial condition, and/or stock price of such a company could be materially and adversely affected. Notably, the ESG regulations to which we are subject are rapidly evolving. See “—We are subject to _health, safety and environmental regulations, which could result in increased costs and fines, as well as the potential for damage to our reputation.”_ We have adopted certain practices and policies to align our ESG approach with our strategy in order to deliver long-term social, environmental and economic values across our business. See “Business—ESG & Sustainability.” While we have in place robust ESG processes for most of our brands, our ESG procedures are still in the process of development and implementation for certain of our more recently acquired brands. We have developed internal processes to track, aggregate and disclose our ESG procedures and standards, however such processes require significant management time and attention. Even though many of the ESG procedures we have in place are robust, comply with market expectations and in certain cases go beyond legal requirements, if we do not adequately disclose our ESG procedures, we may be perceived to not have responded appropriately to the growing concern for ESG issues. Further, our stakeholders may look to us to implement more or different ESG procedures, standards or goals in order to continue engaging with us, to remain invested in us, or before they make further investments in us. We may also face increasing pressures from investors, lenders and other market participants, who are increasingly focused on climate change, to prioritize sustainable energy practices, reduce our carbon footprint and promote sustainability. We are also subject to evolving environmental regulations, the implementation of which may be costly and time-consuming. See “We are subject to health, safety and _environmental regulations, which could result in increased costs and fines, as well as the potential for damage to our reputation”. As a result, we may be required to implement more stringent ESG procedures or standards so_ that our existing and future investors and lenders remain invested in us and make further investments in us. Additionally, we may face reputational challenges in the event our ESG procedures or standards do not meet the standards set by certain constituencies or such constituencies might not be satisfied with our efforts or the speed of adoption of ESG practices or polices. If we do not meet our stakeholders’ expectations or we are not effective in addressing social and environmental responsibility matters or achieving relevant sustainability goals, trust in our brand may suffer and our business and/or our ability to access capital could be harmed. These limitations in both the debt and equity capital markets may affect our ability to grow as our plans for growth may include accessing such capital markets. If those markets are unavailable, or if we are unable to access alternative means of financing on acceptable terms, or at all, we may be unable to implement our business strategy, which would have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations and may also impair our ability to service our indebtedness. Further, it is likely that we will incur additional costs and require additional resources to monitor, report and comply with wide-ranging ESG requirements. Concurrently with the Offering, on the Issue Date we plan to enter into the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, which will be a sustainability-linked financing. As a result, we will be required to maintain our sustainability targets in order to benefit from the pricing benefit associated with the sustainability-linked feature of the facility. Any failure to adhere to such targets could result in the payment of maximum amounts set forth under the terms of the financing. The occurrence of any of the foregoing could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Business
Subsubsection Title: We may be unable to obtain suitable locations for new restaurants and the quality of the locations of the current restaurants in our portfolio may decline.
Subsubsection Text: The success of our restaurant brands depends in large part on the locations of their restaurants. As demographic and economic patterns change, current locations may not continue to be attractive or profitable. Possible declines in neighborhoods where such restaurants are located or adverse economic conditions in areas surrounding those neighborhoods could result in reduced revenue in those locations, which could have an impact on franchisee royalties and our margins. In addition, opening new restaurants that adapt to the customer preferences of our restaurant brands may present additional costs and challenges. For example, drive-through restaurants for 45 ----- restaurant brands operating in the QSR space, such as our Burger King brand, may require sites with specific characteristics and there are a limited number of suitable sites available in our geographic market. Desirable locations for new restaurant openings or for the relocation of existing restaurants may not be available at an acceptable cost when we identify a particular opportunity for a new restaurant or relocation and we may face competition from other restaurant chains for the same or nearby locations. We may also relocate or open restaurants in new areas in anticipation of future development which ultimately does not materialize. In addition, if a franchisor under a Pure Franchise agreement terminates its relationship with us, ceasing restaurant operations in a desirable location, we may be required to find another replacement location, which may happen quickly or at all. Further, an increasing number of local authorities mandate certain environmental requirements in connection with the opening of new restaurants in their communities, including monitoring carbon impact and an assessment of impact on biodiversity. As a result, building permits for new restaurant sites may be more difficult to obtain or may require us to comply with new local requirements, which may be costly. The confluence of several factors as, the limited availability of suitable land, regulatory hurdles, local authority reluctance, and intense competition for prime locations, can significantly impact our ability to maintain and expand our restaurant footprint. The occurrence of one or more of these events could adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Business
Subsubsection Title: Our success is linked to our founder.
Subsubsection Text: Mr. Olivier Bertrand, our founder, has been closely associated with our image since our inception. We believe that under the guidance of Mr. Olivier Bertrand, the Group has significantly transformed the franchise restaurant industry in France by developing existing brands and tremendously increasing their presence throughout the entire French territory. Historically, Mr. Olivier Bertrand has played a key role in our development and communication, positioning us as one of the leaders in the franchise food restaurant sector. Mr. Olivier Bertrand has been instrumental in ensuring that the brands in our portfolio are perceived as leaders in France. Considering the pivotal role Mr. Olivier Bertrand plays in the Group and his status as a well-known public figure, his departure from the Group for any reason, or any damage to his personal reputation, could materially adversely affect our reputation, brand awareness, business, operational results, financial condition and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Franchisees
Subsubsection Title: We are dependent on attracting and retaining qualified and motivated franchisees to operate our brand restaurants and on maintaining good relationships with our franchisees once they have joined our network.
Subsubsection Text: As of March 31, 2024, approximately 83% of the restaurant in our portfolio were Franchise Restaurants. We aim to accelerate the development of our franchise network, particularly across our casual dining brand portfolio, featuring the Au Bureau, Hippopotamus, Léon, Pitaya and Volfoni brands, as a result of which we expect the overall proportion of our Franchise Restaurants in our network to increase. As a food service franchisor, our business relies on the revenue generated from our Franchise Restaurants, which consists of brand royalties, advertising contributions and, in the case of Franchise with Lease Management agreements, lease management fees, each calculated on the basis of a percentage of SWS. Consequently, our results of operations depends substantially upon our franchisees’ sales volumes, which in turn depends on recruiting and retaining qualified and motivated franchisees who play a crucial role in integrating our strategic initiatives and delivering the consistent quality and service that customers expect from our restaurant brands. The process of identifying individuals with the right blend of business acumen, commitment and financial resources is challenging and competitive. Once franchisees are part of our network, maintaining good relationships is paramount, particularly as our business strategy entails attracting high quality franchisees willing to open multibrand restaurants. These relationships are built on trust, support, and mutual benefit, and any breakdown can lead to operational issues, brand damage, and legal disputes. Franchisees who become dissatisfied may not only leave 46 ----- the network, affecting our expansion and revenue, but also potentially erode the brand’s reputation through negative word-of-mouth or public disputes. Franchisees may also choose to terminate their relationship with us in favor of operating competitors’ restaurant brands, which could result in our loss of local market share. As our franchisees benefit from our know-how and expertise, competition from former franchisees may undermine our competitive advantage. The support of our franchisees is important for the success of our promotional activities and the strategic initiatives that we seek to undertake, and the successful execution of these initiatives will depend on our ability to maintain alignment with our franchisees. While we can generally mandate certain strategic initiatives through enforcement of our franchise agreements, we need the active support, as well as the managerial competence and, in certain cases, the financial ability, of our franchisees if the implementation of these initiatives is to be successful. If a significant number of our franchisees are unwilling or unable to participate in the implementation of strategies that we believe are necessary to promote further growth, our business, results of operations and financial condition could be adversely affected.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Franchisees
Subsubsection Title: Our inability to control our franchisees may reduce our influence over their operations and limit our ability to implement our strategic initiatives, which could adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: Our results of operations are dependent on our franchisees’ sales volumes and their successful implementation of our business strategy. Our franchisees are independent operators and, while we can mandate certain operational standards and procedures through the enforcement of our franchise agreements, we may not be able to quickly respond to franchisees that do not uphold these standards. Further, we cannot control many of the factors that impact the traffic in their restaurants, which directly affect sales generated in their restaurants, which in turn impacts our revenues, which are generated as a percentage of their restaurant sales. Although we provide support and know-how to our franchisees, including brand management, supply chain and procurement support and synergistic promotion of omni-channel capabilities, as well as operational quality control audits for our franchisees operating Burger King brand restaurants, we cannot guarantee the performance of franchisee restaurants in line with the standards we set and that our model will be successfully implemented in their individual restaurants. We depend on our franchisees to provide high-quality and consistent service in order to maintain the value of our restaurant brands, however we are at the risk that they fail to abide by the standards we set. Franchisees may be less directly interested in preserving or enhancing our brands and reputation than we are and may operate their restaurants in a manner inconsistent with our standards and requirements, such as the cleanliness, service or quality standards set forth in our franchise agreements and manuals, or standards set by governmental laws and regulations. Further, while we provide our franchisees with specific pricing recommendations for menu items, they are not obliged to follow these recommendations and may implement their own prices, which can have an impact on the price perception of our brands. In addition, franchisees may fail to adequately hire and train qualified managers and other restaurant personnel, which could have an impact on the quality of their offerings and customer experience. We also cannot prevent our franchisees from incurring indebtedness or conducting other businesses that could adversely affect their financial viability, nor can we control many other factors that impact the profitability of our franchise restaurants. While we ultimately can terminate franchisees that do not comply with the terms and conditions of our franchise agreements, our brand and reputation may nonetheless suffer and our franchise business, results of operations and financial condition could be adversely affected.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Franchisees
Subsubsection Title: Our franchisees may challenge the terms of their franchise agreements, may not be unwilling or unable to renew their franchise agreements with us or may be unwilling or unable to expand their franchise agreements to cover new brands in our portfolio.
Subsubsection Text: We enter into two types of agreements with our franchisees: franchise with lease management agreements (“Franchise with Lease Management”) and traditional franchise agreements (“Pure Franchise”). For a detailed 47 ----- description of each of these agreements, see “Business—Our Operating Models—Franchise Restaurants.” As of the year ended December 31, 2023, 53% of our franchise arrangements were Pure Franchise, while the remaining 47% were Franchise with Lease Management arrangements. These agreements have a typical duration of nine years (renewable under certain conditions) for Franchise with Lease Management and ten years (renewable under certain conditions) for Pure Franchise. Our franchisees who have entered into such agreements to operate one or several restaurants may be unwilling or unable to renew their franchise agreements with us for a number of reasons, including low sales volumes, high rental costs, lack of profitability, dissatisfaction with our services or a desire to retire. If our franchisees under our Franchise with Lease Management arrangements cannot, or decide not to, renew their franchise agreements with us, we will have to find a replacement franchisee to operate their restaurants or otherwise operate them as company restaurants. If a substantial number of franchises are not renewed, we may lose a significant amount of revenue, as a result of which our business, results of operations and financial condition could be adversely affected. With respect to our Pure Franchise arrangements, our franchisees either own or directly lease the building in which they operate their restaurants. To the extent that franchisees under our Pure Franchise model decide to terminate their relationship with us, we will lose our ability to operate in that restaurant location, which can cause a significant impact in the case of restaurants that are located in key desirable strategic locations.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Franchisees
Subsubsection Title: Our results of operations depend on the implementation of our business strategy and effectiveness with respect to our marketing and advertising program, which in turn requires the support of our franchisees for its success.
Subsubsection Text: Our success is heavily influenced both by the brand marketing and advertising of our individual restaurant brands. We rely on our franchisees to integrate our advertising and marketing initiatives, as well as to fund the budgets of such initiatives based on a percentage of their sales. A key element of our business strategy involves the development of innovative brand marketing and advertising, tailored to each of the restaurant brands in our portfolio. As part of this process, we identify the key target market for each brand and develop unique marketing campaigns across different channels and platforms to strengthen customer engagement. If our marketing and advertising programs are not successful, if our competitors increase spending on advertising and promotion or if our marketing and advertising programs happen to coincide with a larger marketing and advertising program from one or more of our competitors thereby, rendering our advertising program less visible or effective, we may not be able to attract new customers and retain existing customers for our restaurant brands, as a result of which our results of operations and financial condition could be adversely affected. Further, the marketing and advertising programs that we develop for the Burger King brand must be approved by BKC, the owner of the Burger King brand. If BKC does not approve our market and advertising programs, we may have to develop replacement programs, which could involve additional significant costs and delay the implementation of our marketing and advertising programs. Our franchisees under both our franchise models contribute to the relevant advertising fund associated with the brand under which they operate based on a percentage of their gross sales (with such percentage varying per restaurant brand). As a result, our advertising fund expenditures per brand depend on sales volumes at the restaurants across our portfolio operating under such brands. If such sales decline, there will be a reduced amount available for our marketing and advertising programs. Given the importance we place on advertising and marketing as a direct contributor to our success, we may have to maintain a certain level of marketing and advertising expenditure (notwithstanding any decline in sales) in order to compete and maintain our exposure in the market. In such circumstances, our margins may be diminished, which will have a negative effect on our results of operations. In addition, our margins may also be affected if the cost of mounting advertising campaigns increases. If our marketing and advertising programs are unsuccessful or are subject to an increase in cost, our business, results of operations and financial condition could be adversely affected.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Franchisees
Subsubsection Title: We rely on our franchisees to accurately report their sales as a key performance indicator and the basis on which to calculate fees owed by franchisees.
Subsubsection Text: We rely on our franchisees to accurately report their gross sales in order to evaluate the performance of restaurants across our portfolio and to calculate the fees we are entitled to collect under the terms of our franchise agreements, which include brand royalties, advertising contributions and, in the case of Franchise with Lease Management agreements, rent. Pursuant to our franchise agreements, franchisees are required to self-report certain performance 48 ----- indicators relating to their business. From time to time, franchisees may fail, intentionally or unintentionally, to accurately report their sales performance, which may result in reporting sales levels that are lower than actual sale levels generated. As a result, such franchisees may generate less revenues for us than they would have had to provide to us had they reported their actual accurate sales levels. In addition, if a material number of franchisees do not correctly report their sales, or if such reports are delayed, our overall sales numbers will not be accurate, in which could have an impact on strategic planning decisions and our ability to analyze, plan and forecast our performance may be affected. We may also have to incur significant expense to obtain compliance with such reporting requirements. Any difficulties in monitoring and overseeing our franchisees’ operations could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Franchisees
Subsubsection Title: Our relationships with franchisees are subject to regulations applicable to franchise agreements in France.
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to regulations governing the relationship between a franchisor and franchisee, which operate to prevent undue interference of a franchisor in the franchisees’ business operations, as well as regulations requiring that we provide certain information to existing and potential franchisees. For more information about regulations applicable to our franchise contracts, notably the Loi Doubin and provisions of the French Commercial Code, see “Regulation.” Any claim that we have violated regulations applicable to our relationships with franchisees, including claims that we failed to provide sufficient information or support to a franchisee or claims that we impeded the ability of a franchisee to conduct its business freely, may, among other things result in the imposition of fines on us, harm our relationships with our franchisees, require us to compensate the affected franchisees or potentially trigger claims for contract annulment on the grounds of lack of consent, negatively impact the likelihood of potential franchisees joining our networks, and have a material adverse effect on our reputation, business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects. Additionally, under French franchise law, franchisees are independent entrepreneurs who have freely entered into franchise contracts with a franchisor to use our brand names and know-how in exchange for payment of certain fees and royalties. Although we are not responsible for the employees hired by our franchisees, any change in the relevant laws or re-characterization of the employment relationships between our franchisees and/or their employees by a court or tribunal could oblige us to either hire such employees directly or make arrangements causing us to incur liabilities related to contributions to certain social security programs, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects. Further, regulations pertaining to our relationships with our franchisees are subject to change. New regulations may be introduced in the future or be amended. We may face high costs in implementing processes for continued compliance with such evolving regulations.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Expansion
Subsubsection Title: Our future prospects depend on our ability to successfully implement our business and restaurant brand expansion strategy, but we may not be able to successfully pursue acquisitions, develop or open new brand restaurants or attract new franchisees to operate new restaurants.
Subsubsection Text: Our future performance is dependent on our ability to identify, develop and execute our business strategy. Our growth strategy is based on the sustained performance and expansion of our restaurant brand network, both through growth of the existing restaurants of the brands in our portfolio, as well as the introduction and integration of additional new restaurant brands within our network. As part of this growth strategy, we will continue to seek franchisees to operate new restaurants in France, both under existing and newly acquired or developed restaurant brands, and potentially abroad. We believe that our ability to recruit, train, retain and contract with qualified franchisees will be increasingly important to our operations as we expand. However, there is no assurance that we will be able to attract new franchisees, which will affect our ability to implement our growth strategy. In addition, while we apply stringent criteria when selecting new franchisees, such as previous experience in the business and access to financial resources, there is no assurance that the franchisee will be successful. 49 ----- Developing and opening restaurants involve substantial risks, including the following: - the availability of suitable locations and competition for such locations for potential development sites, the negotiation of acceptable lease terms, and delays in obtaining construction permits, clearing potential pre-construction regulatory requirements and in completion of construction; - the impact of local tax, zoning, land use and environmental rules and regulations on our ability and the ability of our franchisees to develop restaurants, and the impact of any material difficulties or failures that we and our franchisees experience in obtaining the necessary licenses and approvals for new restaurants; - changes in governmental rules, regulations and interpretations; - the availability of financing, at acceptable rates and terms, to both franchisees and third-party landlords, for restaurant development; - employing and training qualified personnel; - securing acceptable suppliers; - developed properties not achieving desired revenue or cash flow levels once opened; and - general economic and business conditions. There is no assurance that we will be able to successfully open new restaurants or that such restaurants will generate strong sales or profits. Delays in the scheduled opening of new restaurants, due to construction hold-ups or other unforeseen issues, pose a significant risk to our expansion plans and financial forecasts. These interruptions can lead to increased costs, missed opportunities, and a delay in revenue generation, impacting our overall business momentum. Further, new restaurants may be located in areas where we have little or no meaningful operating experience and, in such instances, we typically have to rely on the expertise and local knowledge of our local partners. Such markets may have different competitive conditions, consumer tastes and discretionary spending patterns than our existing markets, which may cause our new restaurants to be less successful than restaurants in our existing markets or to incur losses. Our growth strategy also contemplates network growth through the acquisition or development of new restaurant brands, including internationally. We cannot guarantee that we will be able to adequately select the optimal location for such new restaurants based on target market, consumer preference and regional discretionary spending patterns as we begin to integrate new restaurants and brand concepts into our network, the performance of which will need to be monitored. Failure to properly deploy and utilize capital and other resources in furtherance of our identified strategy may negatively affect our planned activities. Given the various risks to which we are exposed and the uncertainties inherent in our business, we cannot guarantee the successful execution of our business and growth strategy. Additionally, the implementation of our strategy may put operational strain on our business and consume management time and focus to the detriment of our existing business operations. If we do not meet our strategic objectives or achieve the results initially expected, we may be unable to recover our investment, which may otherwise have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. 50 -----

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Expansion
Subsubsection Title: The introduction of a new restaurant brand in our portfolio may not achieve anticipated synergies or other expected benefits, or we may underestimate the costs related to the implementation of such synergies or cost savings.
Subsubsection Text: We intend to continue to grow our restaurant brand portfolio, both by potentially acquiring existing restaurant brands and integrating them into our network or by organically developing and growing new brand concepts. We have in the past acquired companies or businesses, such as our acquisition of the Pitaya restaurant network in 2022, the Léon restaurant network in 2019, the Hippopotamus restaurant network in 2017 and the QSR restaurant Quick’s network in 2015 (which we converted into Burger King restaurants), and may in the future strategically evaluate and pursue other acquisitions. Acquisitions involve numerous risks, any of which could harm our business, including difficulties in integrating operations, existing contracts and personnel of an acquired restaurant network; difficulties in supporting and transitioning supply chains to our existing pre-approved supplier network; diversion of financial and management resources from existing operations or alternative acquisition or growth opportunities; failure to realize the anticipated benefits or synergies of a transaction; failure to identify all the problems, liabilities or other shortcomings of an acquired restaurant brand, including issues related to intellectual property, regulatory compliance practices, revenue recognition or other accounting practices; risks of entering new markets in which we have limited or no experience; potential loss of key employees or vendors; or inability to generate sufficient revenues to offset acquisition costs, among others. In our evaluation of our recent and potential acquisitions, assumptions are made as to our ability to increase sales as well as improve restaurant-level profitability particularly in the areas of food, labor and cash controls as well as other operating expenses. If we are not able to make such improvements in these operational areas as planned, the acquired restaurants’ targeted profitability levels will be affected which could cause an adverse effect on our overall financial results and financial condition. Further, our growth plans include the organic creation and development of new brand concepts. This process involves significant development expenditures, which may not yield the results we anticipate achieving within a certain time, or at all. Any misjudgments in developing such brands (such as misjudging consumer preferences, target market, brand positioning or preferred consumption channels) or flaws in our execution could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. We cannot guarantee that the integration of new restaurant brands in our portfolio will generate the expected synergies and cost-saving benefits that contribute to our overall business strategy. There is a risk that these anticipated advantages may not materialize as expected or at all. The complexities of integrating a new restaurant brand into our existing network can lead to underestimating the costs and resources required. The process of integrating operations could cause an interruption of, or loss of momentum in, the activities of our business and the loss of key personnel. The diversion of management’s attention and any delays or difficulties encountered in connection with the acquisition of restaurant brands and integration of acquired restaurants brand operations could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations and financial condition. Further, the successful integration and growth of new restaurant concepts will depend on our ability to identify and enter into franchise agreements with high quality and motivated franchisees who are willing and able to execute our vision for such new concepts, which may evolve in early stages as the market performance of such restaurant brands is evaluated. If the integration process fails to deliver the projected synergies or if the costs of achieving these benefits are higher than anticipated, our financial performance and strategic positioning could be adversely affected. We may from time to time pursue disposals or cease operating certain brands, which involve numerous risks that could have an adverse impact on our business. Periodically, we may engage in the disposal of certain assets of our business or cease operating restaurant brand concepts that no longer help meet our objectives, which carries inherent risks. These disposals could lead to operational disruptions, loss of revenue and unanticipated costs or liabilities that may negatively affect our business continuity and financial health. The success of any disposal depends on market interest for the assets or business sold and our and our franchisees’ ability to maintain optimal management of operations during the transition phrase. Even following a successful disposal, we face the risk of potential claims by former franchisees or by purchasers of such assets or restaurant brands. Impairment charges are possible due to the nature and timing of decisions we make about underperforming assets or markets, or if previously opened or acquired restaurants perform below our expectations. This could result in a decrease in our reported asset value and reduction in our 51 ----- net income. These and other risks relating to disposals could cause use not to realize the anticipated benefits from such transactions, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Expansion
Subsubsection Title: Our strategy to expand internationally throughout Europe presents a number of risks and may not be successful.
Subsubsection Text: Our long-term strategy involves expanding our franchise operations outside of France to other countries throughout Europe. This execution of this strategy exposes us to numerous risks that could impede our success in new markets. Any future international operations could be negatively impacted by volatility and instability in international economic, political, security or health conditions in the countries in which we eventually operate, especially in emerging markets. Navigating different regulatory environments, cultural nuances and consumer preferences requires precise execution and adaptability. Missteps in understanding and adapting to these factors can lead to underperformance or failure of new international locations. Additionally, the complexities of establishing supply chains, recruiting local franchisee partners and talent to operate restaurants and managing operational logistics across borders add layers of challenge that could compromise our expansion efforts. If our international growth initiatives do not yield the anticipated results, this could adversely affect our overall business performance and strategic objectives. We may face limited availability for restaurant locations, higher location costs and difficulties in franchisee selection and financing. We may eventually be subject to difficulties in sourcing and importing high-quality ingredients (and ensuring food safety) in a cost-effective manner, hiring and retaining qualified team members, marketing effectively and adequately investing in information technology, especially in emerging markets.

Subsection Title: Additional General Business Risks
Subsubsection Title: Our revenue and cash flows fluctuate seasonally and are affected by public holidays and weather conditions.
Subsubsection Text: Our revenue and cash flows are subject to seasonal fluctuations influenced by public holidays and varying weather conditions. These factors can influence footfall in our restaurant locations, which are typically higher during school holidays. Consumer consumption behavior and spending patterns are also influenced by weather conditions. Persistent rain, snow or other inclement weather, particularly during the summer months, over our peak trading periods or over weekends, adversely affects us. Certain of our restaurants, namely those with terraces or significant outdoor space, are particularly vulnerable to rain and other bad weather, as the inability to use their outdoor space prevents such restaurants from maximizing their trading capacity. Unfavorable weather conditions can also deter customers from physically dining out, opting instead for delivery service, which could come at a higher cost to us as we pay an additional fee to third-party delivery service aggregators, such as Deliveroo, Uber Eats and Just-Eat. Seasonal fluctuations also impact our inventory, working capital and liquidity levels. We must carry a significant amount of inventory before the peak selling periods, which is also reflected in our liquidity with a certain time lag due to the payment terms that we have agreed with our suppliers. If net sales during our peak trading periods are significantly lower than we expect, we may be unable to adjust our working capital in a timely fashion. Any of these events could have a material adverse effect on our business, operating results, financial condition and prospects.

Subsection Title: Additional General Business Risks
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to risks associated with leasing substantial amount of space, including future increases in occupancy costs.
Subsubsection Text: We currently lease the premises for all our Company Restaurants and Franchise with Lease Management Restaurants. Leases are generally for a fixed term between nine and twelve years and feature periodic increases based on indexation clauses. In addition, market practice for leasing commercial space in certain high value areas such as central Paris requires the payment of key money to lessors and/or the former tenant. Our ability to effectively renew our existing restaurant leases or obtain restaurant leases to open new restaurants depends on the availability of locations that meet our criteria for traffic, square footage, lease economics, demographics and other factors. We may not be able to renew our existing restaurant leases on favorable terms or 52 ----- at all, including, for example, when the landlord is able to establish statutory grounds for non-renewal or if the leases do not have the benefit of statutory or contractual rights of renewal. In addition, as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, we were forced to renegotiate certain of our leases with our landlords. This renegotiation may have an impact on our future leasing transactions moving forward as landlords who operate in the retail space may impose higher rents or new and stringent conditions that would prevent losses like those sustained as a result of pandemicrelated lease renegotiations. We typically occupy our restaurants under operating leases with terms of nine to twelve years. Any favorable rental rates that we are able to negotiate upon entering such leases in the years when there are high vacancy rates are not guaranteed to continue, and this may force us to pay higher rents once those leases expire or restaurants are closed in desirable locations. In addition, under French law, the maximum increases in rent imposed by law do not apply to leases with a term in excess of nine years. Our substantial operating lease obligations could have significant negative consequences, including: - requiring that a substantial portion of our available cash be applied to pay our rental obligations, thus reducing cash available for other purposes; - increasing our vulnerability to general adverse economic and industry conditions; - limiting our flexibility in planning for or reacting to changes in our business or in the industry in which we compete; and - limiting our ability to obtain additional financing. We intend to prioritize Franchise with Lease Management structures with our franchisees moving forward for our Burger King brand, pursuant to which we will continue to own the leasehold rights of the restaurants that they operate, relying on lease management fees as a proportion of gross sales to pay our landlords for such leasehold rights. The proportion of gross sales that we collect from our franchisees varies depending on the restaurant brand. We cannot guarantee that our franchisees will not encounter financial difficulties that could prevent them from paying such lease management fees. Further, if an existing or future Franchise with Lease Management restaurant records reduced profitability, we would collect a reduced amount of fees as lease management fees are structured as a fixed proportion of their sales. Any failure by our franchisees to pay lease management fees or to pay a reduced amount of such fees as a result of reduced sales could have a negative impact on our results of operations. Further, if any of our Company Restaurants or Franchise with Lease Management Restaurants are not profitable and we decide to close them prior to expiration of the relevant lease, we would still be liable for the fulfillment of the obligations under the lease. In the event we decide to close any underperforming restaurant, we would have to renegotiate the terms of the lease agreement with the landlord for the remainder of the term of the lease and/or potentially assign or sub-lease the premises to a third-party. For additional information regarding our real estate, see “Business—Real Estate”.

Subsection Title: Additional General Business Risks
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to a number of risks related to our employees that could adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: Our business is labor intensive and maintaining good relationships with our employees, unions and other employee representatives is crucial to our operations. As of December 31, 2023, we directly employed 5,973 full-time equivalent employees (excluding franchisees’ employees). Our human capital includes approximately 691 corporate employees that provide services to our franchisees, as well as approximately 5,282 employees for the management and operation of our Company Restaurants. Our franchisees are independent business owners that separately employ the management and personnel in the restaurants they operate, however they face similar risks related to labor and the need to maintain strong relationships with their employees. Consequently, our success depends in part on our ability to maintain good relationships with our employees. The occurrence of strikes, work stoppages or other labor disputes could materially disrupt our operations or result in a 53 ----- loss of reputation or increased wages and benefits, all of which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. In France, many of our employees are covered by national collective bargaining framework in place for the hospitality sector that contain provisions that could affect our ability to make certain business changes that impact our employees. As is the case with most companies of our size, we have ongoing disputes with certain of our former employees and may face related litigation in the future, which could affect our business, results of operations and financial condition. We also seek to manage our labor costs and its impact on our margins. In this respect, we have to continuously monitor the productivity levels of our employees by measuring a variety of productivity indicators. In addition, we seek to minimize the long-term trend toward higher wages through increases in labor efficiencies; however, we may not be successful. Any increase in the minimum wage or labor regulations or protracted renegotiations of the restaurant industry collective contract in France could also increase our labor costs. As the minimum wage increases, we may need to increase not only the wage rates of our minimum wage employees but also the wages paid to the employees at wage rates which are above the minimum wage, which will increase our costs. The extent to which we are not able to raise our prices to compensate for increases in wage rates, including increases in social benefits costs, could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations and financial condition. In addition, even if minimum wage rates do not increase, we may still be required to raise wage rates in order to compete for an adequate supply of labor. Furthermore, the successful operation of our Company Restaurants requires us to continue to attract, motivate and retain regional operational and restaurant general managers with the qualifications to succeed in our industry and the motivation to apply our core service philosophy. If we are unable to continue to recruit and retain sufficiently qualified managers or to motivate our employees to sustain high service levels, the perception of our brands could suffer and our business and our growth could be adversely affected. Qualified individuals of the requisite caliber and number needed to fill these positions are in short supply. Following the COVID-19 outbreak, we have experienced a number of additional difficulties in recruiting and retaining employees, in particular due to prospective employees’ perception of the restaurant industry as requiring long hours and difficult working conditions. The inability to recruit and retain qualified individuals may delay the planned openings of new Company Restaurants or result in high employee turnover in existing Company Restaurants, which could harm our business. While our franchisees are independent businesses, they face similar risks in locating and recruiting qualified employees, which could have an impact on the profitability of their restaurants, thus potentially reducing the revenues that we receive them. Additional labor costs could adversely affect our and our franchisees’ business, results of operations and financial condition.

Subsection Title: Additional General Business Risks
Subsubsection Title: We depend on the service of key executives, and our business and growth strategy could be materially harmed if we were to lose these executives and were unable to replace them with executives of equal experience and capabilities.
Subsubsection Text: Our success depends, in part, upon the continued services of our executive management team and our highly qualified managers to operate our business and execute our strategies. Our executives’ and managers’ knowledge of the market, our businesses and our company represents a key strength of our business model, and our experience and human capital serve as a barrier to entry to potential competitors.
