Subsubsection Title: As Adjusted Financial Information

Subsubsection Text: (a) Reflects the estimated net future contribution to our results of new contracts signed prior to December 31, 2019 that were due to commence operations prior to December 31, 2020 as if such new contracts had been fully operational on January 1, 2019 based on our estimated performance of these new contracts during twelve months once they have become fully operational, after deducting the profit contribution of contracts for which we had received notice of expiry by December 31, 2019 as if such contracts had expired on January 1, 2019. As of December 31, 2019, we estimated that new contracts signed prior to such date and due to commence operations by December 31, 2020 would have contributed an additional €12.2 million to our results during the first twelve months from becoming fully operational, as if each of these contracts had been fully operational on January 1, 2019. We have made various assumptions relating to volumes, pricing and other factors, which management believes to be reasonable. We may not realize the volumes, pricing and other factors, either in the amount or within the timeframe we currently anticipate, and the costs of achieving them may be higher than expected. In addition, we excluded the anticipated profitability of the new Berlin airport. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Market and Our _Business—Certain adjusted, underlying and pro forma consolidated financial information included in this Offering Memorandum is presented for illustrative purposes only and our actual results of operations may differ.” In the year ended_ December 31, 2019, contracts that had expired on or prior to December 31, 2019 and contracts that were due to expire by December 31, 2020 and for which we had received notice of expiration by December 31, 2019 contributed an aggregate €6.2 million to our results. (b) Reflects the estimated full-year contribution to our results by OnePark in Denmark, NCPS in Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland, Xpert Parkering in Sweden and the Security Park Group in Norway, which we acquired in May 2019, August 2019, January 2020 and December 2020, respectively, as if we had acquired all these businesses on January 1, 2019, based on their expected results in the first twelve months of ownership by us, including, in each case, the estimated impact of new business contracts signed by such entities prior to completion of each acquisition as well as the estimated synergies expected to be realized in the course of integrating such companies into our operations. We have made various assumptions relating to the performance of OnePark, NCPS, Xpert Parkering and Security Park during their full first twelve months of ownership by us as well as certain synergies that we expect to realize from these acquisitions. Our assumptions relating to the performance of new acquisitions may turn out to be incorrect and we may not realize any of the anticipated synergies in the anticipated timeframe or at all. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Market and Our Business—Certain adjusted, _underlying and pro forma consolidated financial information included in this Offering Memorandum is presented for illustrative purposes only and our actual results of operations may differ.”_ (c) Reflects the full-year effect of certain efficiency and operational excellence initiatives that we implemented during the year ended December 31, 2019 as if such initiatives had been fully operational on January 1, 2019. These initiatives include the benefits derived from the route planning optimization for our control fee operatives in Germany and Denmark, improved terms with our debt providers in Germany, Norway and Austria and centralization of cash handling services in Germany. ##### 35 -----

You should carefully consider the following risks, together with other information provided to you in this Offering Memorandum, in deciding whether to invest in the Notes. The occurrence of any of the events discussed below could materially adversely affect our business, results of operations or financial condition. If these events occur, the trading prices of the Notes could decline, and we may not be able to pay all or part of the interest or principal on the Notes, and you may lose all or part of your investment. Additional risks not currently known to us or that we now deem immaterial could also adversely affect our business, results of operations, or financial condition or our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and affect your investment. Further, to the extent that the COVID-19 pandemic adversely affects our business and results of operations, it may also have the effect of heightening many of the other risks described in this section. This Offering Memorandum contains “forward-looking” statements that involve risks and uncertainties. Our actual results may differ significantly from the results discussed in the forward- looking statements. Factors that might cause such differences include those discussed below and elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. See “Forward-Looking Statements.”_

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: The effects of the outbreak of COVID-19 have disrupted our operations, which have had and may continue to have a material negative adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects.
Subsubsection Text: The COVID-19 pandemic has had an unprecedented impact on the global economy due to the implementation of a wide variety of control measures including states of emergency, “shelter in place” orders, border closures, closures of businesses, and restrictions on commuting, local and international travel, shopping, social and recreational activities and gatherings. The COVID-19 pandemic has significantly impacted our results. The volume of traffic at our car parks is dependent on mobility, and in particular people travelling to locations such as places of employment, shopping centers, leisure facilities, hospitals, airports, offices and urban areas. Beginning in February at our facilities in Italy and across Europe at certain airports and at all our other facilities in March, our car park usage reduced drastically as a result of the restrictions on movement and other social distancing measures imposed by governments in Europe in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. For a number of weeks early in 2020 our short-term parking revenues came to a virtual standstill because people worked from home, were only allowed or advised to go out for essential or permitted purposes and most places that people tend to drive to were no longer accessible. The effect of these measures on the volume of traffic at our facilities was most severe in the period March to May 2020. Following the easing of restrictions during the second quarter of the year, customers immediately started to return to our facilities; however at most we only reached on average 80% of levels of volume of customers at our facilities in the comparable period in 2019. Travel in the countries in which we operate, however, in the second quarter of 2020 remained significantly below the levels in the comparable period in 2019. Increasing infections and hospitalizations led to the reinstatement of government restrictions from October 2020 onwards. All the countries in which we operate experienced various degrees of lockdowns which have continued in many of the countries in which we operate through the first and second quarters of 2021, which have significantly negatively impacted our revenues. The COVID-19 pandemic has subjected our business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects to a number of risks. The effects of the COVID-19 pandemic have negatively impacted, and could continue to negatively impact, our revenues and profitability. The impact of the COVID-19 pandemic made it difficult for us to satisfy liquidity requirements during 2020 due to a sharp decline in our car park usage and could continue to make it difficult for us to satisfy our debt obligations or obtain financing on favorable terms, or at all, which could generally impact our costs and our ability to increase revenue in the future. As part of our response to the COVID-19 pandemic, we reduced or postponed investments and expenses, introduced short-time working and reduced or deferred lease and rental ----- payments in agreement with landlords and partners. We took out government-guaranteed loans in Switzerland and benefited from one-off governmental subsidies from various government capital infusion programs designed to alleviate the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on businesses in the jurisdictions where we operate. We required an amendment to our credit facility in order to prevent a default and raised capital from our shareholders and third-party lenders. Despite the steps we have taken to assess and mitigate the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, the extent to which the COVID-19 pandemic will continue to impact our business, results of operations, financial condition or prospects is uncertain. If our business does not generate sufficient cash flows from operating activities, and financing is not otherwise available to us from borrowings under our Revolving Credit Facility or other sources, we may not be able to cover our expenses, grow our business, respond to competitive challenges or fund our other liquidity and capital needs, all of which would harm our business. The full extent of the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on our business and financial performance, including our ability to execute our near-term and long-term business strategies and initiatives in the expected time frame, will depend on future developments, including the duration and severity of the pandemic, the rollout of vaccines, continued governmental restrictions and new strains or variants of the disease against which existing vaccines might be ineffective as well as the extent of the recovery of business and economic conditions in general, all of which are uncertain and cannot be predicted. We estimate that a partial recovery of the economy may present substantial risks to our business and operations, as in that scenario occupancy levels at our facilities are likely to remain below pre-COVID-19 pandemic levels, which would negatively impact our profitability, while our ability to benefit from governmental assistance would be substantially reduced due to the likelihood of termination of COVID-19 related financial support programs and furlough schemes. In addition, in that scenario our landlords may be more reluctant to provide any relief on our lease payments. The potential effects and long-term impact of COVID-19 could intensify or otherwise affect many of the other risks set forth herein or present other unforeseen consequences for our business.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Changes in individual behavior, including in the aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic, may lead to a decline in parking demand, which could have a material adverse impact on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: New customer behavior, such as an increase in online shopping and working from home, or changes in the popularity of certain stores or locations, including as a result of permanent store, restaurant or entertainment venue closures, poses a risk of a decreased demand for parking facilities and may have an adverse effect on our business and revenue. Changes in customer behavior accelerated during the COVID-19 pandemic and may continue to do so in the aftermath of the pandemic as the majority of the population in the markets where we operate has progressively adapted to the restrictive measures implemented in 2020 and 2021 and has increasingly relied on alternative solutions for leisure and professional needs. Complete and partial closure of shopping centers, leisure amenities and offices and the rapid growth of online retail, grocery shopping and food delivery services during the COVID-19 shutdown have resulted in a drastic reduction of visits to city centers. The COVID-19 lockdowns may have changed shopping behavior for the long-term, and customers may purchase more products online in the future. For instance, in Germany, since the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic, trade fairs have been organized in a different set-up with fewer visitors and a substantial number of main street venues have gone out of business. Significantly decreased national and international travel, reduction in the number of flights and the closure of airports has led to the rapid development of remote working and virtual meetings solutions. Business travel is one of our most profitable business segments, and it might never fully recover because of the continued use of virtual meetings. Reduced travel will also impact hotel parking volume and may result in a decrease in parking at large events, such as sporting events and concerts. These changes in customer behavior and the emergence of alternative solutions for leisure and professional needs may be permanent or remain for the long-term, which may result in part of the parking volumes not recovering to the pre-COVID-19 levels in the long-term in each of the sectors in which we operate, which could have a materially adverse effect on our business. Reliance by customers on online services and progressive shifts by employers to flexible working solutions may continue in the aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic and may result in a decline in ##### 38 ----- parking demand in cities and urban areas as well as transportation hubs such as train stations and airports, which could have a negative impact on our business. In the twelve months ended December 31, 2019, 11.4% of our revenue was generated by contract parking, where customers have monthly or annual passes at our facilities. This has generally been a valuable, recurring portion of our revenues. If many of these customers choose to work from home full-time or even part-time, they may not park in our facilities any longer, or may not buy monthly or annual passes. Moreover, a slight decrease in the average parking time that may result from new customer behavior coupled with a lower occupancy rate of our car parks could have substantial negative impact on our revenue. We have generally relied upon the historical trends towards urbanization in developing our value-creation initiatives. However, many people are leaving cities as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic and are choosing to live in rural areas and work remotely. A material decline in the number of people living in urban areas could have a material impact on the volume of cars using our facilities. In addition, changing customer habits as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic that are long-lasting, for example less frequent or shorter shopping times, utilization of different modes of transportation and reduced in-person gatherings, may have a materially detrimental effect on our business.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: General business and economic conditions, including those caused by the COVID-19 pandemic in the markets where we operate may decrease demand for parking and may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: Our business, financial condition and results of operations are affected by general business and economic conditions in the markets in which we operate, in particular in Germany and our other larger markets. In particular, the long-term economic impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic are unknown at this time. A downturn in economic conditions resulting in high unemployment rates, reduced customer spending, increased bankruptcy filings, increased interest rates, high inflation, fluctuations in the availability or cost of funding, fluctuations in the value of currency or a decline in the strength of national and local economies in which we operate and other factors that may negatively affect our end customers’ financial prospects could affect the mobility rates of our end customers. The number of people visiting shopping centers, restaurants, offices and city centers generally declines during periods of increased inflation and economic downturn. As a result, a decline in economic conditions could lead to a decline in the volume of cars parked at our facilities.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: A large portion of our operations are carried out, and revenue is generated in Europe and Germany, in particular. Any adverse political or economic changes within these markets may have an adverse effect on our business, results of operations or financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: All of our business operations are located in Europe. Our business in Germany accounted for approximately 33% of our Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution in the financial year ended December 31, 2019. In light of this concentration, our business is sensitive to political or economic developments that effect Europe and Germany in particular. Concerns regarding the debt burden of certain European countries and their ability to meet future financial obligations, the overall stability of the euro and the suitability of the euro as a single currency given the diverse economic and political circumstances in individual member states of the EU could have an outsized adverse effect on our business, results of operations or financial condition.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Customer driven changes in transportation habits may result in a reduction in cars parked at our facilities.
Subsubsection Text: Changes in the transportation industry could have a negative impact on our business, such as increased use of public transport by end customers and car sharing. The increased use of ride sharing services and alternative public or private transport providers, and the development of autonomous vehicles, are two trends that are particularly pronounced in larger cities. Such trends may lead to a decline in parking demand in cities and urban areas as well as in transportation hubs, such as train stations and airports. The increase in the accessibility of transportation hubs by alternative public or private transport providers such as trains, shuttles and ride sharing services may lead to a decreased need for car parks. Car share programs reduce the need for parking spots as multiple motorists can share a single vehicle. ##### 39 ----- Further development of pedestrian or bike pathways and general green initiatives like congestion charges which are meant to reduce automobile traffic in urban areas could reduce customers at our car parks. While we devote considerable effort and resources to analyzing and responding to customer preferences and changes to customer preferences in the markets in which we operate, customer preferences cannot be predicted with certainty and can change rapidly. We have invested in positioning ourselves to benefit from trends such as experience shopping and urbanization, but these trends may turn out to be less resilient than expected or even may reverse.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Significant competition in our markets may adversely affect customers’ desire to park at our facilities.
Subsubsection Text: The parking industry is highly competitive. We believe that customer choice regarding parking is driven partly by price but also by factors such as location, lighting and security and the ease of parking in particular as a result of payment apps. Some of our competitors may have greater financial, marketing and other resources available than us. For example, some of our key competitors include Empark and Q-Park, each of which has substantial financial, marketing and other resources and established brand names. Our competitors could use their significant resources to increase their marketing, develop new services or technology or reduce their prices in a manner that adversely impacts our ability to charge prices that generate the same margins we have earned in the past, or at all. We cannot assure you that we will continue to be able to compete successfully against existing or future competitors. Furthermore, new technology and processes could negatively impact our existing business. For example, continued use of digital technology to operate parking facilities might diminish the need for physical controls by our parking officers and therefore the need for certain of our services. In addition, we currently generate a significant percentage of our revenue from consumers who fail to pay their invoices on time or at all (i.e., through late fees and related administration fees), which may decrease as more advance parking technology becomes available. Furthermore, increased use of technology could also lead to new competitors providing parking services, pushing us towards the role of a facility manager with reduced spread in the business, which could make our large number of parking facility locations less valuable, reduce our bargaining powers with our clients and reducing our margins. We also compete with certain property owners and businesses that operate their own parking facilities. Such entities may be able to charge lower prices than us because they are seeking to generate revenue through products sold in their stores, as opposed to parking revenue.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Changes in environmental and traffic control regulations could reduce demand for, and volumes in, our off-street parking facilities that could adversely affect our business, results of operations or financial conditions.
Subsubsection Text: National or local governments could implement measures which are potentially unfavorable to the parking sector as a result of pressure from public opinion, advocacy groups, or election results. For example, proposals relating to limiting traffic within city boundaries or the introduction of bans on driving of diesel vehicles in certain cities could adversely affect inner-city parking, resulting in lower revenue and diminished profitability. As an example, a number of car parking spaces in Copenhagen are expected to be converted to flexible parking spaces for both bicycles and cars. The local authority in Copenhagen also introduced the “Cyclist Priority Plan for 2017-2025,” which seeks to encourage 50% of commuting journeys to be completed by bicycle. In addition, certain of the cities in which we operate have introduced dedicated bike lanes in response to changes in traffic patterns and to tackle environmental concerns. Such initiatives are likely to continue in the future. Governments will likely continue to implement further measures aimed at reducing car traffic and availability of parking spaces, additional regulation to provide free parking for staff, patients and visitors at hospitals and other public places, and regulation with respect to the amount of permitted fines and surcharges that we may charge, thereby affecting our income. Some municipalities may impose traffic congestion charges in urban areas, reduce the availability of on-street parking spaces or promote the use of public transportation in lieu of automobiles. In addition, certain municipalities may measure and charge for curb time parking, which could encourage courier and package delivery services to use transportation methods other than cars. Governments may also ##### 40 ----- increase the tax levels on automobiles and petroleum for environmental reasons, which may reduce traffic. Social perception and pressure relating to environmental concerns over the use of private cars may similarly adversely impact the demand for our facilities. In addition, municipalities may promote environmentally-friendly initiatives by reducing the number of parking spaces and encourage the use of public transport for attendees of large public events and gatherings, trade fairs and transportation hubs. Furthermore, the government in certain cities may reduce the parking tariffs of their parking facilities in order to compete with other cities and private companies. We may also be materially adversely affected by temporary or permanent changes to traffic routes or road closures, which may make it more difficult to access our parking facilities and have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations or financial condition. In addition, during the COVID-19 pandemic, certain municipalities in Austria and Italy also imposed “free parking” to accelerate the recovery of inner-cities or to support essential workers. If these free parking arrangements were to be extended or expanded, our results of operations could be affected.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We have a large amount of fixed costs, and if we experience a decrease in our revenue, our operating expenses and rent payments will not decrease at the same rate, which could have a material adverse effect on our net cash flows, margins and profits.
Subsubsection Text: Many of the expenses associated with operating parking facilities are relatively fixed. These expenses include a large portion of our rent expenses, personnel costs, information technology costs, maintenance and repair and cleaning costs, insurance and utilities. If we are unable to decrease our costs significantly or rapidly when demand for our parking spaces decreases, the decline in our revenue can have a particularly adverse effect on our net cash flows and profits. This effect can be especially pronounced during periods of economic contraction or slow economic growth. Where cost cutting efforts are insufficient to offset declines in revenue, in particular in respect of our leased car parking facilities, we could experience a material decline in margins and potentially negative cash flows which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations or financial condition. We may also be unable to terminate on short notice or renegotiate unprofitable or disadvantageous leases or management contracts. In addition, we may be required to honor our contractual lease provisions or possibly pay considerable amounts in compensation or damages. Furthermore, our auditors may require us to book onerous contract provisions in relation to unprofitable or disadvantageous leases or management contracts, which may significantly increase our operating loss. These lease agreements may negatively impact our profitability, and may have significant adverse effects on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Furthermore, we may be required to recognize unprofitable or disadvantageous leases or management contracts as onerous contracts under IAS 37 and record a provision in our financial statements for the loss we expect to make on such contracts. This may negatively impact our EBITDA and our leverage ratios under the restrictive debt covenants to which we will be subject and consequently limit our ability to finance our future operations and capital needs and to pursue business opportunities and activities. See “—We will be subject to restrictive debt covenants that may limit our ability to finance our future _operations and capital needs and to pursue business opportunities and activities.”_

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to competition that can constrain our ability to acquire new parking facilities, and win and renew parking lease contracts, concessions and management contracts for parking services.
Subsubsection Text: The parking sector in Europe is a competitive market, with a variety of competitors ranging from local single-facility operators to regional, national and international operators with a significant number of parking spaces. While the largest owners and operators in the industry are municipalities, other large competitors include divisions of diversified global corporations with substantial financial, management and other resources and capabilities. In Western Europe, many long-term parking lease contracts and management contracts for parking facilities are awarded and renewed through competitive tenders. A significant number of competing entities may bid on a parking facility tender. Generally, public tenders for on- and off-street leases and ##### 41 ----- off-street management contracts are competitive and primarily determined based on economic terms. Some of our competitors or new entrants to the market may be able to bid at lower prices, or offer additional incentives such as upgrades to the facility. They may be able to realize synergies or operate the facility in as part of a cluster, which would allow them to charge higher parking tariffs. We also may underestimate our cost to run a new facility, or we may overestimate the amount of volume that a new facility will generate, and our bid may contemplate rental or operating costs that are too high for the applicable facility to support. In such a case a facility may turn out to be unprofitable because we are paying too much in rent or are generating too little in management fees. In such a situation, that facility will negatively impact our margins and EBITDA. In addition, certain landlords, including municipalities, may choose not to retender a car park once it has expired, but rather in-source and operate the car parks themselves. This decision on the part of the landlord can result in a loss of revenue or the loss of opportunity to tender for a competitor’s former lease and increased competition for other car parks. As a result of such competition we may not be able to win new tenders or renew tenders on commercially favorable terms or at all, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations or financial condition.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Tenders may be subject to modification or interpretation by the granting party and awards of tenders may be challenged by third parties.
Subsubsection Text: The municipalities and large companies who award parking tenders are entitled to interpret the tender contract, resolve any doubt regarding execution, modify it for reason of public interest, terminate it early and determine the effects of such termination. The awarding party may contractually modify a tender agreement for public interest reasons that may affect the terms of the service provision or the price of tariffs paid by users. Additionally, unsuccessful bidders may challenge the decision of an awarding authority before the courts. Any decision adopted by a granting authority with respect to a competitive bidding process may be challenged be a third party provided this party has a legitimate interest in the result of the annulment of such decision. There can be no assurance that our right to contracts we have won through a competitive bidding process will be upheld. The modification of such agreements by the granting authority, delays caused by claims brought by unsuccessful bidders and cancellation or rescission by a court of our tender agreements could have significant adverse effects on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our lease contracts and management contracts have limited durations and are subject to termination by the contracting counterparty under the various terms and conditions.
Subsubsection Text: Our leases and management contracts are typically long-term arrangements with an average remaining life for our top 100 contracts (based on weighted average Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution for the year ended December 31, 2019) of approximately 12 years. Of our top 20 contracts by Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution, only four are up for renewal by the end of 2026, representing approximately 3.9% of our Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution for the year ended December 31, 2019. There may be significant competition to renew existing leases or management contracts. This risk is more pronounced where the contract is with a public authority and where a bidding process is required as opposed to with a private landlord where we can initiate bilateral discussions ahead of upcoming lease expirations. Approximately 33% of our revenue in 2019 was with public or quasi-public authorities versus with private landlords. The loss of, or the renewal on less commercially favorable terms of, a significant number of our existing facilities, or one or more of our largest facilities, could materially adversely affect our business, results of operations or financial condition. We are also subject to the termination rights set forth in the terms and conditions in our agreements. For example, in some of our contracts, a change in our shareholders may trigger the counterparty’s right to terminate the lease or management contract. A counterparty may also seek to terminate if we are not meeting our contractual requirements under the contract, such as maintenance obligations. The early termination by the relevant authorities of one or more of our lease or management contracts could materially adversely affect our business, results of operations or financial condition. ##### 42 -----

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: If we fail to stay current with developments in technology necessary for our business, our operations could be harmed and our ability to compete effectively could be diminished
Subsubsection Text: New technologies are changing the current parking market, resulting in an increased focus on information technology developments. Sophisticated information technology and other systems, including systems for the efficient collection and management of revenue are integral to our business. In order to maintain the quality of our operations, we refine, update or replace our information technology and other systems with more advanced systems on a regular basis. Motorists increasingly use mobile phone applications and online parking reservation services that allow them to reserve parking at garages, lots and directly with individual owners. As a result, we constantly develop new applications and upgrade our information technology to adapt to changing preferences, to keep up with market demand for new services and to match services offered by our competitors. For example, in 2018 we also launched our APCOA FLOW system, which is an open, digital and scalable cloud-based platform which connects most of our parking garages, including parking technology, with our customers and their vehicles via smartphone apps. This system also provides real time data on occupancy and availability of our parking facilities. Our competitors may develop more efficient or popular solutions, which could attract more customers seeking to park their cars and could affect our business, operations and revenues. Developing and maintaining our systems will require significant capital. If we are unable to introduce information technology and other systems as quickly as our competitors our ability to compete effectively could be diminished. If we are unable to replace outdated or broken systems within budgeted costs or on schedule, our operations could be harmed. Our operations could also be harmed and our ability to compete diminished if we are unable to realize the intended benefits of any new information technology or other systems. Each of these could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations or financial condition. Further, if we fail to keep up with technological advances in our industry, including advances to maintain or improve our cost-effectiveness or that add value to the services we can offer to customers, our brand may be diminished which may harm our ability to win new leases and management contracts.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our information technology systems may fail or be interrupted, which could materially adversely affect our business. In addition, cyber-attacks on our information systems and any failure to maintain the integrity of customer data could harm our reputation and subject us to costs, fines and lawsuits.
Subsubsection Text: We rely on numerous information technology systems that allow us to monitor and manage our parking spaces and facilities, control and collect fees, maintain our financial records, manage our employees and gather information which our management team uses to make decisions regarding our business, including technical information that is used formulate bids for spaces or contracts. The operation of our business is increasingly dependent on the use of these systems. As a result, system failures or disruptions resulting from computer viruses, cyber-attacks, cyber terrorism, security breaches or other causes could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations or financial condition. We also collect and retain large volumes of internal, employee and customer data, including credit card numbers, license plates and other personally identifiable information during the normal course of business. Using our various information technology systems, we collect, process, analyze and report such data. The integrity and protection of our customer, employee and company data is critical to our business. Our customers and employees expect that we will adequately protect their personal information and adhere to information security and privacy regulations. These regulations are increasingly demanding in the jurisdictions where we operate. Theft, loss, fraudulent or unlawful use of customer, employee or company data could harm our reputation and result in remedial and other costs, fines and lawsuits, which may be material. See “—We are subject to stringent data privacy laws _of each jurisdiction in which we operate and may be adversely affected by changes in the laws and regulations of each jurisdiction in which we operate and be exposed to increased compliance costs”_ ##### 43 -----

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: The rates that we can charge our parking customers may be subject to limitations set forth in the lease contract or may be limited by law.
Subsubsection Text: In certain circumstances we may be required to limit the parking tariffs we can charge to customers based on governmental regulations or contractual limitations. For example, in our contracts with municipalities or other government entities the maximum tariffs we can charge to our customers are set by the client and we are not allowed to increase such tariffs above the established limit. These restrictions may impact our profitability from our operations. If the pricing structures at facilities we operate restrict us from profitably operating our facilities and we are unable to adjust them due to contractual or regulatory limitations, we could experience a material decline in the profitability of or a loss with respect our facilities which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations or financial condition. Moreover, limitations on our ability to increase parking tariffs could negatively affect our ability to effectively address issues arising from factors that are outside of our control, such as exposure to inflation and increases in minimum or market wages. Furthermore, our business may be adversely affected if governments chose to reduce parking fees or introduce free parking to make certain locations, such as inner cities, more attractive to consumers or to support essential workers, such as at hospitals.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Changes in the legal and regulatory framework for the management and operation of parking facilities may impose significant costs on us.
Subsubsection Text: We must comply with a variety of laws and regulations relating to our leases, some of which impose substantial financial and other penalties for non-compliance. In addition, we are exposed to the risk of changes in the regulatory regime, which could potentially impose additional costs on our business or subject us to more onerous operating requirements, and thus have an adverse impact on our business, results of operations or financial condition.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: If our landlords or property owners face financial difficulties, our leases or ability to operate certain of our facilities may be adversely affected.
Subsubsection Text: If our landlords or other persons owning the properties in which our facilities are located experience financial difficulties, we may be exposed to certain risks such as poor infrastructure in the areas surrounding and servicing our parking facilities or the closure of stores or other attractions drawing customers to our facilities, thereby decreasing the demand for those parking spaces. We may be required to initiate legal proceedings to claim amounts owed under management contracts. These risks may be exacerbated by the impact of a future economic downturn in Europe and potential austerity measures imposed by the national governments or by the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. If our landlords are unable to effectively address financial difficulties they are facing or become subject to bankruptcy proceedings, we may be exposed to the risk of closure of our facilities and renegotiation or loss of our contracts. Additionally, approximately 33% of 2019 revenue was with municipalities or other public or quasipublic entities. If a municipality with which we have an agreement faces financial difficulties we may be exposed to certain risks such as poorly maintained infrastructure in the areas surrounding and servicing the relevant facilities. Furthermore, certain municipalities facing financial challenges may be reluctant or unwilling to pay compensation amounts to which we are entitled under the relevant agreements. As a result, we may be required to initiate legal proceedings. This risk would be further exacerbated by an economic downturn in Europe. If a municipality with whom we have a contract experiences financial difficulties we are still obliged to continue providing services under our long-term contracts, regardless of outstanding revenues or compensation owed, which could materially adversely affect our business, results of operations or financial condition ##### 44 -----

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Certain transfers of our leases, including indirect transfers are or may be subject to the prior approval of our counterparties to those contracts, and, under certain of our long-term contracts, insolvency proceedings or a change of control may result in the termination of the agreement.
Subsubsection Text: In certain cases, counterparties impose contractual restrictions on transfers of our rights, including change of control clauses, which prohibit the transfer of our rights without the relevant counterparties’ prior approval. Under the terms of certain of our long-term contracts and/or under applicable law, the counterparty to the contract may have the right to terminate the agreement in the event that insolvency or winding-up proceedings are instituted or, upon the occurrence of certain events, if we are in breach of our obligations under such agreements. In the event of an enforcement action under the terms of the Notes or the Guarantees that results in the transfer of ownership of the Issuer or any other Guarantor, or a change in the shareholding of the Issuer for other reasons, one or more counterparties may argue that an indirect transfer also requires their prior approval. As such, the counterparty may attempt to cancel our contract if such change of control clauses exist in the relevant contract and such approval is not sought or granted. In addition, the uncertainty concerning the transferability of such contracts itself could reduce the value placed on such contracts by third parties and ultimately reduce the amount recovered in the event of an enforcement action.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: If we are unable to maintain our reputation as a quality operator, we may be unable to win bids to renew our existing contracts or enter into new contracts, and our business, results of operations or financial condition may be materially and adversely affected.
Subsubsection Text: Since our revenue depends on cash flows from operating parking facilities under long-term contracts, it is important that we maintain good relationships with landlords and property owners in order to bid for, win and renew contracts. In addition, our reputation as a reliable operator of parking facilities is important in winning and renewing contracts. We believe the experience of our management, the quality of our reputation in the key markets in which we operate and the rapport that we maintain with landlords and property owners differentiates us from our competitors and are important factors for the generation of new business opportunities that support our growth. However, if we are unable to maintain good working relationships with the landlords and property owners, or if we do not meet or exceed their expectations, such parties may be unwilling to maintain or grow their business with us, in which case our business, results of operations or financial condition may be materially and adversely affected.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our ability to expand our business by leasing new parking facilities will be dependent upon the availability and cost of capital.
Subsubsection Text: We intend to continue to expand our business through organic growth. We typically make certain capital expenditures at newly leased sites to introduce or upgrade equipment and facilities. Our ability to expand our business will depend in part upon the availability of adequate capital, which in turn requires cash flow generated by our business and the availability of debt and equity financing. Any economic downturn, including as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic may have a negative impact on the availability of excess cash and the availability and cost of bank financing. If we are unable to obtain the funds needed on acceptable terms, we will not be able to continue to expand our operations, which could materially adversely affect our business, results of operations or financial condition.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We may not be able to successfully realize our strategy to acquire other parking facility operators.
Subsubsection Text: The off-street car parking industry in Europe is highly fragmented with a limited number of large players. Accordingly, market dynamics make it possible for large private players to acquire small competitors at attractive multiples and as such, we are focused on growing in part through acquisitions. We expect to continue to evaluate opportunities to acquire businesses that complement our operations. However, there can be no assurance that any acquisition we make in the future will deliver the anticipated benefits. In addition, the process of integrating an acquired business may create unforeseen difficulties, take longer than expected, result in the incurrence of unexpected costs and expenses or we ##### 45 ----- may not realize the synergies or operational advantages expected. The risks we face in connection with any potential acquisition of a business include, but are not limited to: - management time and focus may be diverted from operating our business to acquisition integration; - clients or key employees of an acquired business may not remain, which could negatively impact our ability to grow that acquired business; - we may face competition from management or key employees of an acquired business in case of their departure; - integration of the acquired business’s accounting, information technology, human resources, and other administrative systems may fail to permit effective management and expense reduction; - implementing internal controls, procedures, and policies appropriate for a public company in an acquired business that lacked some of these controls, procedures and policies may fail; - additional indebtedness incurred as a result of an acquisition may impact our financial position, results of operations, and cash flows; and - unanticipated or unknown operational, commercial or technical issues or liabilities may arise relating to the acquired business. If we fail to identify and enter into attractive markets, to identify and operate facilities on acceptable terms, to attract, hire and retain skilled staff, to implement the appropriate infrastructure or to raise the required funds to successfully complete acquisitions, our business plans may be jeopardized and the intended consolidation or increase of our market share may fail to materialize, which could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition or results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Certain adjusted, underlying and pro forma consolidated financial information included in this Offering Memorandum is presented for illustrative purposes only and our actual results of operations may differ.
Subsubsection Text: We have presented in this Offering Memorandum certain adjusted financial data that has been prepared to give effect to the Transactions as well as to certain other adjustments made to calculate the Pro Forma Pre-IFRS 16 Adjusted EBITDA as described in more detail under “Summary—Summary Financial and _Other Data—Pro Forma and As Adjusted Financial Information.” Such adjusted financial data has been_ prepared for illustrative purposes only and does not purport to represent what the actual consolidated financial position or financial information would have been had the Transactions or other adjustments actually occurred as of the dates indicated, nor does such adjusted financial data purport to project our consolidated financial position and financial information at any future date or for any future period. The financial information for the twelve months presented in this Offering Memorandum includes nonGAAP measures and is based on available information and certain assumptions and estimates that we believe are reasonable and may differ materially from the actual amounts. We also present Pro Forma Pre-IFRS 16 Adjusted EBITDA, which gives effect to the estimated full-year effect of certain acquisitions, contract wins or contract terminations as if each of such event had occurred on January 1, 2019, and in the case of acquisitions and contract wins, including assumptions about the performance of such acquisition or contract during the first twelve months of ownership or execution by us. Pro _Forma Pre-IFRS 16 Adjusted EBITDA is calculated on a basis of implementation that contemplates_ interest expense, depreciation and debt on a pre-IFRS 16 basis. Furthermore, Pro Forma Pre-IFRS 16 Adjusted EBITDA is calculated assuming the EBITDA achieved by the Company in 2019, rather than 2020 or the twelve months ended March 31, 2021. Because of the material adverse effects that the COVID-19 pandemic has had on our business, we do not believe EBITDA from 2020 or the twelve months ended March 31, 2021 is an accurate reflection of our long-term business going forward. ##### 46 ----- Nevertheless, we cannot give any assurance that our EBITDA or other financial results will return to the levels of 2019. The adjustments made to calculate the financial information for the twelve months of new business contract and/or company performance and to calculate _Pro Forma Pre-IFRS 16 Adjusted EBITDA are based upon available information and assumptions that we believe are reasonable in the circumstances. In particular, we have estimated the twelve months EBITDA contribution from our new business contracts and/or companies acquired by us based on available data and certain assumptions, including parking volumes and pricing, and these contracts or new companies may not be as profitable as we have anticipated. This adjusted and pro forma data has been prepared for illustrative purposes only and has not been prepared in accordance with the requirements of Regulation S-X of the U.S. Securities Act or any generally accepted accounting standards. The adjustments have not been audited by any independent auditors, should not be considered indicative of actual results that would have been achieved had the events for which we have made the adjustment been completed as the dates stated and do not purport to indicate our future consolidated results of operations or financial position. The actual results may differ significantly from those presented for a number of reasons, including, but not limited to, differences in assumptions used. In addition, the pro forma adjustments made to calculate Pro Forma Pre-IFRS 16 Adjusted EBITDA include estimated synergies that we expect to realize from the implementation of new acquisitions into our operations but exclude future events that may occur after this Offering, including the potential nonrealization of revenue synergies, cost savings, expense reductions and contribution from acquisitions or the incurrence of implementation and investment costs related to the realization of such synergies, and contribution from acquisitions or new contracts, which may be material. The pro forma adjustments made to calculate Pro Forma Pre-IFRS 16 Adjusted EBITDA also do not consider potential negative impacts of market conditions on revenue or expenses. Such actual events may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects. In addition, we may fail to realize any or all of the anticipated synergies.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Instances of theft, fraud, bribery, corruption and privacy breaches involving our management, employees, business partners or agents could expose us to penalties and reputational damage and could hinder our ability to acquire or renew contracts or even continue our operating activities.
Subsubsection Text: The decentralized nature of our operations as well as our employees’ access to the cash that we collect from our operations exposes us to potential theft and other criminal acts. For example, in 2016 one of our employees in Norway stole approximately €0.5 million in coins from parking meter change drawers over a period of approximately three years, and in the past we have had similar theft instances in other jurisdictions. While we have a compliance program and internal policies in place to mitigate the risks of theft, fraud, bribery, corruption and privacy breaches in the contract tender processes we engage in and for our business as a whole, we cannot assure that we can detect or prevent every instance of theft, fraud, bribery, corruption or breaches of privacy involving our employees, business partners or agents. We may be subject to civil and criminal penalties and to reputational damage as a result of such incidents. Instances of theft, fraud, bribery, corruption and breaches of privacy may also be taken into account as a negative factor by public authorities or private companies in evaluating our bids to acquire or renew contracts. Such incidents could result in a prohibition to tender for, or could otherwise prevent us from winning or renewing contracts, or make it more difficult for us to win or renew contracts in the future. Any involvement or association of our senior management, employees, business partners, suppliers or agents with theft, fraud, bribery, corruption and breaches of privacy, or allegations or rumors relating thereto, could negatively impact our reputation and materially adversely affect our business, results of operations or financial condition. For example, in 2018 we lost an on-street tender in Antwerp, Belgium, due to reputational issues resulting from a former fraud case in that city that was first identified in 2016, where one of our former technical directors was found guilty of large scale theft after we uncovered that he had stolen approximately €5 million in coins from parking meter change drawers over a period of at least five years, and in the past we had similar, albeit smaller, case of theft in other jurisdictions. As a result of this case, we hired third party advisors to assist us with identifying areas of risk. We have implemented several measures in order to prevent similar cases from occurring ##### 47 ----- in the future that we deem adequate and we continuously review and upgrade our compliance policies. We also have a dedicated internal audit and compliance team in place. However, we cannot guarantee that these measures will be effective in reducing such cases from happening in the future or at all. In addition, we have in place a whistleblower program, through which we have in the past received, and we may in the future receive, allegations of compliance breaches by our employees, such as for fraud, bribery, political contributions and embezzlement. We have systems in place to thoroughly investigate such allegations, and although to date (and except as noted above) our investigations have resulted in such allegations being dismissed or not being found material, there can be no assurance that our investigations were sufficient or that future allegations will not result in compliance breaches in the future. Any actual or alleged compliance breaches could result in adverse publicity and/or have material adverse effects on our business or results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: In the auditor’s report on our 2019 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements there was attention drawn to uncertainty on the future and the impact that could have on continuing as a going concern.
Subsubsection Text: The auditor’s report on our 2019 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements, issued by PricewaterhouseCoopers GmbH Wirtschaftsprüfungsgesellschaft, our independent auditors, contains an emphasis of matter paragraph on the material uncertainty related to the ability of the Group to continue as a going concern. This paragraph draws attention to note “43 Group Risk Management— Going Concern” of the notes to our 2019 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements, where the executive directors describe that in connection with the ongoing effects of the COVID-19 pandemic the Group’s ability to continue as a going concern depends on the timing of the recovery of the business and hence, the achievement of the Group’s forecast earnings and cash flows, and respectively, the continuing financial support of the shareholders and the core banks. As stated in the note “43 Group Risk Management—Going Concern” in the notes to our 2019 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements, these events and conditions indicate along with other matters stated there that a material uncertainty exists that may cast significant doubt on the Group’s ability to continue as a going concern and that represents a risk that the Company’s ability to continue as a going concern is threatened pursuant to section 322 paragraph 2 sentence 3 of the German Commercial Code (Handelsgesetzbuch— HGB). The audit opinion on the 2019 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements is not modified in respect of this matter. None of our financial information included in this Offering Memorandum, including our 2019 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements, include any adjustments that may result from this uncertainty. The auditor’s report on our 2020 Audited Financial Statements does not contain an emphasis of matter paragraph, as the various measures taken by the Group to counteract the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on our results of operations were deemed sufficient to ensure the Group’s status as a going concern, secure capital and liquidity by providers of equity and debt capital and to safeguard against further negative developments from the COVID-19 pandemic. However, the COVID19 pandemic has had and continues to have a substantial impact on our business, primarily due to a significant reduction in volume of traffic at our car parks as a result of the restrictions on movement and other social distancing measures imposed by governments in Europe in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. See “Risks Related to our Business and Industry—The effects of the outbreak of COVID-19 _have disrupted our operations, which have had and may continue to have a negative adverse effect on our business, results of operations, financial condition and prospects.” Our ability to forecast our pace_ of recovery from the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic, the eventual levels to which our results of operations will return as well as our cash flows are dependent on when and the extent to which we can return to our pre-pandemic operating levels. Although our 2020 Audited Financial Statements do not contain an emphasis of matter paragraph, if one or more of the assumptions in making our assessment to report as a going concern are found to be incorrect, we may be unable to continue as a going concern. If we are unable to continue as a going concern, we would have to liquidate our assets and may receive less that the value at which those assets are carried on our 2020 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements, and investors could lose a part or all of their investment in the Notes. ##### 48 -----

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to stringent data privacy laws of each jurisdiction in which we operate and may be adversely affected by changes in the laws and regulations of each jurisdiction in which we operate and be exposed to increased compliance costs.
Subsubsection Text: We routinely collect and process sensitive customer data and information and, while we believe we have taken reasonable and appropriate steps to protect that information from security breaches, data loss and computer viruses, if our security procedures and controls were compromised, unintentionally or through cyber-attacks, customer data or information could be accessed by unauthorized third-parties. In addition, some customer information and data is stored with third-parties who may also be subject to the risk of cyber-attack or access by unauthorized third-parties. Furthermore, the regulatory environment governing the use of individually identifiable data of customers, employees and others is complex. We must comply with data protection and privacy laws in the EU and other relevant jurisdictions, including the EU General Data Protection Regulation. Under the General Data Protection Regulation the relevant data protection authorities have the power to impose administrative fines for data protection compliance violations, including fines of up to a maximum of €20 million or 4% of the Group’s global annual turnover of the preceding financial year in certain cases. Privacy and information security laws and requirements change frequently and compliance with them may require us to incur costs to make necessary systems changes and implement new administrative processes. The implementation of any such regulations could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Further, any failure of our security systems or the security systems of third-parties that results in customer data or information becoming available to unauthorized third-parties may result in damage to our reputation and the loss of customers. This may adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition. Any failure to comply with data protection laws may harm our reputation or lead to investigations, sanctions, penalties, proceedings or actions against us by governmental agencies, private individuals or companies, including privacy class action litigation in certain jurisdictions, resulting in higher expenditures to adequately protect us against such information security breaches.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Changes in credit and debit card provider requirements or applicable regulations could adversely affect our business.
Subsubsection Text: A substantial portion of our sales are made to customers that pay for their purchases with credit or debit cards, rather than with cash. We are exposed to a variety of risks associated with credit and debit cards. In connection with credit and debit card payments, we pay interchange and other fees. These fees may increase over time and thus increase our operating expenses and adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition if we are unable to increase our parking tariffs accordingly. We are also subject to payment card association operating rules, certification requirements and rules governing electronic funds transfers, which could change or be reinterpreted to make it difficult or impossible for us to comply. Any failure to comply with applicable requirements or regulations may expose us to fines and higher transaction fees, the loss of our ability to accept credit and debit card payments from our customers or the cessation of payments from credit and debit card providers to us for purchases already made. Any of these factors could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. Additionally, any material failure by us or our service providers to maintain compliance with the payment card industry security requirements or to rectify a data security issue may result in fines and restrictions on our ability to accept credit cards as a form of payment. The regulatory framework for data privacy and protection with respect to credit card information is uncertain for the foreseeable future, and it is possible that legal and regulatory obligations may continue to increase and may be interpreted and applied in a manner that is inconsistent or possibly conflicting from one jurisdiction to another. In addition, changes in regulations that require us to update or replace our parking and operational infrastructure, including our points of payments and/or payment systems, may expose us to significant additional costs, which may have an adverse effect on our business. For example, changes to the Payment Card Industry standard have in the past required us (and may require us in the future) to ##### 49 ----- upgrade most of our points of payment and payment systems in certain of our jurisdictions of operations, which resulted in several million euros of additional costs. In addition, changes to legislation (including tax laws) that affect how our points of payments work or account for transactions may require additional investments in the future.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Contractual and other disagreements with counterparties could result in liability and litigation costs or other expenses, which could lower our profits. Under the terms of our contracts, counterparties may terminate such agreements if we do not successfully comply with our obligations.
Subsubsection Text: From time to time, we are involved in contractual and other disagreements with counterparties relating to our parking facilities and agreements and our operations under such agreements. Such disagreements are more likely to occur during periods of challenging economic conditions. We generally are required to maintain the relevant parking facility in satisfactory condition throughout the term of the contract, and upon the expiration of each agreement to turn over substantially all assets related to such agreement to the relevant counterparties without financial compensation. Certain of our contracts require us to sell our equipment at book value once a contract is terminated. If a counterparty claims that we have failed to comply with the terms of our agreements, the contract may be revoked or we may not be successful in extending or renewing the agreement at the end of its term, in either case we may have to compensate the counterparty as a result. Any such disputes could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition or results of operations. If a governmental authority decides to terminate or amend our space agreements due to a serious violation of our contractual or regulatory obligations, such as failure to maintain the facility in such a way that it creates a serious danger to users or a persistent failure to make payments, we may not be entitled to full compensation for our initial investment or loss of anticipated profits from the agreement. If any of our existing significant spaces or other agreements are unilaterally terminated by one of the counterparties, our revenues in the future may be reduced, and our business, results of operations or financial condition may be materially adversely affected.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We may incur higher than expected costs as a result of unforeseen maintenance requirements or investments.
Subsubsection Text: Generally, our maintenance costs are relatively stable. However, we may experience unforeseen problems such as water damage, cracks in the walls or foundation or sinking among other things, for which we may become liable if we fail to timely notify our landlords. In addition, under the terms of certain of our agreements in respect of parking facilities that we do not legally own, we are responsible for maintenance and upkeep. If we were to experience a significant problem requiring repairs, our maintenance costs may be higher than expected or we may be forced to suspend or reduce operations at the affected facility until such time as the issue is resolved. Such increased expenses or any reduction in revenue due to unexpected facility closures may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations or financial condition. From time to time we make investments in our properties to make them more attractive to customers or to increase the ways in which we can generate revenue at those properties. We are currently expanding our core business under the brand “APCOA Urban Hubs”. Through this program, we seek to use our parking areas for logistics, mobility, EV charging and new technologies services. For example, the introduction and popularity of electric cars requires investment in infrastructure, such as charging points and plug-ins, which may lead to increased infrastructure and energy costs in case we are unable to negotiate funding from our partners. Our investments will require capital, and we may not have sufficient liquidity to make such investments or to make our properties attractive to customers. Our investments may not draw new customers to our facilities and may not turn out to be profitable. In addition, we may experience unforeseen issues arising from alternative uses of our car parks which may prove to be costly to rectify. For example, if we see lower than expected demand for charging points and higher than expected demand for logistics and storage, we may be required to make additional investments to address customer demand and increase profitability of our facilities. ##### 50 ----- We manage the construction of two to three parking facilities on average each year. We are thus exposed to a number of risks associated with large-scale construction projects, such as the failure of our contractors and subcontractors to perform, as well as delays and disruptions caused by technical or environmental problems, adverse weather conditions or other factors. Generally, pursuant to the terms of the relevant agreements, our contractors and subcontractors are required to indemnify us for delays in completing the project on time and any losses resulting therefrom. Once the construction of a parking facility on a new site is completed, we are exposed to a variety of risks in connection with the opening and operation of the new parking facility, which could result in us failing to recover our investment in the new parking facility. For example, the actual demand for parking spaces at the new site may not meet our expectations, and we may experience lower than expected volumes and revenues. Further, in a small number of our contracts we are responsible not only for the maintenance and upkeep of the facilities that we construct but also for structural and mechanical repairs of such facilities which can lead to significantly increased expenses in case any unforeseen structural issues occur.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Labor disputes and other labor matters could lead to loss of revenues or higher costs.
Subsubsection Text: We may experience labor disputes in certain situations resulting in strikes, work slowdowns or other actions that may cause the effective closure of our facilities, the need to offer free parking on a temporary basis or other events that disrupt us from providing services, all of which would result in reduced revenues. We have collective bargaining arrangements in place in Sweden, Norway, Austria and Denmark (with respect to employees on our contract with the Billund Airport) which provide employment rights to our work force and may require us to expend greater time and cost to alter or amend employees’ terms of employment or discontinuing employment relationships. If we are made to negotiate additional collective bargaining arrangements with our work force in other jurisdictions where we operate, it could result in a substantial increase in labor costs that we may be unable to recover through our existing contractual arrangements. Further, under applicable law, we have works councils in The Netherlands, Belgium, Germany and Denmark. We are required to seek such councils’ advice and consider any recommendations regarding certain business decisions we make from time to time and, for certain decisions, also seek such councils’ consent. Although we have not experienced any material collective labor disputes in the past and believe we currently enjoy good relationships with our works councils and employees, there can be no assurance that labor disputes will not arise in the future, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations or financial condition. Additionally, we may incur expenses in resolving disputes and complying with local laws relating to overtime, social security and pension contributions, occupational risk matters and other labor related issues. We may also incur increased labor costs due to competition, increased minimum wage, employee benefit costs, medical benefits costs or other factors, which could adversely impact our business, results of operations or financial condition. For example, a significant number of our employees are subject to minimum wage laws. Any increase in the applicable minimum wage may decrease our margins, as we may not be able to recover such wage increases through increased pricing (in the case of lease contracts) or through increased management fees (in the case of management contracts).

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We are exposed to the risk of rising labor costs, as well as work stoppages, strikes or other collective actions which might negatively impact our profitability.
Subsubsection Text: As of March 31, 2021, we had 3,980 full-time equivalents (“FTEs”). Personnel expenses represent a large portion of our cost base. Wages may increase as a result of worker shortages following the COVID-19 pandemic, which could make it more challenging or costly for us to hire and retain workers. Certain governments, including Germany, Poland and the United Kingdom, have imposed statutory minimum wages. The imposition of statutory minimum wages by other governments, or future increases of statutory minimum wages or any general increase in wages due to worker shortages or inflation or otherwise may impact our cost base. We may also be required to raise wages because of pressure exerted by trade unions or general wage increases. Wage increases and the associated rise in labor costs could negatively affect our profitability. Furthermore, labor costs may increase indirectly due to the application of complex collective labor laws and the establishment of works councils. Employees who are members of works councils must be exempted from their work duties at full pay so that they can participate in works council activities. In addition, it is possible that labor costs may rise due to an ##### 51 ----- increase in labor related litigation. For example we could be subject to claims arising from the termination of employment arrangements, continuous remuneration or overtime compensation schemes.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Natural disasters, acts of terrorism and other unexpected events could disrupt our services.
Subsubsection Text: Natural disasters, such as storms, earthquakes or floods, acts of terrorism and other unexpected events, such as large-scale electrical power supply outages, fires and vandalism, may result in reduced revenues for our parking businesses. Natural disasters may also cause economic dislocations throughout urban areas, regions or countries. In addition, terrorist attacks have resulted in, and may continue to result in, heightened security and traffic control measures in urban areas and increased government regulation of airport facilities. For example, the terrorist attacks in large cities in the United Kingdom, Germany, France and Belgium could have a negative impact on customer travel and traffic levels in a number of locations where we operate parking facilities. Increased security protocols in airports and public perception of terrorist threats may lead customers to seek alternative means of transportation such as coaches or trains, in particular for national travel, which could have a negative impact on occupancy of our car parks at airports. The occurrence and consequences of such events are unpredictable, and further attacks could temporarily reduce traffic levels and decrease volumes for our parking facilities, thus causing a reduction in revenues. Our insurance may not be sufficient to cover claims arising from such events. Significant damage to or destruction of one of the facilities we operate may also result in the termination of the contract. Additionally, such events could cause interruptions in our monitoring or other information technology systems, which could materially adversely affect our business, results of operations or financial condition.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our business is seasonal and we may also be impacted by adverse weather conditions in our markets.
