- the relevant Note Guarantee and/or Security Documents were held to exceed the corporate objects of the Guarantor or not to be in the best interests or for the corporate benefit of the Guarantor; - the amount paid or payable under the relevant Note Guarantee was in excess of the maximum amount permitted under applicable law; or - the grant of the Note Guarantee or security is, having regard to the risk accepted by the holders of the Notes, on terms which are, or were, such as to require grossly exorbitant payments to be made (whether conditionally or in certain contingencies) in respect of the subscription for the Notes or otherwise grossly contravenes ordinary principles of fair dealing. These or similar laws may also apply to any future Note Guarantee granted by any of our subsidiaries pursuant to the Indenture or other securities pursuant to the Security Documents. We cannot assure you which standard a court would apply in determining whether a Guarantor was “insolvent” at the relevant time or that, regardless of the method of the valuation, a court would not determine that a Guarantor was insolvent on that date, or that a court would not determine, regardless of whether or not a Guarantor was insolvent on the date its Note Guarantee was issued, that payments to holders of the Notes constituted preferences, fraudulent transfers or conveyances on other grounds. The measure of insolvency for purposes of fraudulent transfer laws vary depending upon applicable governing law. Generally, an entity would be considered insolvent if, at the time it incurred indebtedness: the sum of its debts, including contingent liabilities, is greater than the fair value of all its assets; the present fair saleable value of its assets is less than the amount required to pay the probable liability on its existing debts and liabilities, including contingent liabilities, as they become due; or it cannot pay its debts as they become due. ##### 69 ----- The liability of each Guarantor under its Note Guarantee or other security will be limited to the amount that will result in such Note Guarantee not constituting a preference, fraudulent conveyance or improper corporate distribution, or otherwise being set aside or found to be in violation of the applicable statutory requirements in each such jurisdiction. However, there can be no assurance as to what standard a court will apply in making a determination of the maximum liability of each Guarantor, or the effectiveness of limitation language. It is possible that the entire Note Guarantee or other security may be set aside, in which case the entire liability may be extinguished. If a court decided that a Note Guarantee was a preference, fraudulent transfer or conveyance and voided such Note Guarantee, or held it unenforceable for any other reason, you may cease to have any claim in respect of the relevant Guarantor and would be a creditor solely of the Issuer and, if applicable, of any other Guarantor under the relevant Note Guarantee that has not been declared void. In the event that any Note Guarantee is invalid or unenforceable, in whole or in part, or to the extent the agreed limitation of the Note Guarantee obligations apply, the Notes would be effectively subordinated to all liabilities of the applicable Guarantor, and if we cannot satisfy our obligations under the Notes or any Note Guarantee is found to be a preference, fraudulent transfer or conveyance, or is otherwise set aside, we cannot assure you that we can ever repay in full any amounts outstanding under the Notes.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Notes and Our Capital Structure
Subsubsection Title: We may not be able to obtain the funds required to repurchase the Notes upon a Change of Control and the occurrence of certain important corporate events will not constitute a Change of Control.
Subsubsection Text: The Indenture will contain provisions relating to certain events constituting a “Change of Control” (as defined in “Description of the Notes”). Upon the occurrence of a Change of Control, we will be required to offer to repurchase all outstanding Notes at a price equal to 101% of their principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to the date of repurchase. If a Change of Control were to occur, we cannot assure you that we would have sufficient funds available at such time, or that we would have sufficient funds to provide to the Issuer to pay the purchase price of the outstanding Notes or that the restrictions in the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, the Indenture, the Intercreditor Agreement or our other then-existing contractual obligations would allow us to make such required repurchases. A Change of Control may trigger a mandatory prepayment of amounts outstanding under the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement and other indebtedness even if such event is deemed not to be a change of control under the Indenture. The repurchase of the Notes pursuant to such an offer could cause a default under such indebtedness, even if the Change of Control itself does not. The ability of the Issuer to receive cash from its subsidiaries to allow it to pay cash to the holders of the Notes following the occurrence of a Change of Control, may be limited by our thenexisting financial resources. Sufficient funds may not be available when necessary to make any required repurchases. If an event constituting a Change of Control were to occur at a time when we are prohibited from providing funds to the Issuer for the purpose of repurchasing the Notes, we may seek the consent of the lenders under such indebtedness to the purchase of the Notes or may attempt to refinance the borrowings that contain such prohibition. If such a consent to repay such borrowings is not obtained, the Issuer would remain prohibited from repurchasing any Notes. In addition, we expect that we would require third-party financing to make an offer to repurchase the Notes upon a Change of Control. We cannot assure you that we would be able to obtain such financing. Any failure by the Issuer to offer to purchase the Notes would constitute a default under the Indenture, which would, in turn, constitute a default under the New Revolving Credit Facility. See “Description of the Notes—Change of Control.” The Change of Control provision that will be contained in the Indenture may not necessarily afford you protection in the event of certain important corporate events, including a reorganization, restructuring, merger or other similar transaction involving us that may adversely affect you, because such corporate events may not involve a shift in voting power or beneficial ownership or, even if they do, may not constitute a Change of Control as defined in the Indenture. Except as described under “Description of _the Notes—Change of Control,” the Indenture will not contain provisions that would require the Issuer_ to offer to repurchase or redeem the Notes in the event of a reorganization, restructuring, merger, recapitalization or similar transaction. ##### 70 ----- Moreover, as a matter of German law, with regard to any Change of Control triggered by measures taken in respect of the Issuer for the purpose of a debt/equity-swap as part of an insolvency plan proceeding (Insolvenzplanverfahren) or a restructuring plan proceeding (Restrukturierungsplanverfahren) under German law, the Change of Control provision could be deemed void and we would not be required to offer the repurchase of the outstanding Notes. In addition, the occurrence of certain events that might otherwise constitute a Change of Control will be deemed not to be a Change of Control if a certain net consolidated leverage ratio calculated in accordance with the “Description of the Notes” is not exceeded in connection with such an event. In this case, holders of Notes would not be entitled to require the Issuer to repurchase their Notes and would only be able to rely on the then prevailing trading prices in order to exit their investments, which might be lower than the 101% change of control repurchase price. See “Description of the Notes— _Change of Control” and “Description of the Notes—Certain Definitions—Change of Control Triggering Event.”_ The definition of Change of Control in the Indenture will include a disposition of all or substantially all of the assets of the Issuer and its restricted subsidiaries (if any), taken as a whole, to certain persons. Although there is a limited body of case law interpreting the phrase “all or substantially all,” there is no precise established definition of the phrase under applicable law. Accordingly, in certain circumstances, there may be a degree of uncertainty as to whether a particular transaction would involve a disposition of “all or substantially all” of the Issuer’s assets and its restricted subsidiaries taken as a whole. As a result, it may be unclear as to whether a Change of Control has occurred and whether the Issuer is required to make an offer to repurchase the relevant Notes.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Notes and Our Capital Structure
Subsubsection Title: The Notes will initially be held in book-entry form, and therefore you must rely on the procedures of the relevant clearing systems to exercise any rights and remedies.
Subsubsection Text: Owners of the book-entry interests will not be considered owners or holders of relevant Notes unless and until definitive notes are issued in exchange for book-entry interests. Instead, the common depositary (or its nominee) for Euroclear and Clearstream will be the sole registered holder of the Notes in global form. Payments of principal, interest and other amounts owing on or in respect of the Notes in global form will be made to the Paying Agent, which will make payments to Euroclear and Clearstream. Thereafter, such payments will be credited to Euroclear and Clearstream participants’ accounts that hold bookentry interests in the Notes in global form and credited by such participants to indirect participants. After payment to Euroclear and Clearstream, none of the Issuer, the Guarantors, the Trustee, the Transfer Agent, the Paying Agent, the Calculation Agent or the Registrar will have any responsibility or liability for any aspect of the records relating to or payments of interest, principal or other amounts to Euroclear and Clearstream, or to owners of book-entry interests. Accordingly, if you own a bookentry interest in the Notes, you must rely on the procedures of Euroclear and Clearstream and, if you are not a participant in Euroclear and/or Clearstream, on the procedures of the participant through which you own your interest, to exercise any rights and obligations of a holder of the Notes under the Indenture. Owners of book-entry interests will not have the direct right to act upon our solicitations for consents or requests for waivers or other actions from holders of the Notes, including the enforcement of security for the Notes and the Note Guarantees. Instead, if you own a book-entry interest, you will be permitted to act directly only to the extent you have received appropriate proxies to do so from Euroclear and Clearstream or, if applicable, from a participant. We cannot assure you that procedures implemented for the granting of such proxies will be sufficient to enable you to vote on any requested actions or to take any other action on a timely basis. Similarly, upon the occurrence of an event of default under the Indenture, unless and until the relevant Definitive Registered Notes (as defined in “Book-Entry, Delivery and Form”) are issued in respect of ##### 71 ----- all book-entry interests, if you own a book-entry interest, you will be restricted to acting through Euroclear and Clearstream. We cannot assure you that the procedures to be implemented through Euroclear and Clearstream will be adequate to ensure the timely exercise of rights under the Notes.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Notes and Our Capital Structure
Subsubsection Title: There may not be an active trading market for the Notes, in which case your ability to sell the Notes may be limited.
Subsubsection Text: We cannot assure you as to: - the liquidity of any market in the Notes; - your ability to sell your Notes; or - the price at which you would be able to sell your Notes. Future trading prices for the Notes will depend on many factors, including, among other things, prevailing interest rates, our operating results and the market for similar securities. Historically, the market for non-investment-grade securities has been subject to disruptions that have caused substantial volatility in the prices of securities similar to the Notes. The liquidity of a trading market for the Notes may be adversely affected by a general decline in the market for similar securities and is subject to disruptions that may cause volatility in prices. The trading market for the Notes may attract different investors and this may affect the extent to which the Notes may trade. It is possible that the market for the Notes will be subject to disruptions. Any such disruption may have a negative effect on you, as a holder of the Notes, regardless of our prospects and financial performance. As a result, there can be no assurance that there will be an active trading market for the Notes. If no active trading market develops, you may not be able to resell your holding of the Notes at a fair value, if at all. Although an application will be made to the Authority for the listing of and permission to deal in the Notes on the Official List of the Exchange, we cannot assure you that the Notes will be or remain listed. Although no assurance can be made as to the liquidity of the Notes as a result of the admission to the Official List of the Exchange, failure to be approved for listing or the delisting (whether or not for an alternative admission to listing on another stock exchange) of the Notes from the Official List of the Exchange may have a material effect on a holder’s ability to resell the Notes in the secondary market. In addition, the Indenture will allow us to issue additional Notes in the future, which could adversely impact the liquidity of the relevant series of Notes.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Notes and Our Capital Structure
Subsubsection Title: United States civil liabilities may not be enforceable against us.
Subsubsection Text: The Issuer is incorporated under the laws of Germany, and the Guarantors and security providers are incorporated under the laws of Germany, Austria, Belgium, Denmark, England, Italy, Luxembourg, Norway, Sweden and the Netherlands. In addition, all members of our management board and our officers reside outside the United States. As a result, it may be difficult for investors to effect service of process within the United States upon us or such other persons residing outside the United States, or to enforce outside the United States judgments obtained against such persons in United States courts in any action. In addition, it may be difficult for investors to enforce, in original actions brought in courts in jurisdictions located outside the United States, including those of the Guarantors, rights predicated upon United States laws. See “Service of Process and Enforcement of Civil Liabilities.” Recovery in civil proceedings, ability to effect service of process and the recognition and enforceability of judgments against Guarantors organized in jurisdictions are also subject to qualifications and local applicable law. See “Certain Insolvency Law Considerations and Limitations on Validity and _Enforceability of the Note Guarantees and the Security Interests” on the various relevant jurisdictions_ of the Issuer and Guarantors. ##### 72 -----

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Notes and Our Capital Structure
Subsubsection Title: Credit ratings may not reflect all risks, are not recommendations to buy or hold securities and may be subject to revision, suspension or withdrawal at any time.
Subsubsection Text: One or more independent credit rating agencies may assign credit ratings to the Notes. The credit ratings address our ability to perform our obligations under the terms of the Notes and credit risks in determining the likelihood that payments will be made when due under the Notes. The ratings may not reflect the potential impact of all risks related to the structure, market, additional risk factors discussed above and other factors that may affect the value of the Notes. A credit rating is not a recommendation to buy, sell or hold securities and may be subject to revision, suspension or withdrawal by the rating agency at any time. No assurance can be given that a credit rating will remain constant for any given period of time or that a credit rating will not be lowered or withdrawn entirely by the credit rating agency if, in its judgment, circumstances in the future so warrant. A suspension, reduction or withdrawal at any time of the credit rating assigned to the relevant Notes by one or more of the credit rating agencies may adversely affect the cost, terms and conditions of our financings, could adversely affect the value and trading of the Notes and have an adverse impact on our cost of capital in our local business and our ability to secure local financing or win additional contracts.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Notes and Our Capital Structure
Subsubsection Title: The transferability of the Notes may be limited under applicable securities laws.
Subsubsection Text: The Notes and the Note Guarantees have not been, and will not be, registered under the Securities Act or the securities laws of any state or any other jurisdiction and, unless so registered, may not be offered or sold in the United States, except pursuant to an exemption from, or in a transaction not subject to, the registration requirements of the Securities Act and the applicable securities laws of any state or any other jurisdiction. The Notes are not being offered for sale in the United States except to QIBs in accordance with Rule 144A. We have not agreed to or otherwise undertaken to register the Notes with the SEC (including by way of an exchange offer). See “Transfer Restrictions.” It is the obligation of holders of the Notes to ensure that their offers and sales of the Notes within the United States and other countries comply with applicable securities laws.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Notes and Our Capital Structure
Subsubsection Title: The Sponsor may have interests that do not align with yours.
Subsubsection Text: The Sponsor has the power to control our affairs and policies. The Sponsor also controls, to a large degree, the election of directors, the appointment of management and the entry into mergers, sales of substantially all of our assets, the payment of cash dividends and other extraordinary transactions. The directors so elected will have authority, subject to the terms of our indebtedness (including the Notes), to issue additional stock, implement stock repurchase programs, declare dividends and make other decisions. The interests of the Sponsor could conflict with your interests. For example, if we encounter financial difficulties or are unable to pay our indebtedness as it matures, the interests of the Sponsor and certain of its affiliates as equity holders might conflict with your interests as a holder of the Notes. The Sponsor may also have an interest in pursuing dividend payments, acquisitions, divestitures, financings or other transactions that, in its judgment, could enhance its equity investments, even though such transactions might involve risks to you as a holder of the Notes or decrease the value of the Collateral securing the Notes. Additionally, the Sponsor is in the business of making investments in companies, and may from time to time acquire interests in businesses that directly or indirectly compete with certain portions of our business or are suppliers or clients of ours. For more information, see “Our _Shareholder” and “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions.”_

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Notes and Our Capital Structure
Subsubsection Title: You may face foreign currency exchange risks as a result of investing in the Notes.
Subsubsection Text: The Notes will be denominated and payable in euro. If you are a U.S. investor, an investment in the Notes will entail foreign exchange related risks due to, among other factors, possible significant changes in the value of the euro relative to the U.S. dollar because of economic, political and other factors over which we have no control. Depreciation of the euro against the U.S. dollar could cause a decrease in the effective yield of the Notes below their stated coupon rates and could result in a loss to you on a U.S. dollar basis. ##### 73 -----

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Notes and Our Capital Structure
Subsubsection Title: The Notes may be issued with original issue discount for U.S. federal income tax purposes.
Subsubsection Text: If the stated principal amount of the Notes exceeds their issue price by an amount equal to or greater than a statutorily defined de minimis amount, then the Notes will be considered to be issued with original issue discount (“OID”) for U.S. federal income tax purposes. If the Notes are issued with OID, then, in addition to the stated interest on the Notes, a holder subject to U.S. federal income taxation generally will be required to include the OID on such Note in gross income (as ordinary income) as it accrues on a constant yield to maturity basis for U.S. federal income tax purposes, in advance of the receipt of the cash payments to which such OID is attributable and regardless of the U.S. Holder’s regular method of accounting for U.S. federal income tax purposes. See “Certain Tax Considerations—Certain U.S. _Federal Income Tax Considerations—Original Issue Discount.” Prospective investors should consult_ with their tax advisors regarding the application of such rules to the Notes.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Notes and Our Capital Structure
Subsubsection Title: Upon an IPO Debt Pushdown, material Collateral and Note Guarantees may be released, any retaken Collateral may be subject to hardening periods, and holders of the Notes may have adverse tax consequences.
Subsubsection Text: Under certain circumstances, we may undertake the transactions described in “Description of Certain _Financing_ _Arrangements—Intercreditor_ _Agreement—Provisions_ _Following_ _an IPO” (such_ transactions, an “IPO Debt Pushdown”), pursuant to which the Issuers are entitled to give notice that will automatically operate so that, among other things, the references in the Indentures and any Intercreditor Agreement to such Issuer and Restricted Subsidiaries shall apply only to the IPO Pushdown Entity and its Restricted Subsidiaries. In such event, each holding or parent company of the IPO Pushdown Entity would be released from its obligations under the applicable Debt Documents, which would include the release of Note Guarantees and Collateral provided by such entities. There are no restrictions on the transfer of assets to such entities, and any such release may materially reduce the Collateral securing the Notes. Moreover, we may elect to, but are not under any obligation to, revoke or otherwise reverse an IPO Debt Pushdown undertaken in anticipation of an initial public offering, or to replace any Note Guarantees or Collateral released pursuant thereto, in the event such initial public offering is not consummated. To the extent that new security documents in respect of any Collateral to be retaken (including a pledge over the shares of the Issuer) are entered into, such Collateral may be subject to new hardening periods. In addition, such modifications to the terms of the Notes could be treated for U.S. federal income tax purposes as a deemed exchange of (i) the Notes as in place prior to such modifications for (ii) new Notes as in place after such modifications. If such modifications result in a deemed exchange for U.S. federal income tax purposes, such deemed exchange generally would be treated as a taxable transaction for U.S. federal income tax purposes in which beneficial owners of the Notes would be required to recognize any gain or loss. Furthermore, for U.S. federal income tax purposes, the new Notes deemed issued in such a deemed exchange could be treated as issued with original issue discount. In such event, holders subject to U.S. federal income taxation would be required to include the original issue discount in their income as it accrues, in advance of the receipt of cash corresponding to such income. In addition, the determination of whether the deemed new Notes are treated as “contingent payment debt instruments” as a result of the possibility of additional payments, as further described above under “ —Additional Payments,” would be made at the time of the modification. Holders subject to U.S. federal income taxation should consult their own tax advisors as to the U.S. federal income tax considerations relating to potential modifications of the Notes in connection with the IPO Debt Pushdown. It is also possible that the IPO Debt Pushdown could result in a taxable event for tax purposes other than U.S. federal income tax purposes.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Notes and Our Capital Structure
Subsubsection Title: Interest paid on a Note paid to a resident of a “non-cooperative jurisdiction” after December 31, 2021 may be subject to a new German withholding tax, and the Issuer will not be obligated to pay any additional amounts in respect of any such withholding.
Subsubsection Text: Germany recently enacted a new withholding tax at a rate of 15.825% on interest paid by a payor that is tax resident in Germany to a payee that is tax resident in a “non-cooperative jurisdiction” listed in a decree to be published by the German Federal Ministry of Finance. The list of non-cooperative ##### 74 ----- jurisdictions, which is expected to be based on the European Union’s list of non-cooperative jurisdictions and may be amended from time to time, is currently expected to include: American Samoa, Anguilla, Dominica, Fiji, Guam, Palau, Panama, Samoa, Seychelles, Trinidad and Tobago, the U.S. Virgin Islands and Vanuatu. The new withholding tax is expected to apply to interest paid after December 31, 2021 or, in the case of jurisdictions that were added to the European Union’s list of noncooperative jurisdictions after December 31, 2020, to interest paid after December 31, 2022. If the foregoing withholding tax applies to any amounts payable to a holder of Notes, the Issuer will not be obligated to pay any additional amounts in respect of such withholding. Prospective investors should consult their tax advisors regarding the new German withholding tax. ##### 75 ----- ##### USE OF PROCEEDS We expect the gross proceeds from the Offering will be €665.0 million. We will use the proceeds of the Offering to (i) fully repay the Existing Term Loans, including accrued interest, (ii) fund cash to our balance sheet for general corporate and working capital purposes and (iii) pay fees and expenses incurred in connection with the Transactions. The following table summarizes the estimated sources and uses of funds for the Transactions, assuming the Offering was completed on March 31, 2021. Actual amounts will vary from estimated amounts depending on several factors, including the actual completion date of the Transactions, our actual fees and expenses and the amount of borrowings and accrued interest under the Existing Term Loan on the Issue Date. We currently anticipate that the New Revolving Credit Facility will be undrawn on the Issue Date.

Our results may not be indicative of our future performance. The following discussion includes forward-looking statements based on assumptions about our future performance. Our actual results could differ materially from those contained in any forward-looking statements as a result of many factors, including but not limited to those described under “Cautionary Statement Regarding Forward-Looking Statements,” “Risk Factors” and elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. In addition, we have included in this Offering Memorandum a discussion of the financial information for the twelve months ended March 31, 2021. The financial information for the twelve months ended March 31, 2021 has been prepared solely for illustrative purposes only and is not prepared in accordance with IFRS. Accordingly, this data should not be used as the basis for, or prediction of, an annualized calculation. This Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations contains certain financial measures, in particular the presentation of Pre-IFRS 16 Adjusted EBITDA, which are not presented in accordance with IFRS. These Non-GAAP Measures are being presented because they provide us and readers of this Offering Memorandum with additional insight into our operational performance relative to earlier periods. We do not intend for these Non-GAAP Measures to be a substitute for any IFRS financial information. Readers of this Offering Memorandum should use these Non-GAAP Measures only in conjunction with the comparable IFRS financial measures. Reconciliation of such non-GAAP measures to the most comparable IFRS measures are provided, elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. See “Presentation of Financial Information—Non-GAAP Measures” and “Summary—Summary Financial and Other Data.” Some information included in this Offering Memorandum are management estimates and, although such estimates are based on information derived from our internal management control system, such estimates are not part of our Financial Statements and have not been audited or otherwise reviewed by an outside auditor, consultant or expert._

Subsection Title: Overview
Subsubsection Text: We are a leading parking infrastructure operator and services provider in the European market, with a large and diversified portfolio of leased and managed parking facilities across 13 European countries. We operate off-street parking facilities under leases from private and public landlords, and also operate on- and off-street parking facilities for clients under management contracts. As of March 31, 2021, we operated approximately 11,700 parking facilities with over 1.6 million parking spaces. We believe we are either the leading or number two parking facility operator by number of parking spaces in each of our ten largest country markets. We benefit from a large, structurally attractive and growing parking market that we believe will benefit from ongoing outsourcing, mobility and other industry trends such as growth in the number of vehicles in Europe, urban areas, electric vehicle (“EV”) charging, car hiring and sharing and more recently use of the car parks as infrastructure for the e-commerce value chain and customer delivery. During 2018, the European parking market generated approximately €28 to 29 billion in revenues of which approximately €11 to 12 billion was spent on outsourcing parking management. We believe we are well positioned to capture the benefits from these trends and the general economic recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic expected in 2021 and 2022 because we create significant, stable and recurring value for our clients, for whom parking facilities are often a non-core operation, by providing a large scale platform that is focused on driving higher revenues by increasing volume, pricing and utilization, at a lower cost of operation. ##### 78 ----- Our operations benefit from a diverse portfolio of lease and management contracts as well as geographical, business sector and customer diversification, which made our business more resilient during the COVID-19 pandemic, while at the same time allowing us to leverage operational similarities to benefit from scale economies. Our parking facilities are spread across most of Europe (with certain clusters for operational efficiency) and apart from one large market (Germany), five other countries (Denmark, Italy, Sweden, the United Kingdom and Norway) each contributed approximately 10% of our Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution in the year ended December 31, 2019. We operate in a wide range of business sectors, such as city and shopping, travel, healthcare & education, events and hospitality, and parking enforcement, with limited correlation between them. Furthermore, many of our parking facilities are not dedicated to a single institution, business or purpose but are instead multifunctional and used by motorists that visit a variety of locations, whether it is for work, shopping, restaurant or cultural activities, or other purposes. We have very low contract concentration, with over 5,900 contracts across over 11,700 parking facilities. Subsection Title: Our Sectors and Geographies
Subsubsection Title: Our Sectors
Subsubsection Text: We are a leading, pan-European provider of parking management services, parking enforcement services and ancillary services across all parking sectors. Our parking sectors include (i) City & Shopping, (ii) Travel, (iii) Healthcare & Education, (iv) Events & Hospitality and (v) Parking Enforcement, which include our Park & Control (PAC), Park & Guard and “On-Street” parking enforcement services. The following table provides overview of our revenue by sector for the periods indicated:

Subsection Title: Twelve Three months ended** **months ended Year Ended December 31,** **March 31,** **March 31, (€ million)** **2018** **2019** **2020** **2020** **2021** **2021 (unaudited)** **(unaudited)

Subsubsection Title: Our Main Geographies
Subsubsection Text: We operate our business on a pan-European scale in 13 countries. The following table provides an overview of our Contract Contribution in our main geographies for the periods indicated:

_City & Shopping_ Our City & Shopping sector has historically been our largest sector in terms of revenue. Within the City & Shopping sector, our operations include a mixture of lease contracts and management contracts with clients including municipalities, investors and owners and operators of city centre parking facilities which are generally visited by consumers for a variety of purposes such as offices, other places of work, leisure and recreational locations. Short-term parking, including for work, shopping, cultural activities or other purposes, contributes the majority of revenue by fee type with approximately 65% on average. Our operations in this sector benefit from ongoing urbanization across Europe as well as the continuing increase in population mobility, which have historically led to increased vehicle numbers within urban environments. Our growth in this sector is partially offset by the expanding use of public transportation as well as the growing popularity of e-commerce, all of which reduces footfall in inner cities. In addition, we also operate a number of facilities related to either in-town or out-of-town shopping centers under a mixture of both lease and management contracts. Growth in this sector is generally through a combination of pricing and through utilizing technology to reduce the costs of operating these facilities (e.g., through the introduction of ANPR technology). ##### 79 ----- Our results of operations in the City & Shopping sector were significantly affected as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, which resulted in the implementation of nationwide lockdowns, increased home working and the closure of non-essential shops across Europe. Given the quick and almost instant recovery of the City & Shopping sector upon lifting of lockdown measures during 2020, we expect our operation in this sector to gradually return to the levels seen before the pandemic as the vaccine roll-out accelerates and restrictions on social contact are eased across Europe and, particularly in the initial periods of the recovery, where we expect some consumers switch to using private rather than public transport. _Travel_ The Travel sector is our second-largest sector in terms of revenue. Our operations in the Travel sector include a mixture of lease contracts and management contracts. In the latter, we receive management fees independently of parking volumes at the underlying parking facility, across a number of segments of the travel market including airports, train stations and park & ride facilities. Our financial performance in this sector has historically been partly driven by positive passenger volume trends in European air travel, which increased by 30% between 2014 and 2019, as well as by increasing disposable income, which has resulted in an increase in holiday travel. While our performance in the Travel sector in the three months ended March 31, 2021 and the year ended December 31, 2020, was significantly affected by the COVID-19 pandemic, which led to a year-on-year decrease in air passenger numbers across the European Union by 70%, passenger volumes are forecast to recover to their preCOVID-19 pandemic levels by 2024. Despite the volume impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, our Contract Contribution decreased only by 39% in the year ended December 31, 2020 compared to the year ended December 31, 2019 due to a combination of our mix of contract types and operations across different segments of the Travel sector as well as support from our clients. A number of our clients in this sector waived any guaranteed minimum rents in our airport lease contracts (thereby making them fully variable rents and thus providing downside protection in the face of reduced travel volumes throughout the pandemic) and, in a number of locations, our landlords agreed to temporarily reduce the variable rent percentages. _Healthcare & Education_ Our operations in the Healthcare & Education sector have historically benefitted from the ongoing outsourcing of parking management and parking enforcement services by public and private hospital operators and universities. Our clients in the Healthcare & Education sector include public and private hospitals as well as universities. Many clients in this sector consider parking to be important as both a service to offer their visitors in addition to a revenue generator for them. As such, we operate a mixture of both lease and management contracts, depending on the client’s requirements and our view of the risk profile of a contract. The healthcare sites are usually characterized by limited available spaces with different publics to be served: staff, patients and visitors. The efficient management of these customers flows increasingly requires digital technology. Similarly, in the Education sector there is a mix of teaching and other staff, students and visitors, again with limited spaces that require careful management. Particularly in the Healthcare sector we increasingly help the hospitals to expand parking capacity by planning and coordinating the building of new facilities which we then manage through contracts with a duration of over 15 years. The Healthcare & Education sector were comparatively less impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic as hospitals and other healthcare facilities remained opened throughout the year and continued to benefit from high utilization of parking facilities by, for example, hospital staff. _Events and Hospitality_ The Events & Hospitality sector primarily encompasses parking facilities at exhibitions, events (including sports and cultural venues) and hotels, with both lease and management contracts. Our lease revenue in particular in this sector will be dependent on the number of events held at these locations or the number of visitors. Since parking revenues in this sector are highly dependent on the number of ##### 80 ----- events held or visitors to these locations, our contract and rent structures reflect the characteristics of each location. We usually provide the following services: site-specific ad hoc resources, organize the car flow, provide the parking equipment and focus on driving revenue which is increasingly pre-booked. In the three months ended March 31, 2021 and the year ended December 31, 2020, our performance in the Events and Hospitality sector was significantly affected by the COVID-19 pandemic, which led to the cancellation of mass events and the temporary closure of trade fairs and entertainment venues and significantly reduced occupancy at hotels. _Parking Enforcement Services_ Parking enforcement services sales revenue comprises control fees and revenue generated from enforcement of parking on behalf of the owner or landlord of the parking facilities. This is generally generated by our parking attendants issuing the control fees to owners of vehicles who have parked in contravention of the parking regulations at the site, or through the use of technology such as ANPR cameras. See “—Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Fee Type—Control Fees.”

Subsubsection Text: (1) Other includes Ireland, Poland, Belgium, Luxembourg, Netherlands, Austria, Switzerland, Corporate Center. All countries are internally measured by their ability to win new business, retain existing contracts, site price and utilization optimization and deliver continuous improvements on cost optimization. The level of revenue generation and Contract Contribution from any given country also depends on the sector split in the relevant country as well as the split between revenue types and the mix of lease and management contracts. _Germany_ Germany is our largest market and has a comparatively larger share of lease contracts compared to our other markets. Growth in this market is primarily driven by increased outsourcing of parking management (i.e. first time letting of lease or management contracts) and parking enforcement services, in addition to overall macro drivers around the mobility sector. In addition, we believe that the relatively low digital penetration of the parking industry in Germany provides us with considerable growth potential as our electronic payment and consumer engagement solutions gain increased usage. ##### 81 ----- The following charts provide overview of revenue by sector and contract type from our operations in Germany for the year ended December 31, 2019:

The Travel sector (primarily covering airports and rail segments) is our largest sector in the United Kingdom, which accounted for 38% of revenue in the year ended December 31, 2019. Our operations in the United Kingdom benefit from a high share of management contracts, accounting for 81% of our total revenue in the United Kingdom in the year ended December 31, 2019, which has historically led to stable and predictable Contract Contribution generation. In addition, our operations in the United Kingdom benefit from an increased roll-out of digital parking technology, which provides us with the opportunity to access new, high-margin income streams (such as ANPR technology, which has lower associated operating costs than traditional manned patrols or barrier operations). Subsection Title: COVID-19 Impact on Our Business
Subsubsection Text: Our results of operation in the three months ended March 31, 2021 and the year ended December 31, 2020 have been impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic. In 2020, total revenue declined across all fee types by a total of 26.2%. However, the decline was mainly driven by a reduction of short-term parking revenue (53% of total revenue 2019) by 42.0%, while revenue from all other fee types in aggregate decreased by only 8.2%. See “—Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Fee Type.” Following an approximately 16.1% increase in revenue and an 11.1% increase in Pre-IFRS 16 Adjusted EBITDA in the two months ended February 28, 2020 compared to the prior-year period, revenue generation and Pre-IFRS 16 Adjusted EBITDA declined sharply, by approximately 44% and 173%, respectively, in the second quarter of 2020 as a result of the strict lockdown measures imposed by governments across Europe to slow the spread of COVID-19. The imposition of lockdown measures had most severe impact on our operations during the period from March to May 2020, when short-term parking revenues were significantly reduced, as consumers worked from home and were only allowed or advised to go out for essential or narrowly-defined permitted purposes. With the easing of lockdown measures across our jurisdictions of operation towards the end of the second quarter of 2020, consumers almost instantly started to utilize our parking facilities again, which resulted in a strong recovery of our short-term parking revenues and operating cash flows, which continued through the end of the summer of 2020. Even with short-term parking revenue in the third quarter of 2020 continuing to be negatively affected by the absence of mass events, the closure of hospitality and entertainment venues, nationwide working from home policies and continued restrictions on travel, we estimate that across all of our jurisdictions of operations our revenue for the third quarter ended September 30, 2020 reached approximately 76% of our revenue generated during the third quarter ended September 30, 2019. The resurgence of the virus in the fourth quarter of 2020 and the corresponding imposition of further lockdown measures led to a renewed significant decrease in short-term parking revenues. At the same time, our contract parking revenue increased by 5.5% in the year ended December 31, 2020 compared to the year ended December 31, 2019. In addition, our management contracts remained relatively less impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, with our revenue from management contracts for the year ended December 31, 2020 amounting to €155.6 million compared to €173.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2019. Our management reacted quickly to the COVID-19 pandemic and established a cross-functional COVID-19 response team, which focuses on safeguarding the health and safety of our employees and consumers and limiting the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on our business. In particular, in March 2020, management implemented strict cash management controls, including (i) a bottom-up, 17-week rolling cashflow forecast and (ii) the deferral of non-essential capital expenditures, which resulted in a reduction of our non-new business capital expenditures to €17.7 million (compared to €22.5 million in the year ended December 2019). These cash management controls resulted in reductions in total capital expenditures (excluding finance leases) in 2020 compared to the original budget for that year of €10.3 million, of which €9.9 million was deferred to 2021. In addition, we implemented stringent operational and overhead cost reduction measures, including an immediate freeze on all temporary and new hiring, a reduction in headcount of 736 employees, particularly in our parking attendant and airport staff numbers, and furloughing approximately 20% of our non-directly revenue generating operational and overhead staff. Furthermore, we leveraged government programs, such as flexi-time and furlough arrangements and fixed cost recovery support schemes, in order to further reduce our cost base. These measures resulted in cost reductions compared to the original 2020 budget of approximately €44 million, or 17% of our total non-rent costs, in the period March 1 to December 31, 2020. ##### 85 ----- In March 2020, we initiated a rent waiver and deferral program across our entire business, which included the re-negotiation of lease contracts with the aim to defer rent payments and temporarily reduce or move fixed rent structures to variable rent structures. In addition, we invoked existing contractual protection clauses, such as clauses allowing rent adjustments in the case of an under-utilization of parking facilities, to further reduce our rent payments. These rent reduction measures, coupled with the benefit of reduced variable rent costs due to lower revenues, resulted in rent savings of approximately €125 million in the year ended December 31, 2020 compared to the original budget for that year. In May and June 2020, we also raised additional liquidity in an aggregate amount net of costs of €68 million in the form of an additional term loan facility. Furthermore, in May 2020, our shareholders, Centerbridge and SVP Global provided us with an equity injection in the amount of €40 million. In addition to implementing measures to safeguard our business, we also continued to focus on providing consumers of our parking facilities with the best possible customer service given the circumstances, including by keeping our parking facilities open as much as possible as people were advised to avoid public transportation, decreasing physical contact points by enabling and promoting digital payment and contactless and cashless parking solutions and leveraging our online pre-booking tools. These efforts resulted in high retention rate of 98% in line with previous years and new business equivalent to €13.2 million in annualized Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution during 2020, which we expect will contribute significantly to our portfolio growth going forward. While our business has been significantly impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, the past fifteen months also showed that as soon as restrictions are eased, people quickly start to return to our facilities, corresponding to a direct recovery in revenues. Our liquidity position remains stable and we believe that the continued roll-out of vaccination programs across our markets will contribute to the acceleration of our recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic.

Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Demand for Parking Services
Subsubsection Text: Our revenues and profitability are affected by industry-wide megatrends which drive demand for our parking services. Growth in the European parking industry is driven by increasing urbanization across Europe, as well as an increased mobility of urban populations, with cars historically accounting for more than 80% of passenger transport in the European Union. These trends have led to a significant growth of the overall vehicle fleet in Europe, which has increased by between 12 and 15 million vehicles per year between 2013 and 2019, and stood at over 240 million vehicles at the end of 2019. While this growth trend was reversed in 2020 as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, when new car registrations in Europe decreased by approximately 24%, the total number of vehicles in Europe remained relatively stable. At the same time, traffic volumes and, in turn, demand for parking services are negatively affected by increased consumer reliance on car sharing and taxi services, such as Uber, which provide alternatives to private vehicle usage. In addition, cities and municipalities are expanding their public transportation networks as they seek to control the flow of traffic through their town and city centers, which may result in reduced car traffic. Furthermore, increased regulation of the car industry, such as the phase-out of combustion engines across Europe as well as road user charges, such as London’s congestion charge and Oslo’s road tolls, can lead to a reduction in the level of traffic, as well as stagnating demand for parking spaces.

Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Type of Contract
Subsubsection Text: We provide parking management services and parking enforcement services through a combination of lease contracts and management contracts. ##### 86 ----- _Lease Contracts_ Lease contracts are medium-term contracts with a typical initial duration of ten to fifteen years, with an option to extend for another five to ten years mostly at our sole discretion. Under our lease contracts, we are typical responsible for running the parking operations at the relevant parking facility. In turn, we receive parking fees directly from the consumer using the parking facility and pay rent to the lessor or owner of the underlying asset. Rent payments under our lease contracts are usually in a combination of fixed rent payments, which accounted for 42% of rent payments in the year ended December 31, 2019 (on a Pre-IFRS 16 basis), and variable rent payments that are linked to, for example, the amount of parking fees collected. In addition, under our lease contracts, we are typically responsible for all operating expenses of the relevant parking facility, such as personnel expenses, cost of materials and other operating expenses as well as all capital expenditure for parking equipment. We often have full pricing autonomy under our lease contracts, except at locations where the landlord wishes to retain authority for parking tariffs such as airports and shopping centers. In the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020 and the twelve months ended March 31, 2021, lease contracts accounted for 76%, 76%, 71% and 69%, respectively, of our total revenue . Furthermore, in the year ended December 31, 2019, lease contracts accounted for 96% of revenue in Denmark, 83% in Sweden, 97% in Norway, 84% in Italy, 84% in Germany and 19% in the United Kingdom. As of March 31, 2021, we had approximately 7,000 sites under lease agreements. _Management Contracts_ Management contracts have a typical duration of three to eight years. Under our management contracts, we receive fees from the site owner or lessor to cover our costs for running a site in addition to a fee for managing the site. We can also generate revenue from equipment sales to our clients. The management fees that we receive under our management contracts is typically adjusted on an annual basis based on the consumer price index or other benchmark indices. We do not pay rent to our customers under our management contracts but remain responsible for covering the underlying parking facility’s operating expenses, such as personnel expenses, cost of materials and other operating expenses. Parking tariff control and other strategic decisions related to the underlying parking facility remain with the owner or lessor. As a result, we are not exposed to risk of fluctuating parking volume and instead focus our activities on optimizing our operational performance. Management contracts generally have lower margins than lease contracts as we are not exposed to any revenue risk. However, our margins earned from management contracts are a function of a markup on our operational costs, rather than consumer revenue less rent less operational costs for lease contracts, and as a result on a percentage basis, management contract margins are not directly comparable to those for lease contracts. Total management contract revenue includes that shown as ‘management agreements’ in the fee type analysis, in addition to part of ‘other services’ which relates to charge-on of costs to management contract clients. In the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020 and the twelve months ended March 31, 2021, management contracts accounted for 24%, 24%, 29% and 31%, respectively, of our total revenue. Furthermore, in the year ended December 31, 2019, management contracts accounted for 4% of revenue in Denmark, 17% in Sweden, 3% in Norway, 16% in Italy, 16% in Germany and 81% in the United Kingdom. As of March 31, 2021, we had approximately 4,700 sites under lease agreements.

Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Pricing
Subsubsection Text: Our results of operations are impacted by the pricing of parking tariffs at our parking facilities. We generally determine parking fees based on supply and demand at individual parking locations. In addition, we set parking tariffs with reference to the local competitive environment for alternative locations in the immediate vicinity of our parking facilities. The level of pricing for our parking tariffs ##### 87 ----- typically also depends on the parking fee type, with rates for short-term parking generally being higher than rates for long-term parking. Furthermore, the parking fees are impacted by regulation: regulation affects the level of supply, through controlling new developments, the pricing of on-street parking, and the amount of available free parking. Lastly, regulations affect the demand for our parking facilities through policies that discourage vehicle traffic, such as congestion charges and other urban planning measures, and the promotion of mass transit alternatives. We continue to optimize our pricing structure through the roll-out of our data-driven dynamic pricing model, which allows us to adjust our parking tariffs based on the location of a parking facility, the time and day, demand at a particular parking facility and the duration of stay.

Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Fee Type
Subsubsection Text: Our results of operations are affected by the type of parking fee charged. Our parking fees include (i) short-term parking fees, (ii) fees from management agreements, (iii) contract parking fees and (iv) fees from off-street parking facility monitoring. The following table provides a breakdown of sales revenue according to fee type for the periods indicated:
