Subsubsection Title: Contract Retention and New Business
Subsubsection Text: Our results of operations are affected by our ability to win, retain and renew lease and management contracts. As of March 31, 2021, we had 7,000 sites under lease contracts and 4,700 sites under management agreements and to May 31, 2021 we have signed new contracts accounting for €6.4 million of total Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution. The amount of new contracts signed per year has continued to increase in recent years, from €12.2 million in 2018, to €12.4 million in 2019 and €13.2 million in 2020, in each case, of total Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution. We have historically retained contracts accounting for more than 95% of our Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution in the past five years, which we believe is a result of our disciplined and proactive approach to contract renewals for facilities that we consider desirable or less risky to our overall business operations. In the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, we renewed contracts accounting for €8.6 million, €11.3 million and €22.7 million of total Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution, respectively. Our win rate has also increased, from approximately 35% in 2016 to 60% in 2019 and 75% in 2020. As a result of the successful renewal of these contracts, the volume of contracts that is due for renewal by the end of 2026 is significantly lower and only accounts for an aggregate €44.8 million of Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution for the year ended December 31, 2019 representing on average only 5% per annum across that period of our total Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution for the year ended December 31, 2019. As of March 31, 2021, the remaining average duration of our top 100 lease contracts was 14 years and of our top 100 management contracts was approximately six years, in both cases based on 2019 Pre-IFRS 16 weighted average Contract Contribution. We believe that our high client retention rate, coupled with lower volumes of contract renewals in the period through to 2026, have historically contributed, and will continue to contribute, to the stability of our revenue generation and earnings visibility. Despite the effect of the COVID-19 pandemic on our business, in the year ended December 31, 2020 and the three months ended March 31, 2021 we signed new contracts which we estimate will contribute an aggregate amount of approximately €53.6 million to our revenue and approximately €13.2 million to our Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution and approximately €14.8 million to our revenue and approximately €3.6 million to our Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution, respectively. On average, the Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution margin of new business won during 2020 is approximately 500bps above the existing core portfolio of contracts. Our unweighted pipeline of new contracts has constantly remained high, amounting to approximately €66 million, €67 million, €78 million and €80 million of Pre-IFRS 16 Contract Contribution in the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020 and the twelve months ended March 31, 2021, respectively. Prior to entering into a new contract for a parking facility, we assess the optimum level of investment for that facility in order to increase its profitability and produce a suitable return on our investment. Our level of investment will in turn depend on whether or not we believe that the facility in question would benefit from extensive investment in the redesign and addition of APCOA-specific features, such as APCOA FLOW and ANPR technology, which would be typical for attractive locations with expected high demand for high quality parking, such as in the City & Shopping sector. We typically agree a lower level of investment in facilities where cash flows are less certain and/or there is a limited opportunity to realize financial benefits from our branding and design. We typically recoup or initial investment after one to two years in the case of lease contracts and less than one year in the case of management contracts. Contract Contribution recognized in the year from new contracts increased from €8 million in 2016 to €13 million in 2019.

Subsubsection Title: Cost Structure
Subsubsection Text: Our results of operations are affected by our cost structure. Our cost structure mainly comprises fixed costs, such as fixed rent payments, overhead personnel costs and costs associated with our parking facilities, such as costs for maintenance and repairs and ancillary costs, which accounted for approximately 40% of our costs in the year ended December 31, 2019 (on a Pre-IFRS 16 basis), as well as semi-variable costs, such as operational staff, cleaning costs, costs related to snow removal, travel and equipment repairs, which accounted for approximately 30% of our cost base in the year ended December 31, 2019 (on a Pre-IFRS 16 basis). In addition, in the year ended December 31, 2019, ##### 90 ----- approximately 30% of our costs were variable (on a Pre-IFRS 16 basis), mainly consisting of variable rents and payment card processing fees. _Rent_ Lease expenses, or rent, comprises fixed lease payments as well as performance-based variable lease payments, which are generally calculated on a percentage of the sales revenue generated from the underlying leased site. In the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, 57%, 58% and 46%, respectively, of our pre-IFRS 16 rent expenses were variable. The fixed rent component under our lease contracts is periodically adjusted based on the consumer price index or other benchmark indices. Our total rent expenses amounted to €356.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2016 (of which €126.1 million was fixed and €230.6 million was variable), €321.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2017 (of which €129.0 million was fixed and €192.5 million was variable), €318.6 million in the year ended December 31, 2018 (of which €136.8 million was fixed and €181.8 million was variable), €344.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 (of which €144.0 million was fixed and €200.6 million was variable) and €262.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2020 (of which €141.1 million was fixed and €121.1 million was variable), in each case, before giving effect to the application of IFRS 16. Excluding the effects of IFRS 16, our comparatively low rent expenses for the year ended December 31, 2020 reflect a decrease in variable rents as a result of reduced revenue from lease contracts due to the COVID-19 pandemic during that year. In addition, in connection with the COVID-19 pandemic, during the year ended December 31, 2020, we received government grants on a country-by-country basis to offset fixed costs (including fixed lease payments, office rent, other operational expenditures and other overhead expenses). _Personnel Expenses_ Our personnel expenses constitute the second largest part of our cost structure after lease expenses. Personnel expenses are largely fixed and semi-variable and include wages and salaries as well as social security payments. During the year ended December 31, 2020, we benefitted from a number of government aid programs set up in response to the COVID-19 pandemic in the jurisdictions in which we operate our business. Pursuant to these programs, we received government grants in an aggregate amount of €8.4 million, which were recognized as a reduction in personnel expenses in our 2020 Audited Financial Statements. In addition, during the COVID-19 pandemic, we took advantage of employment support programs, such as Kurzarbeit in Germany, Cassa Integrazione in Italy, temporary unemployment in Belgium and the furlough scheme in the United Kingdom. _Cost of Materials and Purchased Services_ Our cost of materials are largely variable or semi-variable in nature and include (i) maintenance repair costs and expenses for the repair of technical equipment, (ii) expenses for other external services, such as payments in connection with external parking space monitoring and expenses for payment cards and cleaning services, (iii) expenses for energy and other utilities and (iv) the costs of general operating supplies, such as Pay & Display machines. _Other Expenses_ Other operating expenses are mainly fixed in nature and include audit and consulting costs, information technology expenses, expenses for temporary workers, expenses related to our fleet, travel expenses and expenses for telecommunications. In the year ended December 31, 2020, we significantly reduced our other operating expenses in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, by terminating and furloughing temporary employees (resulting in a €2.5 million reduction in other operating expenses), cancelling nearly all business travel (resulting in a €2.2 million reduction in other operating expenses), streamlining our vehicle fleet (resulting in a €1.2 million reduction in other operating expenses) and severely limiting our marketing expenses (resulting in a €0.9 million reduction in other operating expenses). ##### 91 -----

Subsubsection Title: Cost Savings and Efficiency Programs
Subsubsection Text: Starting in 2017, we implemented several cost savings and operational efficiency initiatives focused on (i) driving productivity in our control fee business line, (ii) optimizing site costs and (iii) reducing central and procurements costs. In order to increase the productivity in our control fee revenue stream, we optimized the deployment and routing of parking attendants based on site occupancy, traffic congestion and historical hit rates. We also minimized unproductive hours by starting the routes directly on site, reduced sickness rates and used means of transportation reflecting the local traffic situation. To optimize site costs across our business, we implemented group-wide benchmarks and best practices, resulting in a streamlined FTE headcount and pooled resources to minimize overcapacity. We also adjusted third-party services and reduced utilities costs. To streamline our central and procurement costs, we implemented pooled customer service functions cross-country, we digitized back-office processes and implemented self-administrative contract parker platforms. In addition, we took steps to bundle our procurement activities across our entire business to leverage our scale and generate cross-country synergies. We estimate that these measures have resulted in total cost savings of approximately €10 million across 2017-2019, in addition to the various measures and savings introduced in 2020 in response to the COVID-19 pandemic which are discussed elsewhere in this document.

Subsubsection Title: Increased Digitization
Subsubsection Text: Our business and results of operations are impacted by the increasing digitization of the parking industry, which drives volumes and has resulted in parking convenience being a key factor when deciding where to park. To grow our business, we increasingly rely on digital marketing, including a robust social media presence, which continues to be a key driver of parking volumes. In addition, we are increasing the use of our online sales and pre-booking platforms, which allow consumer to pre-book parking spaces and purchase season tickets online. Between 2015 and 2019, the number of online prebooking services more than tripled. Furthermore, we believe that the increasing digitization of the parking industry allows for new partnerships with participants across the broader automotive landscape, such as fleet lessors, fuel card managers and parking services providers, which drive volumes at existing sites and which we expect will provide for additional revenue streams, such as subscription fees for partners’ services offered through our websites, in the future. To respond to the increased demand for digital parking services, we launched our apps “APCOA Connect” in the United Kingdom and the Republic of Ireland in 2012 as well as “APCOA FLOW” in Denmark, Germany, Italy, Norway, Austria, Poland and Sweden from 2018, which enables consumers to access mobile, contactless on- and offstreet parking services. We estimate that we generated revenues of approximately €35 million through these apps in the year ended December 31, 2019. In addition, the digitization of the parking industry has allowed us to generate revenues from new parking and services concepts, such as storage opportunities for logistics providers, virtual car rental services and electronic vehicle charging, which we continue to roll out across our business through our Urban Hubs initiative.

Subsubsection Title: Acquisitions
Subsubsection Text: Historically, value accretive acquisitions of attractive parking management service providers have been a driver of both organic and non-organic growth in our operations, geographical reach, revenue and profit margin. Our acquisitions have added €0.3 million, €6.8 million and €3.6 million to our EBITDA (excluding the impact of IFRS 16 for years after December 31, 2018) for the ones conducted in the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020, respectively. Between January 2019 and March 31, ##### 92 ----- 2021, we completed five acquisitions. As a result, our results of future periods will not be directly comparable to past periods. _Year Ended December 31, 2019_ On May 6, 2019, we acquired all of the shares in OnePark A/S in order to strengthen our presence in Denmark and further accelerate our growth in that market. Since its foundation in 2012, OnePark has been operating in the parking management sector, managing more than 30,000 parking spaces in Denmark. We fully consolidated OnePark on the date of its acquisition. Between May 6, 2019 and December 31, 2019, OnePark contributed revenues of €11.1 million and net profit of €2.7 million. If the acquisition had taken place on January 1, 2019, OnePark would have contributed revenues of €16.3 million and net profit of €3.5 million. The transaction costs for the acquisition of OnePark amounted to €0.5 million, which we recognized in other expenses for the year ended December 31, 2019. On August 8, 2019, we acquired all of the shares in Nationwide Controlled Parking Systems Limited, Mobile Research Solution Limited and Parking and Enforcement Agency Ltd. (collectively, NCPS) in order to strengthen our presence in Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland and further accelerate our growth in those markets. Since its foundation in 1998, NCPS has been operating in the parking management sector, managing more than 100,000 parking spaces in Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland. We fully consolidated NCPS on the date of its acquisition. Between August 8, 2019 and December 31, 2019, NCPS contributed revenues of €4.4 million and net profit of €0.9 million. If the acquisition had taken place on January 1, 2019, NCPS would have contributed revenues of €10.6 million and net profit of €2.1 million. The transaction costs for the acquisition NCPS amounted to €1.0 million, which we recognized in other expenses for the year ended December 31, 2019. On December 2, 2019, we acquired all of the shares in Alpina Deutschland GmbH in order to strengthen our presence in Germany. Since its foundation in 2017, Alpina has been managing parking spaces in the greater Munich area. If the acquisition had taken place on January 1, 2019, Alpina would have contributed revenues of €0.3 million and net loss of €26 thousand. The transaction costs for the acquisition Alpina amounted to €0.1 million, which we recognized in other expenses for the year ended December 31, 2019. _Year Ended December 31, 2020_ On January 2, 2020, we acquired all of the shares in Xpert Parkering Sweden AB in order to strengthen our presence in Sweden and further accelerate our growth in that market. Xpert manages more than 40,000 parking spaces in Sweden. We fully consolidated Xpert on the date of its acquisition. Between January 2, 2020 and December 31, 2020, Xpert contributed revenues of €6.1 million and net profit of €1.2 million. The transaction costs for the acquisition of Xpert amounted to €0.3 million, which we recognized in other expenses for the year ended December 31, 2020. On December 1, 2020, we acquired all of the shares in Security Park AS, Profectum AS and Automaten AS (collectively, the “Security Park Group”) in order to strengthen our presence in Norway. The Security Park Group manages and markets parking facilities in Norway using technological solutions. We fully consolidated the companies in the Security Park Group on the date of their acquisition. Between December 1, 2020 and December 31, 2020, the Security Park Group contributed revenues of €0.5 million and net profit of €0.1 million. If the acquisition had taken place on January 1, 2020, the Security Park Group would have contributed revenues of €6.8 million and net profit of €0.6 million. The transaction costs for the acquisition of the Security Park Group amounted to €0.4 million, which we recognized in other expenses for the year ended December 31, 2020.

Subsubsection Title: Foreign Currency Effects
Subsubsection Text: We operate car parks in 13 countries of which six countries, the United Kingdom, Sweden, Norway, Denmark, Poland and Switzerland do not use the euro, our reporting currency, as their national currency. Accordingly, our results of operations are subject to currency effects, primarily currency translation ##### 93 ----- exposure; transaction-related exposures at our subsidiaries are limited because revenue and costs are largely incurred in their respective operating currencies. For our subsidiaries in countries with a functional currency other than euro, income and losses are translated into euro at average exchange rates, and assets and liabilities are translated into euro at closing exchange rates. Fluctuations in exchange rates against the euro will give rise to period-on-period differences in our results of operations. In the years ended December 31, 2018, 2019 and 2020 and the three months ended March 31, 2021, 50%, 52%, 57% and 60%, respectively, of our revenue for such periods was reported by subsidiaries whose functional currencies are different than the euro, primarily the British pound sterling, the Danish krone, the Norwegian krone, Polish zloty, Swedish krona and Swiss franc. We are also subject to foreign currency effects linked to loans denominated in currencies other than the functional currency of the entity that holds the loan, which creates unrealized foreign currency gains and/ or losses depending on the fluctuation of the underlying foreign exchange rates.

(1) Primarily relates to refunds or cancellations of control fees. Revenue for leased sites is comprised of a mix of short-term parking fees, contract parking fees and control fees, although we do not always generate all types of fees from every site. For leased sites, our revenue is generally related to the volume of consumers using these sites. In addition, we are usually also responsible for collecting the consumer revenue at leased sites. To minimize our revenue collection risk, we collect most of the short-term parking and contract parking fees at our leased sites either in advance or at the point of utilization of the parking site. Revenue for management sites is comprised of management fees, which are intended to cover both our costs incurred in operating a site for a client and our fees for performing the management services. Management fees are either fixed in total, which allows us to increase site profitability through cost savings, or on an actual cost recovery basis, which results in cost saving programs benefitting the client, plus a fixed management element. In addition to our traditional fee types, we are seeing increasing demand for utilization of our parking facilities as Urban Hubs. We consider income from our Urban Hubs to be incremental to income generated from parking consumers as our Urban Hubs typically either utilize spare capacity at sites or at times of the day when occupancy levels are generally lower, resulting in only limited overlap with our other revenue streams. We plan to separately report revenue from our Urban Hubs once it becomes material to the overall group. ##### 88 ----- _Short-Term Parking Fees_ Short-term parking fees are generated from shorter term parking customers, such as per-hour or per-day tickets, under our lease contracts. We collect short-term parking fees directly from the short-term parking customers in the form of cash or by debit or credit cards at the gates and physical barriers present in our parking facilities. Short-term parking is typically charged at higher rates than long-term parking, resulting in higher profitability per hour as compared to long-term parking. At the same time, short-term parking exposes us to risks of lower level of parking facility utilization and, as a result, greater volatility in revenue generation. _Management Fees_ Management fees comprise fixed and variable fees generated under our management contracts with third parties, including public authorities and private landlords and can be across all the main sectors in which we operate. The level of management fees for a particular asset is typically agreed for the duration of the management contract and is typically adjusted on an annual basis based on the consumer price index as well as other benchmark indices, such as the London Living Wage. Given their relatively fixed nature, management fees provide us with revenue stability and visibility over the duration of the management contract. _Contract Parking Fees_ Contract parking fees describe fees generated from customers holding season tickets, including monthly, quarterly and annual season tickets, under our lease contracts. Contract parking fees are fixed for the duration of the agreement with the consumer and are typically subject to annual price escalations and collected in advance of the period to which they relate. As a result, contract parking fees have historically provided us with greater revenue stability compared to short-term parking fees. _Parking Enforcement Services Fees_ The type of fees received under our parking enforcement services vary depending on whether our contract is with private landlords (in the case of Parking Control (“PAC”) or Park & Guard services) or with municipalities (in the case of “On-Street” services). Under contracts with private landlords, we generate control fees which comprise revenue generated from enforcement of parking on behalf of the owner or landlord of the parking facilities. Under these contracts, we patrol privately-owned parking spaces and issue and collect parking control fees directly from the consumer. We subsequently may pay a portion of the fees collected to the site landlord under our lease agreements based on the level of fees collected. In the case of “On-Street” services, we patrol parking spaces owned by public authorities and issue parking fines, which the consumer pays directly to the municipality. Under such contracts, we receive a management fee from the municipality for the provision of our enforcement services. These fees are reported under the ‘management agreement’ fee type. We do not book any of the control fees and fines as part of our revenue. _Other Services_ Our revenue from other services mainly includes charge-on of certain costs to management contract clients, fees charged to owners and landlords for services provided to them in connection with our contacts, such as revenue generated from the sale of parking equipment, income generated from advertising activities and valet parking services. ##### 89 -----

Revenue decreased by €51.5 million, or 31.4%, to €112.4 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021 as compared to €163.9 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020, primarily due to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. Revenue in all of our geographies decreased in the three months ended March 31, 2021 compared to the three months ended March 31, 2020, primarily due to reductions in frequencies and volumes caused by movement restrictions in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. In Germany this decrease was partly offset by the impact of the new contract at Berlin Brandenburg airport (€3.4 million) which commenced operations in the fourth quarter of 2020. In Norway, the decrease was partially offset by revenue generated from the Security Park Group (€1.6 million), which we acquired in December 2020. Revenue by Sales Type _Short term parking - Short-term parking revenue decreased by €42.0 million, or 53.6%, to €36.4 million_ for the three months ended March 31, 2021 as compared to €78.4 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020, primarily due to reductions in frequencies and volumes caused by movement restrictions in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. Management agreements_ - Management agreements revenue decreased by €3.1 million, or 9.4%, to €29.8 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021 as compared to €32.8 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020, primarily due to reduced headcount and other costs required to service these contracts caused by movement restrictions in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. _Contract parking - Contract parking increased by €0.9 million, or 4.3%, to €22.8 million for the three_ months ended March 31, 2021 as compared to €21.9 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020, primarily due to increased consumer demand for assigned parking spaces when using their car for commuting due to the COVID-19 pandemic. _Control fees - Control fees decreased by €4.3 million, or 22.9%, to €14.5 million for the three months_ ended March 31, 2021 as compared to €18.8 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020, primarily due to reductions in parking violation volumes caused by movement restrictions in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. _Other services - Other services revenue decreased by €3.6 million, or 26.5%, to €10.0 million for the_ three months ended March 31, 2021 as compared to €13.6 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020, primarily due to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. ##### 95 ----- _Sales deduction - Sales deductions decreased by €0.6 million, or 35.4%, to €1.0 million for the three_ months ended March 31, 2021 as compared to €1.6 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020, primarily due to lower overall control fee revenue. _Other Income_ Other income decreased by €2.8 million, or 40.8%, to €4.0 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021 as compared to €6.7 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020, primarily due to COVID-19-related booking of rent discounts. _Rent_ Rent decreased by €14.9 million, or 34.0%, to €28.9 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021 as compared to €43.8 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020, primarily due to lower variable rent payments as a result of decreased revenues due to the COVID-19 pandemic. On a Pre-IFRS 16 basis, our rent for the three months ended March 31, 2021 would have been €63.3 million compared to €79.8 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This decrease was primarily due to lower variable rent payments as a result of decreased revenues due to the COVID-19 pandemic. On a Pre-IFRS 16 basis, our variable rent for the three months ended March 31, 2021 would have been €27.3 million compared to €42.7 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This decrease was primarily as a result of decreased revenues due to the COVID-19 pandemic. On a PreIFRS 16 basis, our fixed rent for the three months ended March 31, 2021 would have been €36.0 million compared to €37.1 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This decrease was primarily due to some clients temporarily reducing or switching our rents to be variable in recognition of the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. _Cost of Material and of Purchased Services_ Cost of material and of purchased services decreased by €2.8 million, or 17.2%, to €13.7 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021 as compared to €16.6 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020, primarily due to lower levels of activity in the business as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. _Personnel Expenses_ Personnel expenses decreased by €9.6 million, or 20.4%, to €37.4 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021 as compared to €47.0 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020, primarily due to reduced staff numbers (including those on furlough schemes) as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. _Other Expenses_ Other expenses decreased by €3.5 million, or 21.8%, to €12.5 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021 as compared to €16.0 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020, primarily due to lower levels of activity in the business as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. _Amortization / depreciation and impairment of intangible assets and of property, plant and equipment as well as right of use asset_ Amortization / depreciation and impairment of intangible assets and of property, plant and equipment as well as right of use assets decreased by €16.2 million, or 29.5%, to €38.7 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021 as compared to €54.9 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020, primarily due to 2020 including a right-of-use asset impairment in the United Kingdom, and impairment of assets in Germany. On a Pre-IFRS 16 basis, our amortization / depreciation and impairment of intangible assets and of property, plant and equipment for the three months ended March 31, 2021 would have been €9.4 million ##### 96 ----- compared to €11.3 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020, primarily due to an impairment of our property, plant and equipment in the three months ended March 31, 2020. _Financial Income_ Financial income decreased by €11.7 million to €3.4 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021 as compared to €15.1 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020, primarily due to a reduction on the interest rate of our Existing Credit Facilities in February 2020, which resulted in a loan book value adjustment. _Financial Expenses_ Financial expenses decreased by €6.0 million, or 19.5%, to €24.8 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021 as compared to €30.8 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020, primarily due to lower levels of foreign currency losses. _Income Taxes_ Income tax expenses increased by €0.8 million to €1.1 million for the three months ended March 31, 2021 as compared to €0.3 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020, primarily due to a write down of deferred tax assets on interest losses carried forward.

The deferred tax credit relates mainly to temporary differences between local GAAP and tax GAAP. ##### 99 -----

On a Pre-IFRS 16 basis, our rent for the year ended December 31, 2019 would have been €344.7 million compared to €318.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. On a Pre-IFRS 16 basis, our amortization / depreciation and impairment of intangible assets and of property, plant and equipment as well as right of use assets for the year ended December 31, 2019 would have been €31.9 million compared to €30.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to the impact of additional capital expenditure conducted in the year. _Financial Income_ Financial income increased by €1.0 million, or 81.6%, to €2.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 as compared to €1.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to currency gains registered in 2019 which resulted from the periodic measurement of loans denominated in foreign currencies and the cash pool accounts in relation to our affiliated companies. _Financial Expenses_ Financial expenses increased by €49.1 million to €74.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 as compared to €25.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2018, primarily due to added interest due to the implementation of IFRS 16. _Income Taxes_ Income taxes decreased by €2.5 million, or 50.0%, to €2.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 as compared to €5.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2018.

Subsection Title: Liquidity and Capital Resources
Subsubsection Title: Selected Cash Flow Line Items

Subsection Title: Liquidity and Capital Resources
Subsubsection Text: Our primary liquidity requirements are to service our debt, fund our operations and for other general corporate purposes. Our ability to generate cash from our operations depends on our future operating performance, which is in turn dependent, to some extent, on general economic, financial, competitive, market, legislative, regulatory and other factors, many of which are beyond our control, as well as other factors including those discussed in this section and the section entitled “Risk Factors.” Following the completion of the Transactions, we expect that our principal sources of liquidity will be cash flows from operations as well as drawings under our New Revolving Credit Facility. See “Description of Certain _Financing Arrangements—New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement.”_ To manage our liquidity and working capital needs, we have entered into certain cash management arrangements with Deutsche Bank. These arrangements are provided to us on customary terms in the ordinary course of business and include, amongst others, zero balancing cash pooling and the collection of direct debits. We will continue to utilize these services following the Issue Date. Any obligations arising in connection with these cash management arrangements may be secured on the Collateral in priority to the Notes. In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, in the year ended December 31, 2020, we implemented a number of measures to safeguard our liquidity, including drawing down a new €78 million term loan facility (which resulted in additional liquidity of €68 million net of costs) and accessing €40 million of funds provided by our Sponsor. Furthermore, we made selective use of economic stimulus and government support programs where available, including furlough programs and government grants to assist with lease payments. In addition, we reduced or postponed investments and expenses and, in particular, we implemented a sustainable reduction in maintenance capital expenditures, introduced ##### 102 ----- short-time working arrangements for employees and reduced or deferred lease and rental payments in agreement with our landlords. We anticipate that we will be highly leveraged for the foreseeable future and our ability to generate future financing cash flows will be limited by the Indenture and New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, which may have important negative consequences for you. See “Risk Factors,” “Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants” and “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements.” Any additional indebtedness that we incur could reduce the amount of our cash flow available to make payments on our then existing indebtedness, including under the Notes offered hereby, and increase our leverage.

Subsubsection Title: Cash Flow from Operating Activities
Subsubsection Text: Our cash inflows from operating activities increased by €13.2 million, or 57.9%, from €22.7 million in the three months ended March 31, 2020 to €35.9 million in the three months ended March 31, 2021. The increase was primarily driven by a €33.3 million improvement in the cash impact of changes in payables, from a payable outflow of €14.1 million in the three months ended March 31, 2020 to an inflow of €19.2 million in the three months ended March 31, 2021. This positive impact was partially offset by the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, which resulted in our group result before income taxes decreasing by €13.0 million from the three months ended March 31, 2020 to the three months ended March 31, 2021. On a Pre-IFRS 16 basis, our cash flow from operating activities for the three months ended March 31, 2021 would have been an outflow of €1.1 million compared to an outflow of €13.6 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This increase was primarily due to a positive impact from working capital, namely increased trade payables and lower trade receivables, partly offset by the impact of the COVID-19, which resulted in a significantly lower EBITDA compared to the three months ended March 31, 2020. Our cash inflow from operating activities decreased by €87.9 million, or 42%, from €209.1 million in the year ended December 31, 2019 to €121.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2020. This decrease was mainly due to the sharp decrease in operating profit caused by the COVID-19 pandemic during the course of 2020. On a Pre-IFRS 16 basis, our cash flow from operating activities for the year ended December 31, 2020 would have been an outflow of €31.6 million compared to an inflow of €64.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. This decrease was mainly due to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, which resulted in a lower EBITDA for the year ended December 31, 2020. Our cash inflow from operating activities increased by €152.1 million, from €57.0 million in the year ended December 31, 2018 to €209.1 million in the year ended December 31, 2019. The increase was primarily driven by the introduction of IFRS 16 and the resultant changes in presentation, although the improved operating cash flow also contributed to the increase on a like-for-like basis. On a Pre-IFRS 16 basis, our cash flow from operating activities for the year ended December 31, 2019 would have been a cash inflow of €64.4 million compared to a cash inflow of €57.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to an increased inflow from working capital in 2019.

Subsubsection Title: Cash Flow from Investing Activities
Subsubsection Text: Our cash outflows from investing activities decreased by €9.5 million, or 62.0%, from €15.4 million in the three months ended March 31, 2020 to €5.9 million in the three months ended March 31, 2021. This decrease was primarily driven by payments for granted loans of €4.8 million in 2020 which was incurred in 2020 but not in 2021 and payments for acquisitions of affiliated companies decreased by €3.4 million. On a Pre-IFRS 16 basis, our cash flow from investing activities for the three months ended March 31, 2021 would have been an outflow of €5.4 million compared to an outflow of €15.3 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This decrease was mainly due to our higher outflows in the three months ended March 31, 2020 due to the acquisition of Xpert Parkering Swede AB and loans to our Belgian joint venture, ParcBrux BV. Our cash outflows from investing activities decreased by €22.7 million, or 34.4%, from an outflow of €66.0 million in the year ended December 31, 2019 to an outflow of €43.3 million in the year ended December 31, 2020. The decrease was mainly due to the lower level of capital expenditure in the year ended December 31, 2020. Cash flow from investing activities in 2020 include €10.8 million of cash used for acquisitions (less cash and cash equivalents acquired). On a Pre-IFRS 16 basis, our cash flow from investing activities for the year ended December 31, 2020 would have been an outflow of €41.9 million compared to an outflow of €64.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. This decrease was due to our capital expenditure reduction initiative, which decreased capital expenditure year-onyear, the acquisition of Security Park AS in Norway and a higher spend on loans to our Belgian joint venture, ParcBrux BV. ##### 104 ----- Our cash outflows from investing activities increased by €38.2 million, from €27.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2018 to €66.0 million in the year ended December 31, 2019. The increase was primarily driven by the greater number and value of acquisitions in the year ended December 31, 2019 resulting in total cash outflows from investing activities in the amount of €40.9 million (less cash acquired in the amount of €2.7 million), while we only acquired one business in the year ended December 31, 2018 for a low single digit million euro amount. On a Pre-IFRS 16 basis, our cash flow from investing activities for the year ended December 31, 2019 would have been a cash outflow of €64.4 million compared to a cash outflow of €27.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This decrease was primarily due to investments in the company acquisitions conducted in 2019.

Subsubsection Title: Cash Flow from Financing Activities
Subsubsection Text: Our cash outflows from financing activities increased by €41.9 million, from €2.7 million in the three months ended March 31, 2020 to €44.6 million in the three months ended March 31, 2021. This increase was primarily driven by the lower outflow incurred in 2020. In the three months ended March 31, 2020, we paid a €90 million dividend to our principal shareholder, which was partly offset by a €131.0 million inflow from payments received from long-term financial debt. This positive impact did not reoccur in 2021 and with other movements within this section remaining stable year-on-year, there was a higher outflow in 2021. On a Pre-IFRS 16 basis, our cash flow from financing activities for the three months ended March 31, 2021 would have been an outflow of €8.1 million compared to an inflow of €33.5 million for the three months ended March 31, 2020. This decrease was primarily due to financial liabilities which increased in the three months ended March 31, 2020, offset by a dividend payout we made in the three months ended March 31, 2020 which did not reoccur in the three months ended March 31, 2021. Our cash outflows from financing activities decreased by €60.9 million, or 47.9%, from €127.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2019 to €66.3 million in the year ended December 31, 2020. In the year ended December 31, 2020, payments received from long-term financial debt increased to €205.1 million. In addition, we repaid lease liabilities and financial liabilities in the amount of €140.7 million (compared to €101.2 million in 2019) and incurred interest payments, bank charges and transaction costs in the amount of €80.5 million (compared to €68.1 million in 2019), including interest on lease liabilities in the amount of €52.1 million (compared to €50.6 million in 2019). In addition, in the year ended December 31, 2020, we paid a dividend to our principal shareholder which resulted in a cash outflow of €90.0 million, partly offset by an equity injection by our principal shareholders which resulted in a cash inflow of €40.0 million. On a Pre-IFRS 16 basis, our cash flow from financing activities for the year ended December 31, 2020 would have been €85.1 million compared to €16.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase was primarily due to the increase in financial debt which was partly offset by the dividend payment to our shareholder. Our cash outflows from financing activities increased by €100.1 million, from an outflow of €27.1 million in the year ended December 31, 2018 to an outflow of €127.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2019. This increase was primarily driven by a redemption of liabilities from finance leases as a result of the the implementation of IFRS 16. In the year ended December 31, 2019, interestbearing loans from third parties increased to €42.2 million, primarily to fund the company acquisitions conducted in 2019. In addition, we repaid lease liabilities in the amount of €101.2 million (compared to €6.4 million from finance leasing in 2018) and incurred interest payment, bank charges and transaction costs in the amount of €68.1 million (compared to €20.5 million in 2018), including interest on lease liabilities in the amount of €50.6 million. On a Pre-IFRS 16 basis, our cash flow from financing activities for the year ended December 31, 2019 would have been a cash inflow of €16.0 million compared to a cash outflow of €27.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to increases in borrowings to fund the company acquisitions conducted in 2019. ##### 105 -----

Subsection Title: Capital Expenditures
Subsubsection Text: Our capital expenditures include (i) expansion capital expenditures comprising new business and digital infrastructure capital expenditures, (ii) renewal capital expenditures, (iii) maintenance capital expenditures and (iv) cars & overhead capital expenditures. Our capital expenditures exclude, in each case, finance leases. Expansion capital expenditures comprise new business and digital infrastructure capital expenditures: - New business capital expenditures relate to investments in new business contracts in order to get them operational. Examples include the new installation or the replacement of prior operator equipment with new parking equipment (barrier systems, lane branding, servers, cash machines and other payment points). - Digital infrastructure capital expenditures relate to investments in our digitalization strategy, including the inclusion of the car park onto our FLOW platform. Renewal capital expenditures comprises investments related to renewed contracts and include the upgrade of existing equipment or refurbishing the appearance of car parks (new lane branding, paint, lighting etc.). Maintenance capital expenditures relate to the maintenance of car parks within our lease portfolio. Examples include necessary repairs of broken equipment, lighting, or regulatory required upgrades, for example to cash or card payment machines. Car & overhead capital expenditures include investments in cars for operational and overhead staff as well as investments related to headquarters or non-operational functions, such as ERP updates, information technology hardware & software. The level of capital expenditures at any given parking facility varies depending on whether the facility is subject to a lease or management contract. Our total capital expenditures in the years ended December 31, 2018 and 2019 were relatively stable at €32.2 million and €37.1 million, respectively. In response to the COVID-19 pandemic situation, in the year ended December 31, 2020, we deferred all nonessential capital expenditures to 2021, resulting in a reduction of our non-growth capital expenditures by 9.4%, to €10.6 million, in the year ended December 31, 2020. We also deferred some growth capital expenditures to 2021, resulting in a reduction of our expansion capital expenditure by 28.0%, to € 13.6 million, in the year ended December 31, 2020. The following table sets forth our combined capital expenditures (excluding finance leases) for the periods indicated on a Pre-IFRS 16 basis.

This decrease was primarily due to a reduction in digital infrastructure capital expenditures due to ongoing strict control of our capital expenditures following the COVID-19 pandemic. Renewal capital expenditures in the three months ended March 31, 2021 increased by €0.1 million to €0.8 million from €0.7 million in the three months ended March 31, 2020. This increase was driven by renewal investments across eleven parking facilities. The biggest investment we undertook in the first quarter of 2021 was Parking Westblaak in the Netherlands. Maintenance capital expenditures in the three months ended March 31, 2021 decreased by €0.7 million to €0.3 million from €1.0 million in the three months ended March 31, 2020. This decrease was primarily due to ongoing strict control of our capital expenditures following the COVID19 pandemic. Car & overhead capital expenditures in the three months ended March 31, 2021 decreased by €0.4 million to €0.5 million from €0.9 million in the three months ended March 31, 2020. This decrease was primarily due to due to ongoing strict control of our capital expenditures following the COVID-19 pandemic. Expansion capital expenditures in the year ended December 31, 2020 decreased by €5.3 million to €13.6 million from €18.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2019. This decrease was primarily due to ongoing strict control of our capital expenditures following the COVID-19 pandemic. Renewal capital expenditures in the year ended December 31, 2020 increased by €0.4 million to €2.9 million from €2.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2019. Our largest renewal investments in 2020 included Southwark (On Street Enforcement) in the United Kingdom, Berlin Alexa in Germany and Stuttgart Bosch Areal. Maintenance capital expenditures in the year ended December 31, 2020 decreased by €0.4 million to €4.1 million from €4.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2019. This decrease was primarily due to ongoing strict control of our capital expenditures following the COVID-19 pandemic. Car & overhead capital expenditures in the year ended December 31, 2020 decreased by €1.1 million to €3.6 million from €4.7 million in the year ended December 31, 2019. This decrease was primarily due to ongoing strict control of our capital expenditures following the COVID-19 pandemic. Expansion capital expenditures in the year ended December 31, 2019 increased by €1.6 million to €18.9 million from €17.3 million in the year ended December 31, 2018. This increase was primarily due to increased investment in our digital strategy for the development and rollout of our APCOA FLOW app. Renewal capital expenditures in the year ended December 31, 2019 decreased by €0.6 million to €2.5 million from €3.1 million in the year ended December 31, 2018. This decrease was primarily due to lower levels of contract renewals requiring investment in replacement parking equipment. Maintenance capital expenditures in the year ended December 31, 2019 increased by €0.9 million to €4.5 million from €3.6 million in the year ended December 31, 2018. Our largest maintenance expenditures in 2020 included Parking de Montbenon in Switzerland, Billund airport and Køge Strædet shopping center in Denmark. Car & overhead capital expenditures in the year ended December 31, 2019 increased by €1.4 million to €4.7 million from €3.3 million in the year ended December 31, 2018. In 2019, we conducted major car purchases in Sweden, particularly relating to our Stockholm on-street contract, and invested in our headquarters for renovation purposes and IT infrastructure in the countries in which we operate.

Subsection Title: Off-Balance Sheet Arrangements
Subsubsection Title: Other Financial Obligations: Pensions and Similar Obligations
Subsubsection Text: Our employees are granted certain pension entitlements and similar benefits under our pension plans. For a description of our pension plans and similar obligations, see note 36 to our 2020 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements.

Subsection Title: Off-Balance Sheet Arrangements
Subsubsection Text: As of December 31, 2020, we had no material off-balance sheet arrangements.

Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Financial Risk Management
Subsubsection Title: Liquidity Risks
Subsubsection Text: Liquidity risks relate to the prospect of our Group not being able to fulfil its financial obligations. We manage our liquidity by maintaining liquid reserves and bank credit lines alongside the cash inflows from its operating business, and by having access to the capital market through continuous dialogue. Operational liquidity management comprises the daily pooling of liquid funds in the Group’s cash pool, which the Group Treasury function coordinates. In this way, liquidity surpluses and shortages can be managed both in accordance with the requirements of the Group as a whole and those of the individual Group companies. For budget planning purposes, a monthly liquidity plan was prepared for 2021, which was updated and extended to 2022. Liquidity at the level of both the Group and the national companies is monitored continuously. A Group liquidity status report is compiled daily for this purpose. In addition, regularly (once a week in times of large uncertainty, every three weeks in times of more stability) all units prepare a rolling 17-week liquidity forecast by planning category. Since March 2020, our liquidity risk has increased due to the COVID-19 pandemic and its impact on our revenue. We introduced a number of early and comprehensive measures in response to the COVID19 pandemic to safeguard our liquidity. See “—Liquidity and Capital Resources.”

Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Financial Risk Management
Subsubsection Title: Tax Risks
Subsubsection Text: Tax risks can arise for our Group if local tax authorities fail to agree with our assessment of a specific case. This risk is taken into consideration by obtaining tax advice and monitoring the relevant matters. The resulting tax risks could have a moderate short-term bearing on our finances.

Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Financial Risk Management
Subsubsection Title: Credit Risks
Subsubsection Text: Credit risks arise from the possibility that contractual partners to a transaction prove unable to fulfil their financial obligations, thereby causing financial losses for our Group. Receivables default risks are low as a result of our business model. This risk is further minimized by the wide geographical distribution of such receivables, and their spread across a large number of individual debtors. The elevated default risk in the parking facility management business unit arising from non-payers is reflected through value adjustments to individual accounts receivables.

Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Financial Risk Management
Subsubsection Title: Currency Risks
Subsubsection Text: Currency risks for our Group arise primarily from investments, financing measures and operative activities. Our national subsidiaries are provided with the necessary financial means in their local currencies so that no significant currency risks are generated for the national subsidiaries. We do not hedge against currency risks that do not influence the Group’s cash flow (risks arising from the currency conversion of foreign financial statements into the Group’s reporting currency, so-called translation risks). As debt funding for our Group is provided in the Group currency (euro) and partly differs from the currencies of the local APCOA companies, a translation risk arises from exchange rate fluctuations. This risk is monitored on a monthly basis with hedging measures being implemented where required. Additionally, currency risks arising from cash flows are monitored on a monthly basis.

Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Financial Risk Management
Subsubsection Title: Interest Rate Risks
Subsubsection Text: Risks of interest rate changes arise based on potential changes in the market interest rates and can lead to a change in the fair value of fixed-interest financial instruments, and fluctuations in interest payments on variable interest rate financial instruments. In the medium term, we expect interest rates to remain low and assess the risk of substantial rate increases to be minor. The relevant reference interest rate of ##### 108 ----- our Group is EURIBOR, and due to the agreed floor of 0%, a slight increase does not affect interest payments. Based on this assessment and to avoid additional financial costs (especially front-end fees), we have currently decided against interest rate hedging of our variable rate liabilities. Following the Offering, we will be exposed to additional interest risk. See “Risk Factors—The Floating Rate Notes _and drawings under the New Revolving Credit Facility will bear interest at floating rates that could rise significantly, increasing our costs and reducing our cash flow.” The company monitors and assess_ interest rate risks on a monthly basis so it can react quickly to changes in the market.

Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Financial Risk Management
Subsubsection Text: We are exposed to financial risks in the form of liquidity risks, tax risks, credit risks, currency risk and interest rate risk during the course of our ordinary business activities. ##### 107 ----- Non-financial or non-quantifiable risks, such as business risks or reputational risks, are not considered here.

Subsection Title: Critical Accounting Policies
Subsubsection Title: Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic
Subsubsection Text: Our business activities have been significantly affected by the pandemic and the associated uncertainties since March 2020. In particular, due to the still not fully foreseeable global consequences of the COVID-19 pandemic, the estimates and discretionary decisions made in connection with the assets and liabilities reported in the balance sheet are subject to a greater level of uncertainty. In updating the estimates and judgements, management took into account the information available concerning expected economic trends and country-specific government policies. This information was included particularly in impairment tests for the cash-generating units; in the case of impairment of trade receivables, the expected credit loss model was reviewed in relation to the assessment of future economic conditions in the context of COVID-19. Furthermore, this information was taken into account in the tax planning prepared by the Norwegian subsidiary, as sufficient taxable income exists in the long-term against which the loss carry forwards can be offset.

Subsection Title: Critical Accounting Policies
Subsubsection Title: Trade Receivables
Subsubsection Text: All trade receivables are initially recognized at the transaction price and subsequently adjusted for impairment to reflect the expected default. The calculation is based on historical default rates, which are adjusted to reflect current economic developments. As a rule, a decline in the volume of receivables reduces such value adjustments on a portfolio basis accordingly, and vice versa. If individual receivables are at risk of default, estimates and assessments based on the respective client’s creditworthiness are included.

Subsection Title: Critical Accounting Policies
Subsubsection Title: Impairment
Subsubsection Text: The determination of the recoverable amount of a cash generating unit, an asset and an intangible asset with an indefinite useful life is based on management estimates. The recoverable amount is the higher of the fair value less costs to sell, and value in use. Management normally determines these values in line with valuation methods based on discounted cash flows. These discounted cash flows are calculated on the basis of five-year forecasts which are prepared in line with financial plans authorized by the Management Board. The cash flow forecasts take into consideration historical data and are based on the Management Board’s best estimates of future development. Cash flows beyond the planning period are extrapolated applying a standard growth rate that is determined in consideration of the expected long ##### 109 ----- term development potential of the relevant markets and publicly available long-term inflation expectations as well as the possibility of passing these on to customers in the form of price increases. Weighted average costs of capital are utilized to discount the cash flows. These are based on a peer group and were determined using capital market data. The most important assumptions on which the determination of fair value less costs to sell and value in use is based include estimated cash flows, estimated growth rates, weighted average costs of capital, and tax rates. The measurement of intangible assets with indeterminable useful lives is additionally dependent on the underlying license rates. These premises and their underlying methodology can have a significant impact on the respective values and ultimately on the amount of possible impairment of goodwill, intangible assets with indefinite useful lives, and other assets.

Subsection Title: Critical Accounting Policies
Subsubsection Title: Pensions and Similar Obligations
Subsubsection Text: Obligations for pensions and similar commitments and related expenses and income are calculated in accordance with actuarial valuations. Such valuations are based on key assumptions, including discounting factors, wage and pension trends, and life expectancies. The discount factor applied reflects the interest rates that can be achieved as of the balance sheet date for high-value fixed-interest investments with matching maturities. The underlying assumptions can differ from actual outcomes due to a fluctuating market and economic situation. This can exert significant effects on the obligations of pensions and other post-retirement benefits. The resultant differences are recognized directly in other comprehensive income under equity in the period in which they arise, and do not affect profit and loss as a consequence.

Subsection Title: Critical Accounting Policies
Subsubsection Title: Other Provisions
Subsubsection Text: The calculation of provisions is associated with significant estimates. Other provisions are formed for a large number of individual risks whose payment dates or amounts are uncertain. Determining these other provisions requires the making of estimates. These provisions also relate to provisions against risks arising from legal disputes and processes, insofar as these fulfil the criteria for making provisions. Assessing the level of such provisions entails not only an assessment of circumstances in the specific case that is being asserted, but also making recourse to the results of comparable proceedings and appraisals by lawyers and other factors, as well as assumptions about event probabilities and the bandwidths of potential utilization.

Subsection Title: Critical Accounting Policies
Subsubsection Title: Income Tax
Subsubsection Text: The recognition of tax provisions is based on estimates. It should also be determined whether the recognition of deferred tax assets is permitted, or whether a valuation adjustment to deferred tax assets is required. The likelihood that deferred tax assets arising from timing differences and losses carried forward can be offset against taxable profits in the future must be evaluated. Deferred tax assets must also be recognized to the extent that sufficient taxable temporary differences are available. Uncertainties exist concerning the interpretation of complex tax regulations as well as concerning the amount and date of future taxable income.

Subsection Title: Critical Accounting Policies
Subsubsection Text: Our management must make certain estimates and assumptions that affect the amounts reported in the Financial Statements, based on historical experience, existing and known circumstances, authoritative accounting pronouncements and other factors that management believes to be reasonable, but actual results could differ materially from these estimates. The full impact of the COVID-19 pandemic is unknown and cannot be reasonably estimated for these key estimates. However, we made appropriate accounting estimates based on the facts and circumstances available as of the reporting date. To the extent there are differences between these estimates and actual results, our Financial Statements may be materially affected. We apply estimates and judgments by management especially in the following accounting policies.

Subsection Title: Leasing
Subsubsection Text: The measurement of liabilities from leases and rights of use assets requires assumptions to be made regarding key parameters or their probabilities and dates of occurrence or exercise, as well as the determination of an appropriate capitalization rate. In determining the term of leases, all facts and circumstances that provide an economic incentive to exercise renewal options or not to exercise termination options are taken into consideration. Term changes arising from the exercise of renewal or termination options are only included in the contract term if their exercise is reasonably certain. For APCOA PARKING Group this is regularly the case if the exercise option lies within the detailed planning period and is reflected in planning. ##### 110 ----- For further information, please refer to note (10) Accounting and valuation methods, and (41) Information about leases in our 2020 Financial Statements.

Subsection Title: Recent Accounting Pronouncements
Subsubsection Text: From time to time, new accounting pronouncements are issued, which are adopted by us as of the specified effective date. We believe that the adoption of these new standards did not have a significant impact on our Financial Statements. ##### 111 ----- ##### INDUSTRY _In this section, we rely on and refer to information regarding our business and the market in which we operate and compete. The market data and certain economic and industry data and forecasts were obtained from publicly available information and independent industry publications and reports. In many cases, there is no readily available external information (whether from trade associations, government bodies or other organizations) to validate market related analyses and estimates, requiring us to rely on the review of industry publications, including information made available to the public by our competitors. Industry publications and forecasts generally state that the information they contain has been obtained from sources believed to be reliable, but that the accuracy and completeness of such information is not guaranteed. We have not independently verified such data and cannot guarantee their accuracy or completeness._

Subsection Title: Introduction
Subsubsection Text: Parking plays a pivotal role in daily activity around private and professional mobility, local and international travel, leisure and general location based activities, transportation, quality of life and environmental issues. Generally, the parking infrastructure and parking operations and management business, has limited demand risk and limited direct competition. Additionally, the industry benefits from a degree of regulatory protection and stability because it provides a critical service to municipalities. The number of car parking spaces has been growing in Europe driven by a variety of factors which include urbanization and an increase in the number of cars. The profitability of the sector is generally improving, supported by scale efficiencies, the implementation of cost savings programs and the utilization of digital based technologies, among others. In aggregate, there are 24 million parking spaces in APCOA’s geographies, of which approximately 60% are off-street and 40% are on-street. APCOA’s top 6 countries (Germany, United Kingdom, Italy, Sweden, Denmark and Norway) account for 18 million of these spaces, of which 11 million are offstreet. Despite approximately 40% of European parking spaces being on-street, major industry players are focused on the off-street segment due to legislation that restricts private operators from operating onstreet car spaces. Parking spaces located in cities and shopping centers are the two largest sectors in Europe, accounting for 70% of regulated off-street parking spaces.

Subsection Title: Parking Market by Segment
Subsubsection Text: Based on segment, the parking market is divided between on-street and off-street car parks.

Subsection Title: On-street parking spaces are regulated spaces on the roadway with some type of signaling, control or
Subsubsection Text: surveillance and can be paid or be for free. Parking is short-term, and this segment is typically very much exposed to city policies and regulatory changes. In this segment, parking operators usually offer meter management services (i.e. management and maintenance of parking meters) and revenue collection (i.e. issuance and collection of fines through enforcement services) on behalf of the municipality.

Subsection Title: Off-street parking spaces are parking spaces for public-use in dedicated facilities. These can be both
Subsubsection Text: indoor and outdoor, single or multi-storey and used short-term (hourly) or long-term (monthly and yearly). They tend to be located in high footfall locations e.g. city centers and airports. These spaces can be: i) publicly or privately managed; ii) paid or for free, and; iii) in-structure or on-surface. Instructure parking refers to multilevel or underground car parks while on-surface refers to uncovered car parks at street level with horizontal signs and access control (barrier, attendant, ANPR etc.). An additional category of off-street parking is Park & Ride, consisting of parking spaces close to coach, ##### 112 ----- rail stations or other means of transport that allow commuters to leave their vehicle and commute via bus, rail, etc. for the remainder of the journey. The off-street segment is the most relevant in terms of overall economics generated given the significantly higher revenue per space and EBITDA margins compared to on-street (lower margin profile for on-street parking is primarily driven by cost-plus outsourcing enforcement contracts). Within off-street parking, spaces located in cities and shopping centers represent the largest segment accounting for c. 70% of the total outsourced market, followed by spaces located in airports.

Subsection Title: Car Parking Location
Subsubsection Text: Parking spaces located in city and shopping centers and airports account for a large proportion of the market. Parking spaces located in city and shopping centers typically have high turnover with shorter stays lasting a few hours or a day. Landlords are mainly municipalities, infrastructure funds, companies, private investors, shopping centre operators / owners in addition to a large number of less sophisticated private landlords. Parking spaces located in airports typically have a lower rotation given travelling passengers stay for days to weeks at a time (except for drop-off parkers). Landlords are mainly sophisticated airport operators / owners given the importance and size of the business with relevant negotiation power upon contract renewal. Given the growing importance of car parking economics within airport activities, in a few cases airport operators have decided to keep the management of parking spaces in-house in order to realize all car park economics despite a lack of operating experience. Contracts are usually large and the underlying volume risk is linked to air traffic volume. Volume risk is mitigated by an ongoing shift in the airport parking market to management contracts (primarily fixed fee) and the introduction of specific clauses within lease agreements limiting downside risks for airport parking operators.

Subsection Title: Parking Market by Operating Model
Subsubsection Text: By operating model, the car park market can be split by: (i) management contracts, (ii) lease contracts, (iii) concessions and (iv) full ownership.

Subsection Title: Management contracts represent service agreements with short to mid-term contract length, usually
Subsubsection Text: 3-8 years, where the operator is responsible for operating a car park on behalf of the landlord or concession owner. Overall risks to the operator under these contracts are very limited given low investments required, no exposure to traffic risk and limited location risk. Facility maintenance activities are generally up to the landlord and other required investments are very limited from the operator perspective. The operator is not subject to traffic risk as most contracts primarily involve fee based payments given that strategic decisions like tariff policy, etc., remain with the landlord of the car park. There is limited exposure to location risk given the length of these contracts. Management contract business represent approximately 30-40% of total European market spaces, with a typical contract contribution margin of 10-20%. The lower economics generated by this segment in terms of revenue and margin can be explained by the lower underlying risk of the business, given a revenue model based on broadly fixed fees agreed with the landlord, where the revenue generated by the consumers that park go directly to the landlord, hence no volume risk, and limited investment and location risks.

Subsection Title: Lease contracts represent rental agreements with mid-term contract lengths, usually between seven to
Subsubsection Text: 20 years (including options to extend), where the operator runs the parking facility and pays an annual rent to the lessor that can be fixed and/or variable depending on specific success factors. Overall risk borne by the operator under these types of contracts is higher than with management contracts but sensibly lower compared to concession and full ownership agreements, given lower investments ##### 113 ----- required, and lower location risk. Under lease contracts the operator is responsible for installation & maintenance of parking equipment. Other investments required are usually limited and shared with the landlord, however higher than the ones required under management contracts. The operator is subject to full traffic exposure given the revenue stream is mainly based on car park ticket fares from users. Lease contracts represent the largest proportion (approximately 40-50%) of total European market spaces, with a typical contract contribution margin of 15-25%. There is limited location risk compared to concession or full ownership agreements given the limited 7-20-year contract length.

Subsection Title: Concessions represent long-term contracts with duration typically between 30-50 (sometimes up to 99)
Subsubsection Text: years, where the operator acts as a temporary owner responsible also for building maintenance activities. In greenfield concessions the operator is responsible for both building and operating the new car park on behalf of a concession-owner to whom it pays royalties. In brownfield concessions the operator runs an existing car park on behalf of a concession-owner to whom it pays royalties, but the operator is not involved in the construction of the car park and hence initial investment requirements are lower than in greenfield concessions. In both cases the operator is exposed to high investment requirements and full traffic risk, given the revenue stream is mainly based on car park ticket fares from users. Furthermore, the operator is subject to any long-term location risk that might arise. Under **full ownership the operator owns the parking facilities. This model requires high capital investment including build-up of the facility or buy-out of existing property and ongoing maintenance investments. The operator is exposed to high investment requirements and full short and long-term traffic and location risk, given the revenue stream is mainly based on car park ticket fares from users. By number of spaces, concession and full ownership operating models represent approximately 5-15% of European parking spaces, with a typical contract contribution margin of 30-40%. Margins in this segment are the highest in the market given the higher capital invested and risk exposure compared to other operating models.

Subsection Title: Car Parking Locations
Subsubsection Text: The car park industry can be divided into various sectors and locations with different characteristics:

Subsection Title: Structural Growth Drivers of the Parking Sector
Subsubsection Title: Personal Car Fleet Growth and Urbanization
Subsubsection Text: In Western Europe, the vehicle parc is expected to continue growing steadily at +0.8% CAGR from 2021-2025E, and remain an important driver of the parking industry’s turnover. Additionally, the Western European urban population is forecasted to increase by +0.4% CAGR from 2021-2025E. This increase is expected to drive demand for parking in cities.

Subsection Title: Structural Growth Drivers of the Parking Sector
Subsubsection Title: Favorable Pricing Dynamics that Support Larger Companies
Subsubsection Text: Larger companies in the parking industry benefit from the high barriers to entry, particularly in offstreet parking which include: - Operational economies of scale which support the pricing and winning of new contracts - Pricing power advantage stemming from operating car parks in close proximity to each other Limited supply of new parking spaces, especially in city centers, which benefits the larger players with established positions and long-term contracts

Subsection Title: Structural Growth Drivers of the Parking Sector
Subsubsection Title: Shift in Cities from On-street to Off-street Parking
Subsubsection Text: Across Europe, particularly in large city centers, local municipalities are disincentivising on-street parking due to urban planning, traffic and environmental concerns. They continue to do this through increasing pricing, reducing spaces and introducing maximum allowed parking times. ##### 115 |Col1|Non-Airport|Airport| |---|---|---| |Customer Segments|• Key split is turnover with several shorter stays for few hours (e.g. for shopping trips) or a day (e.g. parking for work)|• Generally, low turnover given travelling passengers stay for several days to weeks
